[1013923] A member of the compliance team is confirming the compliance of a financial promotion with FCA rules. Which of the following must be included in the promotion?
A
Capital at risk products are clearly referred to as such
B
It labels the regulator as MiFID
C
It quotes a variety of expected returns
D
It must take into account the British Bankers' Association Code of Conduct
The correct answer is: A - Capital at risk products are clearly referred to as such

Explanation

MiFID is a directive, not a regulator. The expected returns figure should give a balanced view of the long and short term prospects of the investment instrument, but it is not something that must be included in the promotion.

Question 40

[1014090] When a firm communicates initially with a retail client it must provide 'appropriate information', which includes all of the following except:
A
The firm's name and address
B
A statement that it is FCA authorised or regulated
C
The name and status of the person they can contact
D
Who to refer complaints to if they cannot be resolved by the firm
The correct answer is: D - Who to refer complaints to if they cannot be resolved by the firm

Explanation

Reference to any complaints resolution body is not necessary.

Question 41

[1015045] Which of the following statements are true regarding money awaiting re-investment that is being held by an authorised firm on behalf of a client?
I
It must be kept in a client money account with an approved bank
II
Interest must be paid on the client money account if the funds are held for more than 10 days, or if it is in excess of £10,000
III
Client money accounts must be reconciled as often as necessary
A
I and II
B
II and III
C
I and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - I and III

Explanation

Interest must be paid on client money accounts to the client UNLESS there has been a written arrangement to the contrary. If there is to be no interest paid to a retail client, the retail client must be informed of this in writing.

Question 42

[1014079] Which clients need to have the most comprehensive risk explanation provided to them?
A
An execution only retail client selling shares to the firm
B
An execution only retail client selling warrants
C
A discretionary professional client engaged in derivatives
D
An execution only retail client buying options
The correct answer is: D - An execution only retail client buying options

Explanation

The risks should be explained to the client as specified by the client's knowledge etc. given that the first two are sales of assets pre-owned. A professional client would most likely not have a significant explanation of the risks given the requirements, as they are considered to have sufficient knowledge and experience.

Question 43

[1013993] A firm may treat a client as an elective professional client for non-MiFID business if:
A
The qualitative test alone is passed
B
The quantitative test alone is passed
C
Both the quantitative and qualitative tests are passed
D
The qualitative test is passed and there is a statement that protection will be lost
The correct answer is: D - The qualitative test is passed and there is a statement that protection will be lost

Explanation

The quantitative test is only used for MiFID business. The qualitative test and a statement of protection loss are always required. The client must state that it wishes to be treated as a professional client, the firm must warn the client that the loss of protection might occur and the client has to state, in writing, separate to any contracts, that it is aware of this loss of protection.

Question 44

[1013931] As an employee of an authorised firm, you are just about to make a personal recommendation to a client. Before doing so you must ensure that the investment:
A
Has no risk
B
Is compatible with the client's level of experience and understanding of the risks involved
C
Contains only packaged products in the case of retail clients
D
Allows the client to take advantage of gearing opportunities whenever available
The correct answer is: B - Is compatible with the client's level of experience and understanding of the risks involved

Explanation

Clearly portfolios may have risk. The opportunity of gearing opportunities is too strong in this statement. Retail clients are able to invest in more than only packaged products.

Question 45

[1015004] What best describes the way a tied agent should act when advising on packaged products?
A
The tied agent must recommend the packaged products of his/her marketing group
B
The tied agent must recommend the best available packaged product
C
The tied agent must recommend the packaged product of his/her marketing group that best suits the needs of the client
D
As long as the scope of advice is made clear the tied agent has no other responsibilities
The correct answer is: C - The tied agent must recommend the packaged product of his/her marketing group that best suits the needs of the client

Explanation

This question assumes the advisor is an appointed representative of an authorised firm rather than an independent financial advisor.

Question 46

[1013960] A firm finds itself in possession of money that belongs to a client. In which of the following situations would the firm need to apply the client money rules?
A
If the money is paid as part of a transaction due for settlement within one business day
B
If the money is due to the firm for its own account
C
If the money is interest paid on any holdings of client money
D
If the money has been paid to the client or authorised representative of the client
The correct answer is: C - If the money is interest paid on any holdings of client money

Explanation

Within a delivery versus payment, if the money is due within one business day it is not necessary to count the money as client money. Once it is paid to a client then the money ceases to be client money. Only interest, if paid, is client money.

Question 47

[1014081] A key features document (KFD) must be provided when:
A
Selling packaged products to a retail client
B
Selling packaged products to any client
C
Selling packaged products to a professional client
D
Selling any product to a retail client
The correct answer is: A - Selling packaged products to a retail client

Explanation

A firm must send a KFD to a retail client unless a simplified prospectus is used. These documents must be in a durable medium.

Question 48

[1013903] All key features documents must include information:
A
That the firm is passported under MiFID
B
Explaining the cancellation procedure
C
Commenting on the applicability of stakeholder pensions rather than the product covered
D
Containing sufficient material such that a professional client is able to make an informed decision
The correct answer is: B - Explaining the cancellation procedure

Explanation

'That the firm is passported under MiFID' is irrelevant for the KFD. The stakeholder pension clauses are necessary only for personal pension schemes and the information must be sufficient for a retail client to understand and make an informed decision.

Question 49

[1015037] When a firm is acting as an investment manager, periodic statements must always be sent to which one of the following types of client?
A
Professional clients resident in the UK
B
Retail clients resident in the UK
C
Retail clients resident overseas
D
Professional clients resident overseas
The correct answer is: B - Retail clients resident in the UK

Explanation

Retail clients of an investment manager, who are resident in the UK, need to receive periodic statements every six months. The exception to this is if a portfolio contains uncovered open positions in a contingent liability, then the statements need to be sent monthly.

Question 50

[1015020] What type of service is best suited for a retail client who has decided to sell shares?
A
Advisory
B
Discretionary
C
Execution only
D
Portfolio management
The correct answer is: C - Execution only

Explanation

A retail client who has decided to sell shares will not require advice or investment management services.

Question 51

[1013896] The requirements for record keeping according to MiFID are:
A
Six years
B
Five years
C
Three years
D
Indefinitely
The correct answer is: B - Five years

Explanation

The directive explicitly states that firms must keep records for a period of five years. If the record sets out rights and obligations of the investment firm and the client, it should be kept for the duration of the relationship with the client. Competent authorities may require firms to keep these records for up to five years after that relationship ceases.

Question 52

[1014083] Which of the following are not protected by the conduct of business rules sourcebook?
A
Personal recommendations to a retail client
B
Pension transfers for retail client
C
Acting as investment manager for a retail client
D
Property purchases by a retail client
The correct answer is: D - Property purchases by a retail client

Explanation

The purchase of property is not classed as a regulated activity.

Question 53

[1013961] The firm is holding money belonging to clients. When would it NOT need to comply with the client money rules?
A
If the money is coins held for the value of their metal
B
If the money is held in a central bank
C
If the money is interest paid by an FCA authorised firm
D
If the money is being held in a money market deposit account
The correct answer is: A - If the money is coins held for the value of their metal

Explanation

A firm does not need to apply the client money rules to coins held for the value of their metal on behalf of clients.

Question 54

[1013979] The firm need not inform a retail client of the nature and risks of which of the following regulated activities:
A
Managing designated investments
B
Arranging a warrant deal
C
Making a recommendation on a designated investment
D
Entering a funeral plan agreement
The correct answer is: D - Entering a funeral plan agreement

Explanation

The first three are specified in COBS as requiring a notice.

Question 55

[1013900] A firm has searched through its client list, looking for those that have been inactive for some time. They plan to cold call these clients. If these clients are retail clients, which of the following products are permitted to be sold on the cold call?
A
A generally marketable packaged product that has lower volatility
B
A life policy linked to high volatility funds
C
A firm cannot sell any product on a cold call to a retail client
D
Shares in an inverse leveraged exchange traded fund
The correct answer is: A - A generally marketable packaged product that has lower volatility

Explanation

The others are prohibited - either due to the increased risk through volatility or gearing, or the derivative aspects of the products. Where it comes to shares, they must be readily realisable. It is also worth noting that it is only the services relating to these shares that can be sold on the cold call, not the shares themselves.

Question 56

[1013997] According to COBS, which of the following is not considered an execution venue?
A
Market maker
B
Retail broker
C
Multilateral trading facility
D
Regulated market
The correct answer is: B - Retail broker

Explanation

As well as these three, the COBS also states other liquidity providers (such as stock borrowing and lending intermediaries or inter dealer brokers) could also be considered execution venues.

Question 57

[1014088] An authorised firm provides a service to a retail client. The FCA requires that the firm discloses its charges to that client. When should this disclosure occur?
A
At the time of doing business
B
Before doing business
C
After a reasonable period of doing business
D
At the discretion of the firm
The correct answer is: B - Before doing business

Explanation

Charges must be made clear to retail clients before doing business. (They may be disclosed to professional clients within a reasonable time of starting business).

Question 58

[1014093] What is the minimum amount of net turnover that a trust must have to be classified as professional client for MiFID business?
A
100 million
B
75 million
C
50 million
D
40 million
The correct answer is: D - 40 million

Explanation

MiFID requires at least 40 million in addition to at least one other of the quantitative tests. The other quantitative tests are: - net assets 20m - own funds 2m This is true of any undertaking, whether a company, charity or trust.

Question 59

[1013982] Which of the following is not defined as a packaged product according to COBS?
A
A regulated CIS
B
A personal pension scheme
C
An interest in an investment trust savings scheme
D
A government or public security
The correct answer is: D - A government or public security

Explanation

A government or public security would be considered a readily realisable security, according to COBS.

Question 60

[1013953] If an analyst invests in a UCITS collective investment scheme, how soon should they contact the compliance team to inform them of any increase in the number of units they hold?
A
Immediately irrespective of the analyst's relationship with the CIS
B
Within one business day if the analyst has no relationship with the CIS
C
Immediately if the analyst has no relationship with the CIS
D
There is no need if the analyst has no management relationship with the CIS
The correct answer is: D - There is no need if the analyst has no management relationship with the CIS

Explanation

So long as the person is not involved with the management of the UCITS CIS undertaking then the personal account dealing rules do not apply.

Question 61

[1013921] What information must always be included in a firm's order execution policy for retail clients?
A
The process the firm uses to specify relative importance of the execution factors
B
The exchange that the transaction will definitely be traded on
C
The price that the firm will get for the transaction
D
The foreign exchange rate that will be used in the transaction
The correct answer is: A - The process the firm uses to specify relative importance of the execution factors

Explanation

The firm will include a list of POSSIBLE venues... not necessarily the specific exchange. It will not have to specify the price nor the FX rate in the execution policy details.

Question 62

[1013925] If the information presented by a firm contains an indication of simulated past performance then which of the following must be satisfied?
A
The simulated past performance relates to a derivatives index
B
The actual past performance of the investment is ignored
C
Simulated past performance is based on actual past performance of instruments that are the same as or underlie the investment concerned
D
A statement that the simulated past performance is a reliable indicator of the future performance of the instrument
The correct answer is: C - Simulated past performance is based on actual past performance of instruments that are the same as or underlie the investment concerned

Explanation

Simulations need not relate to a derivatives index.

Question 63

[1013951] If the firm aggregates a client's order with a transaction for its own account, which of the following is true?
A
The firm's allocation, if the order is partially allocated, must take priority
B
The client's allocation, if the order is partially allocated, must take priority
C
The allocation must be in proportion with the order size
D
A retail client's allocation, if the order is partially allocated, must take priority over a professional client's order
The correct answer is: B - The client's allocation, if the order is partially allocated, must take priority

Explanation

COBS states that the client must take priority on an aggregated order allocation. There is no stipulation as to whether the client needs to be a retail or professional client.

Question 64

[1014008] A firm that manages a client's investments must ensure that which of the following occurs?
A
The portfolio must be benchmarked against the FTSE All Shares Index
B
They benchmark portfolio performance at least monthly
C
They specify any index against which performance will be compared
D
They outline only the types of designated investments in the portfolio
The correct answer is: C - They specify any index against which performance will be compared

Explanation

The first benchmark (FTSE All Shares) might be comparable in some cases but not all and so is not the best answer here. The timing of performance benchmarking is not specified in the COBS. The firm should also include an outline of any designated investments that may be included in the portfolio, not just those in which it is currently invested.

Question 65

[1013904] In order to make a recommendation to its clients, and assuming knowledge and experience and objectives have been assessed, which of the following also needs to be assessed?
A
The client's employment history
B
Whether the client is accustomed to trading in derivative instruments
C
The client's financial situation
D
If the client has the experience to trade in all designated investments
The correct answer is: C - The client's financial situation

Explanation

The employment history is not required; rather, the client's financial situation, including real estate, sources of income, liquid assets etc. Experience in derivatives is only necessary as part of a decision to recommend that type of instrument. Clearly a requirement to have experience in all designated investments is not required - only the specific type is necessary.

Question 66

[1013952] Martin gives an instruction to a stockbroking firm to sell a holding of shares at a limit price much higher than the current market price quoted by that firm. Assuming that there have been no specific instructions beyond the order itself, which of the following best reflects what Martin can expect to happen?
A
The firm will wait for the market to move to the limit price and then execute
B
The firm must execute immediately at the limit price, regardless of the firm's quoted price
C
The firm will execute immediately at the quoted market price as it is below the limit price
D
The firm will be unwilling to execute at the limit price, so will place the order on a regulated market
The correct answer is: D - The firm will be unwilling to execute at the limit price, so will place the order on a regulated market

Explanation

The order must be disclosed for soonest execution, possibly via transmission to an order book. There is an exception to this rule for large orders.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1015060] If a complaint has been received by a firm and remains unresolved, how soon after the firm receives it can the client refer the complaint to the Financial Ombudsman?
A
Four weeks
B
Six weeks
C
Eight weeks
D
Six months
The correct answer is: C - Eight weeks

Explanation

The client has the right to refer the complaint to the Financial Ombudsman if it has not been resolved eight weeks after it has been received by the firm. The firm must also give the client a leaflet about the Financial Ombudsman service.

Question 2

[1049916] Which of the following comes under 'compulsory jurisdiction' of the Financial Ombudsman Service?
A
Plastic cards including credit card transaction
B
Mortgages
C
General insurance
D
Pension provision
The correct answer is: D - Pension provision

Explanation

Currently, the following can be considered under voluntary jurisdiction: lending on mortgages by non-FCA-authorised firms; other specified lending activity; providing payments on plastic cards (excluding store cards); accepting deposits and providing general insurance where the service was provided from elsewhere within the EEA but was directed at the UK.

Question 3

[1000396] Which of the following is UNTRUE in respect of the procedures of an authorised firm for dealing with client complaints?
A
Firms must have adequate internal controls put in place
B
Firms must refer all complaints to the regulator
C
The firm must remedy legitimate grievances
D
The firm has a duty to inform clients of other avenues of complaint
The correct answer is: B - Firms must refer all complaints to the regulator

Explanation

Internal complaints procedures must be in writing and cover the receipt of complaints, methods of response and how they will be investigated. Complaints should be handled by a member of staff with sufficient experience and authority, and who was not involved in the matter. If a complaint cannot be resolved, the firm must inform the client about their rights to complain to the Financial Ombudsman and provide the client with the explanatory leaflet about the Financial Ombudsman Service.

Question 4

[1000388] What is the maximum payout that will be made for deposits under the FSCS?
A
£48,000
B
£37,000
C
£35,000
D
£85,000
The correct answer is: D - £85,000

Explanation

The FSCS currently pay out 100% of the first £85,000.

Question 5

[1015066] If a complainant accepts the determination of the Financial Ombudsman, it is:
A
At the discretion of the firm
B
Implemented through an RIE
C
Binding on the firm
D
Binding on the client
The correct answer is: C - Binding on the firm

Explanation

If the complainant accepts the determination of the Financial Ombudsman, this is then binding on the firm.

Question 6

[1015065] If, either party does not agree with a provisional assessment by the Financial Ombudsman, the next step will be:
A
Referral to the FCA
B
Disciplinary action
C
A written statement
D
Referral for arbitration
The correct answer is: C - A written statement

Explanation

If either party disagrees with a provisional assessment, the next step is a written statement from the Ombudsman of the determination, and the reasons for it.

Question 7

[1015068] Which ONE of the following statements about a firm's internal complaints procedure is FALSE?
A
The complaints procedure must be in writing
B
It must cover how complaints will be investigated
C
Complaints must be dealt with by someone involved in the subject matter of the complaint
D
The procedure must detail the method of response to complaints
The correct answer is: C - Complaints must be dealt with by someone involved in the subject matter of the complaint

Explanation

It is important that complaints are dealt with by someone impartial and not involved in the same area.

Question 8

[1015069] If the FOS (Financial Ombudsman Service) makes an award it can be for:
I
Actual financial loss
II
Pain and suffering
III
Damage to reputation
IV
Distress or inconvenience
A
I, III and IV
B
I, II, III and IV
C
I and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: B - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

The FOS (financial ombudsman service) can make awards for a range of reasons including financial loss, pain and suffering, damage to reputation and distress or inconvenience.

Question 9

[1014013] If a firm receives and deals with a complaint with respect to non-MiFID business, how long is it necessary to keep the records of the complaint?
A
Five years from the date of the resolution of the complaint
B
Three years from the receipt of the complaint
C
Five years from the date of the complaint
D
Three years from the date of the resolution of the complaint
The correct answer is: B - Three years from the receipt of the complaint

Explanation

For non-MiFID business, the records are kept for at least three years.

Question 10

[1000390] Who, in the first instance, should a customer refer a complaint to?
A
The Financial Ombudsman Service
B
The Treasury
C
A magistrate
D
The firm itself
The correct answer is: D - The firm itself

Explanation

Complaints should, in the first instance, be referred to the firm. If the dispute is not resolved, it may then be referred to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

Question 11

[1015070] Which statement about the Financial Ombudsman Scheme is false?
A
It is independent of the FCA
B
It was set up by the FCA
C
It is for large institutional corporate clients as well as individuals
D
It can consider complaints and make awards
The correct answer is: C - It is for large institutional corporate clients as well as individuals

Explanation

The FOS (Financial Ombudsman Scheme) is for individuals, and very small companies, charities and trusts.

Question 12

[1000402] How much can an eligible complainant claim from the Financial Services Compensation Scheme with respect to long term protected insurance products?
A
100% of a maximum £50,000 claim
B
100% of the first £30,000 plus 90% of the next £20,000
C
100% of the first £2000, then 90% of the remainder
D
90% of valid claims and unexpired premiums
The correct answer is: D - 90% of valid claims and unexpired premiums

Explanation

For most insurance contracts 90% of valid claims and unexpired premiums are protected. For compulsory insurance 100% is protected.

Question 13

[1000395] In what circumstances could a claim on the Financial Services Compensation Scheme be made?
A
When an authorised firm becomes insolvent
B
Exclusively in response to claims by retail clients
C
Breach of principles of business
D
As an alternative to mediation by the Financial Ombudsman Scheme
The correct answer is: A - When an authorised firm becomes insolvent

Explanation

The Financial Services Compensation Scheme was established to provide compensation where authorised persons and appointed representatives are unable to satisfy claims against them. Although the scheme mainly applies to retail clients, it can also apply to professional clients and eligible counterparties.

Question 14

[1015058] After what length of time must a firm advise the FCA of a complaint lodged by a client which has not been dealt with to the client's satisfaction?
A
No time limit
B
4 weeks
C
8 weeks
D
26 weeks
The correct answer is: D - 26 weeks

Explanation

An authorised firm must report a summary of all complaints to the FCA every six months (26 weeks), whether it has been dealt with to the client's satisfaction or not.

Question 15

[1015062] For how long must firms retain records of complaints relating to non MiFID business?
A
Three weeks
B
Three months
C
Thirteen months
D
Three years
The correct answer is: D - Three years

Explanation

A firm must retain records of complaints for at least three years. Firms must also provide the FCA with twice-yearly reports on the number of complaints, and completions of complaints, with four and eight weeks of receipt.

Question 16

[1000394] To whom is the Financial Service Compensation Scheme (FSCS) primarily accountable?
A
The Treasury
B
FCA
C
Lord Chancellor
D
The First Lord of the Treasury
The correct answer is: B - FCA

Explanation

The FSCS is accountable to the FCA primarily and to the Treasury through the FCA only.

Question 17

[1000401] A complaint is NOT considered resolved where:
I
The firm has made a final response
II
The complainant has indicated in writing acceptance of the firm's response
III
The complainant has not responded to the firm after eight weeks of the firm's written response
IV
The complainant has not responded to the firm within four weeks of the firm's written acknowledgement
A
I and II
B
II and III
C
I and IV
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I and IV

Explanation

Sending out a final response, in itself, does not resolve a complaint. The firm has to wait for the client to accept the response before the complaint is resolved. However, often clients do not respond. If the client has not responded to a response after eight weeks, the firm can consider the complaint resolved. Once a complaint is resolved, no further action by the firm is necessary.

Question 18

[1015061] If a complaint has not been resolved within eight weeks, which of the following must be given to a complainant?
A
A leaflet about the Financial Ombudsman Service
B
A leaflet about the Financial Conduct Authority
C
A leaflet about the Mortgage Code
D
A leaflet about the Consumer Credit Council
The correct answer is: A - A leaflet about the Financial Ombudsman Service

Explanation

When a complaint has not been settled within eight weeks of receipt, the firm must give the client an explanatory leaflet about the Financial Ombudsman Service. The firm must also let the client know that he has the right to complain to the Financial Ombudsman.

Question 19

[1000389] Harold has lost £35,000 through a failed investment scheme. How much will be paid if his claim to the compensation scheme is successful?
A
£35,000
B
£34,500
C
£31,500
D
£30,000
The correct answer is: A - £35,000

Explanation

Investors can claim for up to £50,000 of losses with regard to investments and will receive a payout of 100% of that claim. For deposits this limit is £85,000.

Question 20

[1015063] How frequently must a firm supply the FCA with reports on the number of complaints and completions of complaints received by the firm?
A
Once a year
B
Once every two months
C
Once a month
D
Twice a year
The correct answer is: D - Twice a year

Explanation

A firm must provide the FCA with a twice-yearly report on the number of complaints and completions of complaints within four and eight weeks of receipt. They must also report the number of complaints accepted as valid by the firm.

Question 21

[1000400] The FCA requires that firms maintain records of complaints for a period of three years from the date of the receipt of the complaint for non-MiFID business. These records need not include details of:
A
Any correspondence between the firm and the complainant, including details of any redress offered by the firm
B
The number of phone calls taken place in an attempt to resolve the complaint
C
The substance of the complaint
D
The name of the complainant
The correct answer is: B - The number of phone calls taken place in an attempt to resolve the complaint

Explanation

These records are required for the purposes of monitoring by the FCA.

Question 22

[1015067] The maximum financial award by the Financial Ombudsman is:
A
Established in each case
B
Up to £150,000
C
Up to 150,000 or equivalent
D
On a sliding scale
The correct answer is: B - Up to £150,000

Explanation

The maximum financial award a firm can make is £150,000. Awards over £150,000 can be requested from a firm, but the firm is not compelled to pay them.

Question 23

[1015071] Which of the following statements are true regarding complaints against a firm which is being investigated by the Financial Ombudsman?
I
During the investigation the firm must co-operate fully with the Ombudsman
II
There is no ceiling regarding the award the Ombudsman may make against the firm
III
Any money award made by the Ombudsman against the firm is binding on the firm
A
I and III
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

The rules for the Ombudsman state that the maximum award the Ombudsman may make is £150,000. If the Ombudsman feels that an amount in excess of the maximum is appropriate it can invite the firm to pay the balance. Awards made by the Ombudsman against the firm may be recovered or enforced through the courts.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1015103] Which of the following are TRUE of money laundering?
I
The JMLSG Guidance Notes have received Treasury approval
II
It is a criminal offence not to report a suspicion
III
It is a criminal offence not to have procedures in place
A
I and II only
B
II and III only
C
I and III only
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

The Courts are required to take account of Guidance approved by the Treasury, such as the Guidance Notes. All are correct.

Question 2

[1015095] Passing on price sensitive information is primarily what type of offence?
A
Civil
B
Criminal
C
Non-statutory
D
Disciplinary
The correct answer is: B - Criminal

Explanation

Insider dealing is a criminal offence.

Question 3

[1015104] All of the following are covered by the insider dealing legislation except:
A
Futures
B
Forward foreign exchange contracts
C
Depository receipts
D
Warrants
The correct answer is: B - Forward foreign exchange contracts

Explanation

The insider dealing legislation relates specifically to abuses of information in respect of securities markets. This therefore includes instruments based on securities, such as stock index futures, share warrants and equity options. It does not relate to FX markets, such as foreign exchange forward contracts. Additionally, the legislation does not cover assets with no secondary market, such as unit trusts.

Question 4

[1012334] What is the maximum penalty for unauthorised investment business?
A
One year in jail
B
Two years in jail
C
Three years in jail
D
Five years in jail
The correct answer is: B - Two years in jail

Explanation

In a CROWN Court the maximum penalty is two years and an unlimited fine. NB: In a Magistrates' Court the maximum penalty is six months and a £5000 fine.

Question 5

[1015092] Which of the following is the FCA most likely to take into consideration, when deciding the amount of a fine for market abuse?
A
The age of the Individuals involved
B
The time that the behaviour took place
C
If the behaviour was deliberate or reckless
D
If the behaviour created a profit or a loss
The correct answer is: C - If the behaviour was deliberate or reckless

Explanation

The FCA can impose fines and in determining how much these should be for, it must consider if the behaviour was deliberate or reckless amongst other factors.

Question 6

[1015076] Which is not an example of insider dealing?
A
Encouraging someone to deal on the strength of price sensitive information
B
Dealing oneself on the strength of price sensitive information
C
Passing on price sensitive information
D
Disclosing price sensitive information in proper performance of duty
The correct answer is: D - Disclosing price sensitive information in proper performance of duty

Explanation

Insider dealing is a criminal offence under the Criminal Justices Act 1993.

Question 7

[1015112] Restricted information is NOT related to:
A
Equities
B
Gilts
C
Commodity futures
D
Derivatives
The correct answer is: C - Commodity futures

Explanation

Restricted information relates to securities markets only, not commodities.

Question 8

[1015098] Which of the following prosecutes insider dealers?
A
London Stock Exchange
B
Department of Trade and Industry
C
Treasury
D
Financial Conduct Authority
The correct answer is: D - Financial Conduct Authority

Explanation

The FCA can bring prosecutions for insider dealing. The London Stock Exchange has an obligation to monitor transactions to identify potential cases of insider dealing.

Question 9

[1047694] An employee has noticed that one of his clients has started settling transactions in Australian dollars. There is nothing in the 'Know Your Customer' information that would suggest this is to be expected. Which is the following is the best description of the action that the employee should take?
A
Contact the customer to discuss it
B
Report the client to their Money Laundering Reporting Officer
C
Report the client to the National Crime Agency
D
Report the client to the Financial Conduct Authority
The correct answer is: B - Report the client to their Money Laundering Reporting Officer

Explanation

The best course of action would be for the employee to report these transactions to their MLRO. They should not contact the client as this may alert them that they are being investigated for money laundering.

Question 10

[1015100] Which of the following is not true of insider dealing?
A
It only applies to dealings via a regulated market
B
Gilts are included in the law on insider dealing
C
The FCA is responsible for prosecuting offences
D
An exemption exists if it can be shown that the individual would have acted as he did if he had not had the information
The correct answer is: A - It only applies to dealings via a regulated market

Explanation

The legislation applies to dealings on a regulated market OR by or via a professional intermediary. The legislation applies to all investments except those where there is no secondary market. Investments such as unit trusts, and life policies, have no secondary market.

Question 11

[1015106] Which of the following are TRUE regarding insider dealing?
I
Offences are committed by individuals not corporations
II
Encouraging a third party to deal is an offence
III
UK equities and gilts and their derivatives are covered
IV
Disclosure, other than in the normal course of business, is an offence
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, II and IV
C
II and IV
D
I and III
The correct answer is: A - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Insider dealing is a crime committed by INDIVIDUALS. Offences include dealing, encouraging and passing on information.

Question 12

[1015086] Which one of the following is not a money laundering offence as defined in the Proceeds of Crime Act?
A
Tipping off
B
Failure to report
C
Assistance
D
Dealing on price sensitive information
The correct answer is: D - Dealing on price sensitive information

Explanation

This is an offence under the INSIDER DEALING legislation.

Question 13

[1015082] Which of the following would not be covered by the insider dealing legislation?
A
An options trade on NYSE Liffe
B
OTC interest and currency options facilitated by an accountant
C
Buying shares through an internet broker
D
Buying gilts through a broker
The correct answer is: B - OTC interest and currency options facilitated by an accountant

Explanation

The essence of insider dealing is access to some inside information on a company. Interest rate and currency derivatives are unrelated to company performance and so would not be affected by the insider dealing legislation.

Question 14

[1015074] Insider dealing is which of the following?
I
Acting on price sensitive information of which the source is known to be an insider
II
Selling bonds whilst in possession of price sensitive information, but in a forced sale
III
A predator buying shares in a target company
A
II only
B
I only
C
I and II
D
II and III
The correct answer is: B - I only

Explanation

Forced sales are exempt under the defence of 'not to make a profit or avoid a loss'.

Question 15

[1015111] The law relating to insider dealing as a criminal offence is contained in:
A
FSMA 2000
B
The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002
C
Criminal Justice Act 1993
D
Companies Act 1985
The correct answer is: C - Criminal Justice Act 1993

Explanation

The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 outlines criminal money laundering offences, FSMA 2000 section 118 covers market abuse and the civil regime.

Question 16

[1015109] Market abuse is different from the offence of insider dealing in all of the following ways EXCEPT:
A
The guilt is based on the civil burden of proof, i.e. the balance of probabilities
B
It should be easier for the FCA to demonstrate guilt
C
It should be easier for the FCA to impose a custodial sentence
D
It can apply to commodity derivatives
The correct answer is: C - It should be easier for the FCA to impose a custodial sentence

Explanation

The burden of proof is less difficult to establish than beyond a reasonable doubt and hence it should be easier to obtain a conviction. However, only fines can be imposed. Market abuse is applicable across the board.

Question 17

[1015116] An employee is processing a single premium investment in the Megafund Life Fund. The client has made an unusual £50,000 cash payment to Megafund. To whom is the employee required to report this?
A
His manager
B
Megafund's MLRO
C
IFA who introduced the client
D
Megafund's Compliance Officer
The correct answer is: B - Megafund's MLRO

Explanation

The implication here is that the report is being made for money laundering purposes and therefore the employee must report suspicions to the money laundering reporting officer of the firm.

Question 18

[1015114] Which of the following is FALSE about the Joint Money Laundering Steering Group?
A
It comprises 14 organisations, including the British Banking Association
B
Breach of the guidance notes constitutes breach of FCA rules
C
It provides guidance on how the statutory regulations should be applied
D
The guidance notes provide an exception in respect of FCA regulations
The correct answer is: B - Breach of the guidance notes constitutes breach of FCA rules

Explanation

The Steering Group is a trade organisation and as such the guidelines are best practice, not mandatory. Breach of the guidance notes does not constitute a breach of FCA rules.

Question 19

[1015108] Which of the following are true of money laundering?
I
There are three stages: placement, layering and integration
II
Assisting a money launderer, failure to report and tipping off are all offences
III
The firm must appoint an appropriate person to handle suspected cases
IV
Records must be maintained for five years under the Money Laundering Regulations
A
I, II and III
B
I, II, III and IV
C
I and IV
D
I, II and IV
The correct answer is: B - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Note: Other procedures include, internal controls and training of staff.

Question 20

[1015079] Who should suspicions of money laundering be reported to?
A
Compliance Officer
B
Managing Director
C
Money Laundering Reporting Officer
D
Line Manager
The correct answer is: C - Money Laundering Reporting Officer

Explanation

Suspicions of money laundering should be reported to the Money Laundering Reporting Officer - if appropriate this person can then speak to the National Crime Agency (NCA).

Question 21

[1015096] Which of the following is not true of insider dealing?
A
It only relates to unpublished price sensitive information
B
The legislation applies to unit trusts
C
The FCA can prosecute
D
No offence is committed if information is passed on in the proper course of employment
The correct answer is: B - The legislation applies to unit trusts

Explanation

Unit trusts are excluded. This is because there is no secondary market in unit trusts.

Question 22

[1015081] A UK fund manager is aware of insider information but enters in to a deal regardless. What defence could she use?
A
She had reasonable grounds to believe information was widely known
B
She dealt because others who were not privy to the information had already dealt
C
She dealt only to avoid a loss
D
She only traded for client accounts
The correct answer is: A - She had reasonable grounds to believe information was widely known

Explanation

Given the choice in the question, this is the only valid defence.

Question 23

[1012256] All of the following are covered by the insider dealing legislation except:
A
Futures
B
OTC traded interest rate and currency derivatives
C
Depository receipts
D
Warrants
The correct answer is: B - OTC traded interest rate and currency derivatives

Explanation

The insider dealing legislation relates specifically to abuses of information in respect of securities markets. This therefore includes instruments based on securities, such as stock index futures, share warrants and equity options. It does not relate to OTC markets, such as foreign exchange forward contracts. Additionally, the legislation does not cover assets with no secondary market, such as unit trusts.

Question 24

[1015113] Under which ONE of the following categories of function does the FCA classify a Money Laundering Reporting Officer?
A
A customer function
B
A systems and controls function
C
A significant management function
D
A required control function
The correct answer is: D - A required control function

Explanation

MLROs are required in every financial institution. It is a required control function.

Question 25

[1015089] Market abuse is an offence under:
A
The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000
B
The Companies Act 1985
C
The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002
D
MiFID
The correct answer is: A - The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000

Explanation

The legislation is in FSMA 2000.

Question 26

[1015090] The rules on market abuse apply to:
A
Regulated individuals only
B
Regulated firms only
C
Members of the public
D
Regulated individuals and members of the public
The correct answer is: D - Regulated individuals and members of the public

Explanation

Market abuse is a civil offence and applies to both regulated individuals and also generally to members of the public.

Question 27

[1015094] The Treasury will mostly limit qualifying investments, in respect of market abuse, to those traded on:
A
All futures markets worldwide
B
All exchanges based in the European Economic Area
C
Only the London Stock Market
D
The six RIEs physically based in the UK
The correct answer is: D - The six RIEs physically based in the UK

Explanation

In practice the Treasury will limit qualifying investments to those traded on the six recognised investment exchanges (six RIEs) physically based in the UK. However, developments such as the Internet could lead to UK markets being physically based anywhere.

Question 28

[1015099] In relation to money laundering, which of the following is FALSE?
A
Money laundering offences are defined by the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002
B
Identification procedures are required for new business
C
The offences are not confined to the financial services industry
D
Firms have to report money laundering suspicions to FATF
The correct answer is: D - Firms have to report money laundering suspicions to FATF

Explanation

FATF is an intergovernmental policy making body. In the UK suspicions are reported to NCA.

Question 29

[1014786] If a compliance officer wished to review details of activities which could constitute a money laundering offence, he should review which legislation?
A
FSMA 2000
B
Proceeds of Crime Act 2002
C
Criminal Justice Act 1993
D
SYSC Handbook
The correct answer is: B - Proceeds of Crime Act 2002

Explanation

The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 contains details of the money laundering offences and their criminal penalties. FSMA 2000 contains details of the fines that a firm would face for money laundering offences.

Question 30

[1015118] An IT consultant places an order to sell some shares that she owns. She then becomes aware of some inside information that would lead to the shares rising in value. What would the insider dealing legislation PREVENT her from doing?
A
Calling her stockbroker and cancelling the sale order
B
Passing the information on to someone she is certain will not act on it
C
Informing her work colleagues of the information, if this would be in the normal course of her job
D
She cancels the order after hearing a press release containing the information later that day.
The correct answer is: A - Calling her stockbroker and cancelling the sale order

Explanation

The defences against insider dealing include passing information on in the normal course of business and passing it on to someone you do not expect to act on it. A press release containing the information would mean that it is no longer inside information.

Question 31

[1015085] Which of the following securities would not be covered by the insider dealing legislation?
A
Equity Option
B
Unit Trust
C
Debenture
D
Gilt Futures Contract
The correct answer is: B - Unit Trust

Explanation

Insider dealing legislation (CJA 1993) does not cover unit trusts and life policies.

Question 32

[1012363] Under the Money Laundering Regulations how long are firms required to keep records?
A
One year
B
Two years
C
Three years
D
Five years
The correct answer is: D - Five years

Explanation

Records must be kept for a minimum of five years.

Question 33

[1015115] For which of the following is customer due diligence procedures ALWAYS required under the Money Laundering Regulations?
A
A transaction with a UK credit institution
B
A potential new client who is UK resident
C
A one-off transaction from a financial institution in the FATF
D
A transaction or series of transactions worth Euro 12,000
The correct answer is: B - A potential new client who is UK resident

Explanation

Firms are required to carry out identification procedures on new clients where a business relationship is to be established.

Question 34

[1015075] In respect of money laundering, which of the following is/are required of a company?
I
Identification procedures
II
Training staff
III
Internal controls, policies and procedures
A
I, II and III
B
I and III
C
III only
D
I and II
The correct answer is: A - I, II and III

Explanation

Other requirements are to appoint a Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO) and to report all suspicions.

Question 35

[1000443] Before conducting designated investment business for a new customer, the money laundering regulations require an authorised firm to evidence identity. Which of the following is not true?
A
Unless satisfactory evidence of identity is obtained in a timely manner, the business must not proceed
B
To identify someone an official document bearing a photograph should always be obtained, whether the new business is opened face-to-face or through the post.
C
The register of electors, recent utility bills and bank statements are valid methods of verifying the address of a prospective customer
D
Records of identity must be kept for five years
The correct answer is: B - To identify someone an official document bearing a photograph should always be obtained, whether the new business is opened face-to-face or through the post.

Explanation

Although photographic identification is favourable, it is not always necessary. The JMLSG states: "a government-issued document (without a photograph) which incorporates the customer's full name, supported by a second document ... which incorporates: - the customer's full name and - either his residential address - or his date of birth."

Question 36

[1012273] An IT consultant places an order to sell some shares that she owns. She then becomes aware of some inside information that would lead to the shares rising in value. What would the insider dealing legislation PREVENT her from doing?
A
Calling her stockbroker and cancelling the sale order
B
Passing the information on to someone she is certain will not act on it
C
Informing her work colleagues of the information, if this would be in the normal course of her job
D
She cancels the order after hearing a press release containing the information later that day.
The correct answer is: A - Calling her stockbroker and cancelling the sale order

Explanation

The defences against insider dealing include passing information on in the normal course of business and passing it on to someone you do not expect to act on it. A press release containing the information would mean that it is no longer inside information.

Question 37

[1015107] Which of the following are TRUE regarding money laundering?
I
'Criminal conduct' referred to in the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 covers any offence regardless of size
II
The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 only applies to all authorised firms and individuals
III
Someone who knowingly assists another in laundering terrorist funds can use in his/her defence that she passed her knowledge onto the police
IV
A firm that fails to implement an educational programme for its staff will not be committing an offence so long as no money laundering transactions are handled
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
I, II and IV
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

'Criminal conduct' includes any conduct that would constitute a criminal offence if committed in the UK.

Question 38

[1015102] At which stages of the money laundering process are FCA fund management companies generally most vulnerable?
A
Placement and layering
B
Layering and integration
C
Placement and integration
D
Placement only
The correct answer is: B - Layering and integration

Explanation

Fund management companies are most vulnerable during the Layering and Integration stages of money laundering.

Question 39

[1015078] Which of the following is an acceptable defence against the charge of insider dealing?
A
It was believed that the information was already widely known
B
The information was passed on with no encouragement to deal
C
A market maker acting outside the ordinary course of business
D
The information was price sensitive, but not known to the market
The correct answer is: A - It was believed that the information was already widely known

Explanation

It is a valid defence to maintain that the information was already publicly available.

Question 40

[1015105] Which of the following is not an offence under the insider dealing legislation?
A
Passing on price sensitive information
B
Director dealing in shares two months before announcement of results
C
Dealing on price sensitive information
D
Encouraging someone to deal on price sensitive information
The correct answer is: B - Director dealing in shares two months before announcement of results

Explanation

Directors are permitted to deal in their company's shares subject to: 1. Proper disclosure. 2. Not acting on inside information.

Question 41

[1015097] Which two of the following would constitute insider dealing?
I
Dealing on unpublished price sensitive information
II
A director dealing in company shares immediately after the annual report is published
III
Encouraging another person to deal on unpublished price sensitive information
IV
Buying shares on rumours of a takeover
A
III and IV
B
II and III
C
II and IV
D
I and III
The correct answer is: D - I and III

Explanation

Dealing on, or encouraging another person to deal on, unpublished price sensitive information can constitute insider dealing. Note: If the annual results have been published, the information would not be classed as 'unpublished' any more. Also, 'rumours' are unlikely to constitute specific or precise inside information.

Question 42

[1005020] Sue becomes suspicious of a 'high number of sales' by her client to an unknown party. Sue should report her fears to:
A
The client
B
The FCA
C
The NCA
D
The MLRO
The correct answer is: D - The MLRO

Explanation

The MLRO is the Money Laundering Reporting Officer. Every authorised firm must have one. They act as a conduit for information relating to money laundering from inside the firm to the relevant authorities.

Question 43

[1012399] Which of the following is the FCA most likely to take into consideration, when deciding the amount of a fine for market abuse?
A
The age of the Individuals involved
B
The time that the behaviour took place
C
If the behaviour was deliberate or reckless
D
If the behaviour created a profit or a loss
The correct answer is: C - If the behaviour was deliberate or reckless

Explanation

The FCA can impose fines and in determining how much these should be for, it must consider if the behaviour was deliberate or reckless amongst other factors.

Question 44

[1015101] Which two of the following are false of the Money Laundering Regulations?
I
Failure to report a suspicion is a criminal offence
II
Firms must appoint a Money Laundering Reporting Officer
III
Not reporting when "reasonable grounds" to suspect money laundering exist is not an offence
IV
The regulations only apply to drugs laundering operations
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
III and IV
D
II and IV
The correct answer is: C - III and IV

Explanation

The requirement (under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002) to report when "reasonable grounds" exist places an objective test of suspicion on the financial services industry.

Question 45

[1047692] Which ONE of the following is TRUE in respect of suspicious transactions?
A
Employees should report the transactions to their compliance officers
B
Not reporting a suspicious transaction is a criminal offence
C
Employees should report the transactions to the National Crime Agency
D
Employees can continue with the relationship once the transaction has been reported
The correct answer is: B - Not reporting a suspicious transaction is a criminal offence

Explanation

Not reporting a suspicious transaction is a criminal offence. Employees should report suspicious transactions to their Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO). This may not be the same as their compliance officer. The MLRO then reports to NCA. The relationship may continue, but it will depend on what NCA says.

Question 46

[1015093] For a person to engage in market abuse, which one of the following is true:
A
Intention must be proved
B
Intention and effect are both equally relevant
C
Effect is most important
D
Effect is not a consideration
The correct answer is: C - Effect is most important

Explanation

The statutory definition of market abuse does not require the person engaging in the behaviour to have intended to abuse the market. It is not essential for such behaviour to be present for behaviour to fall below standard. The focus of the market abuse regime is on the effects of behaviour and not intentions.

Question 47

[1015088] Which of the following statements about the offence of insider dealing is TRUE?
A
Persons prosecuted for insider dealing may only be imprisoned for up to two years
B
A decision not to deal on the basis of inside information is not an offence
C
An offence can only be committed where there is a transaction in investments (as defined)
D
The offence is contained within the Companies Securities (Insider Dealing) Act 1985
The correct answer is: B - A decision not to deal on the basis of inside information is not an offence

Explanation

Option 'an offence can only be committed where there is a transaction in investments (as defined)' is incorrect because a transaction is not necessary for a prosecution to occur, i.e. a person may be prosecuted for disclosure of inside information. 'A decision not to deal on the basis of inside information is not an offence' is the correct answer.

Question 48

[1015091] Which of the following descriptions is closest to the definition of a reasonable regular user of a particular market?
A
An individual who regularly invests in a pension plan
B
A floor trader on a similar off-shore market
C
A reasonable person who regularly deals on that market
D
A private investor who trades twice a year on that market
The correct answer is: C - A reasonable person who regularly deals on that market

Explanation

In summary, a reasonable regular user is a person who regularly deals on that market in investments of the kind in question (Section 118 of the FSMA 2000). It is an investor who uses a market often enough to understand the tacit aspects of the market and understands the day to day operations.

Question 49

[1015084] Mr. Bowman owns shares in a UK company. As part of his job as a computer consultant he obtains price sensitive information about the company. He should:
A
Sell his shares
B
Attempt to prevent anyone else finding this link
C
Only disclose the information as a necessary part of his job
D
Place his shares in trust
The correct answer is: C - Only disclose the information as a necessary part of his job

Explanation

Mr. Bowman could be prosecuted if he were to deal, encourage someone else to deal, or disclose the information. One of the defences against an insider dealing prosecution is that the disclosure was made without the intention of the recipient dealing.

Question 50

[1015110] Which of the following is not taken into consideration when the FCA applies the regular user test during a prosecution of Market Abuse?
A
That standards of behaviour on one market can not be expected to be the same as standards on another
B
That a user of the market may not expect the same standards as a member of the general public
C
Higher standards would be expected from a private investor than from a market professional
D
Intention is not required to be demonstrated in determining the standards of behaviour
The correct answer is: C - Higher standards would be expected from a private investor than from a market professional

Explanation

A regular user is a reasonable person who regularly deals on that market in investments of the kind in question. The criteria for market abuse are established by reference to the expectations of regular users. Regular users are not dealers, investment banks or market makers but are individual investors who understand the nature and day to day running of the market.

Question 51

[1015077] Which of the following is an offence under the insider dealing legislation?
A
A predator company buying shares in a target company
B
Acting on inside information where the source is NOT known
C
Using inside information where the intention is not to make a profit or avoid a loss
D
An institutional shareholder NOT announcing their intentions before buying securities
The correct answer is: B - Acting on inside information where the source is NOT known

Explanation

The important thing is that the perpetrator KNOWS that the information is inside information. Whether they know the source or not does not matter.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1015146] Where a company breaches the takeover code, what action can the Panel take?
A
Fine the directors
B
Suspend the company from listing
C
Imprison the directors
D
Issue a public censure
The correct answer is: D - Issue a public censure

Explanation

The Panel is now a statutory body but still has very limited powers.

Question 2

[1015133] Information relating to registered companies is available for inspection by:
A
The Inland Revenue only
B
Shareholders only
C
Inland Revenue and the London stock exchange
D
Any member of the public
The correct answer is: D - Any member of the public

Explanation

Company information at Companies House is available to anyone for inspection - companies are supposed to live public lives.

Question 3

[1012429] Under the takeover code, a mandatory bid must be made on the purchase of:
A
20%
B
30%
C
50%
D
75%
The correct answer is: B - 30%

Explanation

Under the takeover code, a mandatory bid must be made on the purchase of 30% of a company's shares.

Question 4

[1018131] Which of the following best describes the takeover code?
A
It complies with the Takeover Directive
B
It supersedes the Takeover Directive
C
It applies to all EEA member states
D
It constitutes legislation in the UK
The correct answer is: A - It complies with the Takeover Directive

Explanation

The takeover code complies with the Takeover Directive and applies to the UK, Isle of Man, and Channel Islands.

Question 5

[1015126] The percentage required to pass a special resolution at a company meeting is:
A
Greater than 50%
B
75% or more
C
Greater than 90%
D
95% or more
The correct answer is: B - 75% or more

Explanation

A special resolution is required to be passed by the shareholders in order, for instance, to change the company's name. Note: an ORDINARY resolution requires a simple majority of the share capital to be passed (over 50%).

Question 6

[1012481] When the director of a company undertakes a transaction in their own company's shares she must disclose this to the company's Regulatory Information Service for which one of the following?
A
For purchases and sales of any size
B
For sales only of any size
C
For purchases only were the size of transaction amounts to 3% or more of the company's issued share capital
D
For both sales and purchases were the size of transaction amounts to 3% or more of the company's issued share capital
The correct answer is: A - For purchases and sales of any size

Explanation

The UK Listing Rules state that any deals done by the director of a company in their company's shares must be reported to the company's Regulatory Information Service by close of business the following business day.

Question 7

[1015134] When a listed company receives notification of a 3% interest to whom must it disclose this information?
A
Treasury
B
FCA
C
A Regulatory Information Service
D
JMLSG
The correct answer is: C - A Regulatory Information Service

Explanation

Once the company has received disclosure of a 'notifiable interest' (3% or more) it must inform its Regulatory Information Service (which in turn disseminates the information to the market).

Question 8

[1015171] When a UK listed company releases profit figures and/or dividends which of the following methods do the FCA's listing rules require the company to use?
A
By holding a press conference on the day of the announcement before the market opens
B
By informing a primary information provider (PIP) without delay
C
By sending a circular to all shareholders on the register
D
By announcement at the next general meeting
The correct answer is: B - By informing a primary information provider (PIP) without delay

Explanation

All announcements made by listed companies must be made to a Primary Information Provider (PIP) - also known as Regulatory Information Services (RISs). PIPs/RISs are approved by the FCA and include the London Stock Exchange's Regulatory News Service (RNS), Business Wire and Newswire.

Question 9

[1065534] Under which of the following pieces of legislation would companies that trade on the AIM market be required to provide half yearly reports?
A
AIM rules for companies
B
Companies Act
C
Listing Rules
D
IFRS
The correct answer is: A - AIM rules for companies

Explanation

An AIM company must prepare a half-yearly report in respect of the six month period from the end of the financial period for which financial information has been disclosed in its admission document and at least every subsequent six months thereafter (apart from the final period of six months preceding its accounting reference date for its annual audited accounts). All such reports must be notified without delay and in any event not later than three months after the end of the relevant period.

Question 10

[1024441] An investor has a portfolio of FTSE100 index shares and now wishes to become more ethical by excluding tobacco products from their portfolio. What are the implications?
A
The investor will have to sell all his shares and take out a deposit
B
There are no implications. The investor can continue to invest in the FTSE100
C
The investor will need to switch into AIM shares
D
The investor will need to narrow the range of FTSE100 shares he invests in
The correct answer is: D - The investor will need to narrow the range of FTSE100 shares he invests in

Explanation

The FTSE100 will need to be negatively screened for tobacco companies, and these companies taken away from the portfolio. This may reduce the diversity of the portfolio, but would make it more ethically sound.

Question 11

[1012417] What is the percentage ownership of a company that a predator must attain in a target company before it can force the minority target company shareholders to sell their shares to them?
A
51%
B
75%
C
76%
D
90%
The correct answer is: D - 90%

Explanation

The takeover code in this instance is trying to prevent a successful predator being held to ransom by a minority.

Question 12

[1015136] Four investors act together in order to build up a holding of 4% in XYZ plc. Which of the following is true?
A
Each investor is deemed to hold 1% and must disclose their position to the company
B
Each investor is deemed to hold 1% and need not disclose their position to the company
C
Each investor is deemed to hold 4% and must disclose their position to the company
D
Each investor is deemed to hold 4% and need not disclose their position to the company
The correct answer is: C - Each investor is deemed to hold 4% and must disclose their position to the company

Explanation

The Companies Act requirement requires a holding of 3% or more to be disclosed to the company within two business days. This includes investors acting together in 'concert'.

Question 13

[1065557] Which of the following is not true in relation to the Corporate Governance Code?
A
It applies all companies with a premium listing of equity shares in the UK, regardless of whether they are incorporated in the UK or overseas
B
Compliance is voluntary for companies with a standard listing
C
It encourages strong leadership by allowing directors to set their own salary to a level that motivates them to run the company successfully and ensures retention
D
Nomination committees should be made up of a majority of independent NEDs
The correct answer is: C - It encourages strong leadership by allowing directors to set their own salary to a level that motivates them to run the company successfully and ensures retention

Explanation

Levels of remuneration should be sufficient to attract, retain and motivate directors of the quality required to run the company successfully, but a company should avoid paying more than is necessary for this purpose. No director should be involved in deciding his or her own remuneration.

Question 14

[1015135] Two different shareholders have appointed the same proxy. One shareholder wishes to vote for a resolution, the other wishes to vote against it, what should the proxy do?
A
Refuse to vote
B
Vote in favour of the resolution
C
Vote against the resolution
D
Vote for and against the resolution
The correct answer is: D - Vote for and against the resolution

Explanation

The proxy must vote on behalf of BOTH of the shareholders. Note: 48 hours notice must be given in order for the proxy to be valid.

Question 15

[1047428] Which of the following is exempt the requirement to disclose notifiable interests?
A
Fund managers
B
Investment banks
C
Custodians
D
Individuals
The correct answer is: C - Custodians

Explanation

Market makers and custodians are exempt from disclosing their interests under the notifiable interests legislation.

Question 16

[1065561] What is the role of the FCA with regards to the trading of Official List securities.
A
To suspend trading or listing
B
Advise companies on listing
C
Promote the official list
D
To provide liquidity
The correct answer is: A - To suspend trading or listing

Explanation

The FCA determines which companies are eligible to join the Official List, and writes and enforces the FCA Rules which apply to these companies through their UKLA role.

Question 17

[1015137] A shareholder who acquires an interest of 3% in the share capital of a public company is obliged to notify the company in writing within:
A
1 business day
B
2 business days
C
5 business days
D
10 business days
The correct answer is: B - 2 business days

Explanation

The Companies Act refers to this as a NOTIFIABLE interest. Disclosure must be made to the company in writing.

Question 18

[1015169] A company seeking to apply for a listing on the Official List of the LSE applies to:
A
LSE
B
FCA
C
Treasury
D
SEC
The correct answer is: B - FCA

Explanation

The FCA is the UK's Listing Authority.

Question 19

[1012434] Which of the following dealings in a company's shares does NOT need to be reported to the company?
A
A purchase by a director amounting to 1% of the total value of issued shares
B
A sale of shares in a company amounting to 0.5% of the value of the company's issued shares by the spouse of a director of that company
C
A purchase by an investor of shares amounting together with any existing interest amounting to 2% of the value of the issued shares of a company
D
A purchase by an investor of shares amounting to 4% of the value of the issued shares of a company
The correct answer is: C - A purchase by an investor of shares amounting together with any existing interest amounting to 2% of the value of the issued shares of a company

Explanation

Any dealings in a company's shares by the director or anyone connected with the director (the spouse in answer B) must be reported to the company. Dealings by ANYONE in the company's shares that takes their holding to 3% or more must also be reported to the company.

Question 20

[1015121] What percentage of a company's shares does the Companies Act 2006 define as a notifiable interest?
A
2%
B
3%
C
5%
D
10%
The correct answer is: B - 3%

Explanation

On obtaining 3% of the voting capital of a company, a shareholder must disclose the interest in writing within two business days.

Question 21

[1065560] Which of the following best outlines the main role of a NOMAD after the company has been admitted for trading?
A
Only sponsors have continuing obligations
B
To support trading in the company's shares
C
Provide advice on exchange rules
D
To assist in pricing and marketing in a flotation
The correct answer is: C - Provide advice on exchange rules

Explanation

The nomad must be available at all times to advise and guide the directors of its AIM clients about their obligations and to ensure compliance with the AIM rules. Supporting trading in the company's shares and assisting in pricing and marketing in a flotation are the roles of the brokers.

Question 22

[1015124] How many votes are required to pass an ordinary resolution?
A
Over 25%
B
Over 30%
C
Over 50%
D
Over 75%
The correct answer is: C - Over 50%

Explanation

Ordinary resolution: over 50%. Special resolution: 75% or more.

Question 23

[1015164] Minimum criteria for listing are set by the UKLA in respect of:
I
Market capitalisation
II
Number of years incorporated
III
Published accounts existing at least three years
IV
Total assets of the company
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, II and IV
C
I and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - I and III

Explanation

Companies applying for a listing must have a minimum market capitalisation of £700k and must have a trading history of three years, with corresponding audited financial statements. There are no requirements regarding the number of years incorporated and assets.

Question 24

[1015142] The Combined Code for Corporate Governance recommends that boards of directors should evaluate their own performance every:
A
Month
B
Two years
C
Year
D
Six months
The correct answer is: C - Year

Explanation

The combined code contains a number of principles of good governance relating to directors and institutional investors.

Question 25

[1015122] A proxy is valid:
A
On the day of the General Meeting
B
On the day of the General Meeting and at any adjournment
C
On the day of the General Meeting and at any adjournment if expressly stated by the chairman
D
At any General Meeting
The correct answer is: B - On the day of the General Meeting and at any adjournment

Explanation

Once a shareholder has appointed a proxy to vote on their behalf, it is valid until the proxy exercises their voting rights.

Question 26

[1065533] Which of the following is required for an official LSE listing?
A
A market cap of £700,000
B
A 33% free float
C
3 years working capital
D
5 years accounts
The correct answer is: A - A market cap of £700,000

Explanation

The issuer must have published consolidated, independently audited accounts covering at least three years. The expected market value of all securities issued by the company, and to be listed, must be at least £700,000 for shares and £200,000 for debt securities. (There are exceptions where the amount of debt securities is not fixed, and also if the securities of the same class are already listed). At least 25% of the shares must be available for public trading, i.e., not be held by directors or significant shareholders (5%+). This is known as free float.

Question 27

[1015150] At what level is a mandatory bid required according to the Takeover Code?
A
3% of the voting capital of a company
B
5% of the voting capital of a company
C
15% of the voting capital of a company
D
30% of the voting capital of a company
The correct answer is: D - 30% of the voting capital of a company

Explanation

If anyone acquires 30% of the voting capital of a company they are obliged to make a compulsory, or mandatory bid for the remaining shares in the company. This bid must be at a price no lower than the highest price paid over the preceding 12 months.

Question 28

[1015119] How often must a company hold a general meeting for the shareholders?
A
Annually
B
Bi-annually
C
6 monthly
D
Quarterly
The correct answer is: A - Annually

Explanation

A company must hold an AGM each calendar year. NB: A General Meeting (formally known as an EGM) may be called at any time on request of 5% of the voting capital.

Question 29

[1015145] In the event of an unfair takeover, which of the following courses of action is/are open to the Takeover Panel?
I
Rescind the takeover
II
Fine the predator company
III
Issue a public censure
A
I, II and III
B
II and III
C
III only
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - III only

Explanation

The Panel on Takeovers and Mergers is now a statutory body but still has limited powers.

Question 30

[1015149] What level of control of a market in goods or services would suggest a substantial lessening of competition?
A
25%
B
30%
C
33.33%
D
50%
The correct answer is: A - 25%

Explanation

25% is generally regarded as potentially against the public interest.

Question 31

[1015117] When the directors of a listed company have price sensitive information to disclose to the market, which of the following must the company inform?
A
The Department of Trade and Industry
B
A Primary Information Provider
C
The press
D
The Bank of England
The correct answer is: B - A Primary Information Provider

Explanation

Company announcements are made through Primary Information Providers (PIPs) like the LSE's RNS.

Question 32

[1047497] The Transparency Directive defines a notifiable interest as:
A
3%
B
5%
C
10%
D
30%
The correct answer is: B - 5%

Explanation

The EU Transparency Directive sets 5% as the level of notifiable interest. In the UK it is 3%.

Question 33

[1015147] Who has the power to stop a merger on the grounds of public interest?
A
The Panel on Takeovers and Mergers
B
Department of Business Innovation and Skills
C
Competition and Markets Authority
D
Office of Fair Trading
The correct answer is: C - Competition and Markets Authority

Explanation

The Competition and Markets Authority decides whether a merger or takeover may go ahead. The Department of Business Innovation and Skills may only intervene in cases of national security

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1044482] The Trustee Act 2000 places which of the following obligations or powers on trustees?
A
The trustees must be remunerated
B
The trustees must not delegate any roles to third parties
C
The trustees must apply a duty of care when insuring trust properties
D
The trustees must diversify the investments they hold
The correct answer is: C - The trustees must apply a duty of care when insuring trust properties

Explanation

Trustees can be remunerated when working in a professional capacity. Trustees can appoint third parties to perform roles such as investment manager. Trustees need to be aware of the need for diversification, but can invest in anything as long as it meets the objectives of the fund. The best answer is that trustees must apply a duty of care when insuring trust properties. This duty of care also applies to other areas, such as exercising their powers of investment, employing agents, and using nominees.

Question 2

[1049930] Geoffrey is 66 years old, recently retired with no dependents other than his wife. Paul is 37, currently in full-time employment, with a wife and three young children. Which of the following would best summarise the investment objectives of these two clients?
A
Geoffrey would be more interested in growth than Paul
B
Paul would not be as interested in life assurance as Geoffrey
C
Geoffrey would be more interested in retirement planning than Paul
D
Paul would not be as interested in generating income as Geoffrey
The correct answer is: D - Paul would not be as interested in generating income as Geoffrey

Explanation

Geoffrey, being retired, would be far more interested in generating income from his investments to tide him through his retirement. Paul, in full-time employment, would be less interested in his income generating income and more interested in growth. Paul would also be interested in retirement planning - hopefully, Geoffrey has this covered.
