Paul is much more likely to be interested in life assurance in order to protect his dependents should something unfortunate happen to him.

Question 3

[1017663] Deeds of variation must be made within how many years of the death of the legator?
A
1 year
B
2 years
C
3 years
D
5 years
The correct answer is: B - 2 years

Explanation

For a deed of variation to be valid, it must: - Relate to a valid will, to an intestate estate or to a trust - Be signed by all the parties who would have benefited had the variation not been made (all of whom must be over 18 and must be of sound mind) - Be executed within two years of the death of the 'legator' (the person who left the money) - Not be made for any consideration (i.e. no one should have received money or value as encouragement for them to sign) The deed must also contain a statement to the effect that it is intended that the inheritance tax effect of the variation will be the same as if the deceased had made that variation himself.

Question 4

[1017301] What is the most important reason for presenting recommendations face to face at a client meeting?
A
Signing the forms
B
Verifying status
C
Answering client questions
D
Giving the client the report
The correct answer is: C - Answering client questions

Explanation

Answering questions is most important.

Question 5

[1049918] Which of the following is a key feature of an interest in possession trust?
A
The beneficiary cannot draw from the trust until they are 18 years old
B
The trustee has the power to appoint beneficiaries at their discretion
C
The beneficiary of the income differs from the beneficiary of the assets
D
The trustee has the power to distribute the assets at their discretion
The correct answer is: C - The beneficiary of the income differs from the beneficiary of the assets

Explanation

An interest in possession trust allows a settlor to set aside assets for the benefit of stated individuals. However, there will also be a lifetime interest given to another beneficiary. The lifetime interest benefits from the income from the trust during a stated period. After that period, the assets become the property of the remainderman - often called the reversionary interest.

Question 6

[1013490] An investment strategy that is passive usually means:
A
The trustees do not usually evaluate the performance of the fund manager
B
The trustees take NO part in the management of the fund at any stage
C
The fund manager is trying to identify and acquire undervalued stocks
D
The fund manager is seeking to track a benchmark index having determined the preferred level of risk of the client
The correct answer is: D - The fund manager is seeking to track a benchmark index having determined the preferred level of risk of the client

Explanation

Passively managed funds are usually tracker or index funds. The fund manager is not trying to choose cheap stocks, but instead looking to mimic the performance of a particular index that reflects the required risk level of the customer.

Question 7

[1015304] The investment powers of trustees as defined by the Trustee Act 2000 apply to which of the following?
I
Authorised Unit Trust
II
Occupational Pension Funds
III
Life Insurance Companies
A
I,II and III
B
I and II
C
None of above
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - None of above

Explanation

The provisions of the Trustee Act do not apply to occupational pension schemes, authorised unit trusts and companies.

Question 8

[1051444] If a retail client wishes to ensure that they do not lose any money in a deposit, which of the following is the most suitable deposit or investment?
A
Up to £100,000 in a UK bank account
B
Any amount in a UK account
C
Up to £35,000 in a UK account
D
Up to £85,000 in a UK bank account
The correct answer is: D - Up to £85,000 in a UK bank account

Explanation

£85,000 is the amount is guaranteed by the FSCS in respect of deposits. This reflects a recent change in the regulations that may not be reflected in your exam.

Question 9

[1015228] A small trust fund governed by the investment powers of the Trustees Act 2000 would normally be able to invest in which of the following investments?
I
Ordinary shares
II
Corporate bonds
III
Land in the United Kingdom
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

The Trustees Act 2000 gives trustees, not governed by a trust deed, two types of investment powers: General Investment Powers, which state that the trustee may invest in any ordinary security (such as equities and bonds) and Specific Investment Powers allowing them to invest in freehold or leasehold land in the UK.

Question 10

[1010932] If an individual dies intestate, who will the court appoint to distribute the estate?
A
Administrators
B
Lex incognitam
C
Executors
D
Juris major
The correct answer is: A - Administrators

Explanation

In England and Wales, the individuals appointed are known as administrators. (Lex incognitam and Juris Major do not exist, they are merely distracters).

Question 11

[1011224] A trust may be created for all of the following legitimate reasons, EXCEPT:
A
Holding assets for someone incapable
B
For the succession of property
C
For future flexibility
D
For tax evasion
The correct answer is: D - For tax evasion

Explanation

Tax evasion is illegal, unlike tax avoidance. It would not be a legitimate reason to create a trust.

Question 12

[1013504] Which of the following is/are true of systematic risk?
I
It can be controlled by diversification
II
It is the total risk for a fully diversified portfolio
III
It is the risk particular to a particular investment
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
II only
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - II only

Explanation

A fully diversified portfolio is assumed to have diversified unsystematic risk away. Therefore, the only risk left is systematic risk (measured by Beta).

Question 13

[1031503] Joe Frazier is considering an investment overseas in Ruritanian stocks as a way of diversifying his holdings. His friend Michael Tyson, an investment advisor, tells him that "Such an investment will decrease the efficiency of your portfolio, as appreciation of the foreign currency will cause losses. We call this 'currency risk'. Not only that, but you will be exposed to risk of civil unrest or government actions, what we in the trade call 'country risk' ". Michael's descriptions of currency risk and country risk are?
A
Correct and incorrect respectively
B
Both correct
C
Incorrect and correct respectively
D
Both incorrect
The correct answer is: C - Incorrect and correct respectively

Explanation

The currency risk description is incorrect, as appreciation of the foreign currency will cause gains to Joe Frazier's portfolio. The second description of country risk is correct.

Question 14

[1051080] An investor has the following spread of assets in his portfolio: Which of the following would best benefit the investor?
A
Increase in interest rates
B
Decrease in interest rates
C
Increase in inflation
D
Decrease in inflation
The correct answer is: B - Decrease in interest rates

Explanation

A decrease in interest rates would improve the ability to borrow. This would increase the demand for property, sending prices higher, and improve conditions in which companies could expand, increasing share prices. A drop in interest rates would also increase the prices of bonds.

Question 15

[1015269] The Trustee Act of 2000 deals with which of the following?
A
The required balance of investment in all trusts
B
The best execution responsibilities of trustees
C
The need to disclose investment policy
D
The balance of investment required if it is not specified in the trust deed
The correct answer is: D - The balance of investment required if it is not specified in the trust deed

Explanation

The Trustee Act is only relevant where the trust deeds make no specific reference on investment policy.

Question 16

[1001468] Which of the following explains the relationship for risk and return for any 'rational' investor?
A
A positive relationship
B
Inverse relationship
C
No relationship
D
Indirect relationship
The correct answer is: A - A positive relationship

Explanation

As risk increases, a rational investor would want more return to compensate. This is a positive relationship.

Question 17

[1044484] Under the Trustee Act 2000, what is the minimum level of investment that must be allocated to gilts and other fixed income securities?
A
At least 40% of the value of properties held
B
At least 25% of the value of properties held
C
At least 10% of the value of properties held
D
The Trustee Act 2000 does not specify a minimum level
The correct answer is: D - The Trustee Act 2000 does not specify a minimum level

Explanation

The Trustee Act 2000 does not specify a minimum level of investment in any asset. It insists, instead, that trustees apply a duty of care in exercising their investment powers.

Question 18

[1015014] When considering the suitability of advising a client to opt out of state secondary pension (S2P), which of the following should be considered?
I
Tax position
II
Existing pension provision
III
Career prospects
IV
Age and sex
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I and II
C
II and IV
D
II and III
The correct answer is: A - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

The advisor should consider all relevant factors.

Question 19

[1005202] Who creates a trust?
A
A trustee
B
A settlor
C
A beneficiary
D
A trustor
The correct answer is: B - A settlor

Explanation

A settlor creates a trust.

Question 20

[1015018] Which of the following is/are true with respect to adverts for investments which fluctuate in value?
I
The value can go down as well as up
II
You may not get back all the money originally invested
III
An example illustrating the effect of a fall in value
A
I only
B
I and II
C
I and III
D
I, II, and III
The correct answer is: B - I and II

Explanation

A numerical example is not required under the rules.

Question 21

[1032584] Which of the following statements best defines the role of a Fact Find?
A
It must be completed by the client prior to meeting the advisor
B
It must be in writing and signed by both the advisor and the client
C
It must be attached to any recommendations
D
The nature and content of the Fact Find are not governed by regulations
The correct answer is: D - The nature and content of the Fact Find are not governed by regulations

Explanation

Although a useful tool, the fact find is not a regulatory requirement.

Question 22

[1049922] Mary has recently inherited a lot of money. Her friend has recommended that she invest the money in equity as this gives the best return, although Mary does not fully understand how. As Mary's financial adviser, you know that your fact-find revealed her as a cautious investor. Mary instructs you to advise her on the most suitable equity investments. Which of the following is the best course of action?
A
Give advice on equity after explaining the risks
B
Give advice on FSTE 100 shares only, as these are low-risk
C
Refuse to trade in equity, as it does not fit in with her profile
D
Perform another fact-find to see if Mary's attitude to investments have changed as a result of the inheritance
The correct answer is: D - Perform another fact-find to see if Mary's attitude to investments have changed as a result of the inheritance

Explanation

Before giving advice the adviser needs to assess suitability. This includes ensuring that the advice meets her objectives and that she understands the risks. As far as the adviser is concerned, her profile does not fit with equity. Mary's financial situation has obviously changed. Although a financial adviser cannot assume that this will change her investment preferences, it would be worth performing another fact-find to see if it has.

Question 23

[1032582] Before giving pension advice to a new client who wishes to retire at 60 and maintain her lifestyle for both herself and her spouse, which of the following would be the MOST important starting point?
A
A copy of the latest tax return
B
Details of last will and testament
C
Reviewing of their exiting life policies
D
An analysis of the household income and expenditure
The correct answer is: D - An analysis of the household income and expenditure

Explanation

Finding out the details of the client's income and expenditure will give the advisor an idea of what lifestyle needs maintaining and what funds are available to invest.

Question 24

[1032585] Which of the following is LEAST likely to affect a client's attitude to risk?
A
Whether their investment objective is income or capital
B
The timescale of the investment
C
The existing investments owned by the client
D
The level of the client's current tax bracket
The correct answer is: D - The level of the client's current tax bracket

Explanation

Objectives, timescale and the existing assets owned by the investor are major factors affecting an investor's attitude to risk. Tax implications are less about risk and more about whether income or capital should be a major concern.

Question 25

[1005203] In which type of trust is the role of the trustee to act as nominee only for the beneficiaries?
A
Discretionary trust
B
Life interest trust
C
Interest in possession trust
D
Bare trust
The correct answer is: D - Bare trust

Explanation

A bare trustee is a nominee rather than truly a trustee.

Question 26

[1012522] You are advising a retail client whom you have assessed as a cautious investor. He has previously stated that he is seeking sufficient income to cover a regular expenditure. Capital growth is not one of his investment objective. Now he wants to place an order to purchase low coupon gilts, which are unlikely to meet the level of expenditure you previously discussed. Best practice would be to:
A
Warn the client that this would be an unsuitable investment strategy for him, based on his previously stated objectives
B
Refuse to accept the order, as your mandate is to provide sufficient income
C
Ask the client to sign a risk warning stating that they waive the right to suitable advice
D
Transact the business immediately as you have received a specific client instruction
The correct answer is: A - Warn the client that this would be an unsuitable investment strategy for him, based on his previously stated objectives

Explanation

It is best practice to warn the client if the investment does not meet their objects. As this is an execution only trade, however, the investor may still decide to place the order.

Question 27

[1015261] Prior to setting up a portfolio a manager should establish:
I
Client's tax position
II
Client's age
III
Client's income
IV
Suitable stocks which may outperform the index
A
I, II, III and IV
B
IV
C
I and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

The suitability rule states that a firm must take reasonable steps to find out about a client's personal and financial circumstances which are relevant to the services being offered. These facts should be written down and reviewed ANNUALLY. Option IV will probably take place AFTER the portfolio has been set up.

Question 28

[1051093] The trustees of a charity ask you for investment advice on their portfolio. Which of the following is the most suitable objective for the fund?
A
A portfolio generating a reasonable amount of income with some long-term capital growth
B
A portfolio generating a considerable amount of income with capital protection
C
A portfolio generating no income but a considerable amount of capital gain
D
A portfolio generating an annuity for a set period of time
The correct answer is: A - A portfolio generating a reasonable amount of income with some long-term capital growth

Explanation

Trustees must seek to strike the right balance for their particular charity between providing an income to help the charity carry out its purposes effectively in the short-term; and maintaining and, if possible, enhancing the value of the invested funds, so as to enable the charity effectively to carry out its purposes in the longer-term. For this reason, income and capital growth is ideal.

Question 29

[1032583] A client asks for advice and provides the following objectives to his financial advisor: to retire at 55 years of age, to provide protection to his family in the event of death and to repay his mortgage as quickly as possible. If the advisor believes meeting all of these objectives is not currently possible, which of the following is true?
A
Regulations state that the advisor needs to persuade the client to be more realistic
B
The FCA state that life insurance objectives must be met before pension requirements
C
In exercising the client's best interests rules, the advisor should recommend that the pension takes priority over other investment
D
Regulations do not dictate which objectives should take priority, it is down to investor choice
The correct answer is: D - Regulations do not dictate which objectives should take priority, it is down to investor choice

Explanation

If an investor cannot meet all of their objectives, which of them will take priority is a decision for the client to make.

Question 30

[1051094] The trustees of a charity approach you for advice on the following investment strategies. Which would be suitable?
A
Buying a property with the intention of leasing that property out
B
Buying a development property to sell on once the work is completed
C
Buying and selling official list shares based on technical analysis
D
Investing in fine wines to sell on at a profit
The correct answer is: A - Buying a property with the intention of leasing that property out

Explanation

Charity portfolios should not be treated as trading accounts. The suitable strategy is to buy and hold. Buying property with the intention to lease it out fulfils this. It also fulfils the requirement for income and long-term capital gain. Although official list shares in themselves are appropriate, using these simply for trading could be deemed inappropriate.

Question 31

[1051081] You have collected the following information from a client: Based on the information given only, how would assess this portfolio?
A
The investor is exposed to too much risk
B
The investor has the balance about right
C
The investor should place more weight in CFDs
D
The investor should place more weight in AIM shares
The correct answer is: A - The investor is exposed to too much risk

Explanation

Despite the ageing population in the UK - the client is likely to have a good many years ahead of them - They are approaching the official retirement age. For this reason, they should be seeking a greater proportion of income-related investments in order to meet the ongoing costs of young children.

Question 32

[1032586] Asset allocation:
A
Is influenced by a client's objectives and attitude to risk
B
Must remain fixed for the duration of the portfolio
C
Is less important than fund or investment selection
D
Must be revised annually
The correct answer is: A - Is influenced by a client's objectives and attitude to risk

Explanation

There is no requirement to review the asset allocation annually or to maintain a fixed portfolio. Whether it is more or less important that selection would be down to the investor.

Question 33

[1032587] In selecting a collective investment scheme to recommend to a client, which of the following is LEAST important to that process?
A
Customer service
B
Past performance
C
Size of the fund
D
Management charges
The correct answer is: C - Size of the fund

Explanation

All of the other elements would contribute to the investor's experience with and returns from the fund. The size of the fund is least relevant to this.

Question 34

[1017684] Dana and Brad Tanner are very risk averse. They have recently inherited £100,000 and have approached you for financial advice. They currently have a mortgage of £150,000 on which they are paying a variable interest rate of 6.25% pa. You estimate that their £100k is likely to generate 5.75% on deposit at current rates. What would be the most suitable advice to give to the clients?
A
Consider investing 25% of the funds over the medium- to long-term to obtain a higher return
B
Consider investing 50% of the funds over the medium- to long-term to obtain a higher return
C
Invest the funds in a deposit account at the 5.75% rate
D
Pay-off their mortgage
The correct answer is: D - Pay-off their mortgage

Explanation

Given no other information about the investor's circumstances, this seems the best solution. The interest on the mortgage is far higher than any return that they could expect from investments.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1015276] In what type of pension fund does the sponsoring company agree to pay members of the scheme a predetermined percentage of salary, subject to the contributor's years of service?
A
Defined benefit
B
Defined contribution
C
Personal pension
D
Stakeholder pension
The correct answer is: A - Defined benefit

Explanation

Company pension schemes tend to be defined benefit although these are becoming less popular!

Question 2

[1015239] The manager of a pension fund, in considering possible investments in the UK equity sector, will need be most concerned about:
A
Capital Gains Tax
B
Income Tax
C
The transaction costs of buying and selling shares
D
Corporation tax
The correct answer is: C - The transaction costs of buying and selling shares

Explanation

Pension funds do not pay income, capital gains or corporation tax.

Question 3

[1015244] In a pension scheme, which of the following is responsible for the Statement of Investment Principles?
A
The sponsoring company
B
The members
C
The trustees
D
The fund manager
The correct answer is: C - The trustees

Explanation

The SIP must set out in writing: the scheme specific funding requirements, the nature of investments in the fund and the risks of the fund. The SIP must be reviewed every three years.

Question 4

[1012499] Which of the following are powers of The Pensions Regulator?
I
Power to remove trustees or the directors of trustee companies from office
II
Power to impose fines and civil penalties
III
Power to wind up a scheme where it is in the best interests of the members
IV
Power to investigate breaches of the general law of trusts
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, II and III
C
III only
D
II and IV
The correct answer is: B - I, II and III

Explanation

The Pensions Regulator replaced OPRA under The Pensions Act 2004. It is not concerned with all trusts, only those related to pensions.

Question 5

[1015267] Which of the following are powers of The Pensions Regulator?
I
Power to remove trustees or the directors of trustee companies from office
II
Power to impose fines and civil penalties
III
Power to wind up a scheme where it is in the best interests of the members
IV
Power to investigate breaches of the general law of trusts
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, II and III
C
III only
D
II and IV
The correct answer is: B - I, II and III

Explanation

The Pensions Regulator replaced OPRA under The Pensions Act 2004. It is not concerned with all trusts, only those related to pensions.

Question 6

[1015219] Which of the following regulates pension funds?
A
Trustee Act 2000
B
Pension Act 2004
C
Companies Act 2006
D
Financial Services and Markets Act 2000
The correct answer is: B - Pension Act 2004

Explanation

Occupational Pension Funds are regulated by the Pension Act 2004.

Question 7

[1015250] Which of the following is/are correct regarding defined benefit pension plans?
I
Immature plans have high liquidity needs
II
Liquidity requirements increase as the fund matures
III
Liquidity requirements dependent on current age of future beneficiaries
A
I only
B
II and III
C
I and III
D
I, II, and III
The correct answer is: B - II and III

Explanation

The need for liquidity will increase as the beneficiaries approach retirement and the fund matures.

Question 8

[1015227] With what would a UK pension fund manager managing a new portfolio be least concerned?
A
Future liabilities
B
Risk
C
Stock selection
D
Taxation
The correct answer is: D - Taxation

Explanation

Pension funds do not pay tax.

Question 9

[1014923] Which one of the following would normally regulate the marketing of authorised unit trust schemes by the manager of the scheme?
A
BIS
B
Lloyds
C
ICMA
D
FCA
The correct answer is: D - FCA

Explanation

The FCA (Financial Conduct Authority) initially authorise, and then regulate unit trusts.

Question 10

[1015303] The Scheme Specific Funding Requirement, introduced by the Pensions Act 2004, relates to which of the following pension schemes?
A
Certain occupational defined benefit schemes
B
Certain occupational money purchase schemes
C
Private pension schemes
D
SERPS
The correct answer is: A - Certain occupational defined benefit schemes

Explanation

The minimum funding requirement only applies to defined benefit pension schemes to ensure they remain adequately funded.

Question 11

[1012479] Which of the following is addressed in the Statement of Investment Principles?
I
A recovery plan addressing any shortfall
II
The trustees policy regarding selecting investments
III
The balance between investment risk and returns
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

The Statement of Investment Principles are prepared by the trustee of an occupational pensions scheme. A recovery plan addressing any shortfall would be addressed in the statement of funding principles.

Question 12

[1015211] A pension scheme where the contributions into the scheme are used to buy investments, and the returns from the investments determine the pensions paid, is called what?
A
Defined Benefit Scheme
B
Personal Pension Plan
C
Occupational Pension Scheme
D
Defined Contribution Scheme
The correct answer is: D - Defined Contribution Scheme

Explanation

A defined benefit scheme, on the other hand, guarantees a level of pension.

Question 13

[1015256] What is the most suitable risk warning stated on an advert for an income and growth fund?
A
You might lose more than you originally invested
B
The value of your units may go down as well as up
C
You must be a professional investor
D
Your home may be at risk if you do not keep up payments
The correct answer is: B - The value of your units may go down as well as up

Explanation

'You might lose more than you originally invested' would be most suitable for adverts relating to contingent liability transactions, e.g. futures.

Question 14

[1015222] Who authorises ICVCs?
A
FCA
B
Inland Revenue
C
DTI
D
Bank of England
The correct answer is: A - FCA

Explanation

The FCA also authorises unit trusts. NB. ICVC = Investment Company with Variable Capital

Question 15

[1015240] Which of the following is/are likely to cause a pension fund manager to increase the proportion of equities in their portfolio?
I
An increase in the trustees' tolerance of risk
II
An increase in the average age of contributors to the fund
III
An increase in expected inflation
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
III only
D
All of them
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

Option II is incorrect because an increase in the average age of contributors would cause a shift into bonds rather than equities. Option I is correct; an increased tolerance for risk permits a greater allocation to equity and its higher long-run expected return. Option III is correct as inflation erodes the nominal value of bonds, whereas shares are more likely to see their prices rise with inflation.

Question 16

[1015245] A pension fund where most of the members are close to retirement will invest more heavily in which of the following?
A
Equities
B
Fixed income securities
C
Short term securities
D
Derivatives
The correct answer is: B - Fixed income securities

Explanation

The income on fixed income securities is more certain; this becomes important as people reach retirement age and expect to draw down a regular pension.

Question 17

[1015209] Most UK pension funds are mainly invested in:
A
Gilts
B
Equities
C
Derivatives
D
UK corporate bonds
The correct answer is: B - Equities

Explanation

UK funds have a strong equity culture compared to other European countries.

Question 18

[1015286] Which of the following types of pensions best describes a situation where an agreed level of contributions are paid by an individual and are invested over time to give a return?
A
Defined benefit
B
Defined contribution
C
SERPS
D
Occupational Pension Scheme
The correct answer is: B - Defined contribution

Explanation

A defined benefit scheme is one where the RETURN is guaranteed. A defined contribution scheme (or 'money purchase' scheme) best suits the description in the question.

Question 19

[1015283] A pension scheme where the contributions to the scheme are determined as the amounts needed to buy investments to fund a specified level of pension payment is called what?
A
A Defined Benefit Scheme
B
A Personal Pension Plan
C
An Occupation Pension Scheme
D
A Defined Contribution Scheme
The correct answer is: A - A Defined Benefit Scheme

Explanation

Remember that, in a DEFINED BENEFIT SCHEME, it is the pension payout that is guaranteed.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1046724] Where do corporate bonds mostly trade?
A
Exchanges
B
Liquidity pools
C
OTC
D
TRAX
The correct answer is: C - OTC

Explanation

TRAX is a reporting mechanism. Even though corporate bonds trade through the other three mechanisms it is OTC where they are most frequently traded.

Question 2

[1016986] In the event of a default by an exchange member, which of the following is the best description of what will happen if the clearing house offers an independent guarantee?
A
The resources of the clearing house can be used to close-out the position
B
The resources of the clearing house and the clearing house members will be used to close-out the position
C
The resources of the members of the clearing house only will be used
D
The resources of only the defaulting member will be used
The correct answer is: A - The resources of the clearing house can be used to close-out the position

Explanation

If an exchange is using an independent guarantee then after using clearing member margin, its resources will be used in the event of a default by a clearing member. ICE Clear Europe uses a mutual guarantee where both the clearing house and members' resources are used.

Question 3

[1046718] In a stock borrowing and lending situation which of the following statements are FALSE?
A
The lender of the stock may receive an artificial dividend
B
The lender of the stock loses voting rights
C
The lender of the stock can still sell the stock
D
The lender of the stock will have stock returned at a future date
The correct answer is: C - The lender of the stock can still sell the stock

Explanation

If the lender of the stock wished to sell it, the stock would have to be returned from the Stock Borrowing and Lending Intermediary.

Question 4

[1001210] All of the following are true of CREST except:
A
It is the primary settlement system for UK equity on the LSE
B
It is operated and owned by Euroclear UK and Ireland
C
Physical payments are made within the CREST system
D
It provides settlement of dematerialised and paper stock
The correct answer is: C - Physical payments are made within the CREST system

Explanation

CREST is the settlement system used for UK equities traded through the LSE. The CREST Courier and Sorting Service (CCSS) still allows investors to transfer paper certificates although most settlement within CREST is done electronically. This is called 'book entry transfer'. Payments are made outside CREST by payment banks.

Question 5

[1015830] At what stage does a clearing house become the central counterparty to a trade?
A
When the trade is struck
B
When the trade is reported
C
When the trade is settled
D
When the trade is registered
The correct answer is: D - When the trade is registered

Explanation

Once the trade has been allocated and assigned in the Universal Clearing Platform, it is then passed onto the clearing house.

Question 6

[1015656] A benefit of LSE's CCP service is:
A
Reduced administration
B
Disclosure of parties to the trade
C
Reduced FX risk
D
Decreased market risk
The correct answer is: A - Reduced administration

Explanation

The identity of the counterparty will not be disclosed, the CCP service has no impact on FX, and it reduces credit risk. However, there is a reduction in administration thanks to the ability to settle on a net basis with a single counterparty, such as LCH.

Question 7

[1015205] Standard settlement for UK Government loan stock is:
A
T+1
B
T+2
C
T+3
D
T+5
The correct answer is: A - T+1

Explanation

Gilts settle via CREST on the next business day after the trade date - T+1.

Question 8

[1013449] What is the purpose of variation margin?
A
Cover adverse movements expected over the next week
B
An initial deposit to cover the maximum likely daily loss on a futures contract
C
Cover adverse movements in value from the previous day
D
Cover adverse movements from the previous week
The correct answer is: C - Cover adverse movements in value from the previous day

Explanation

Variation margin can be a receipt or a payment. It represents the profit or loss on open derivative positions, which result from changes in underlying asset values from the previous day.

Question 9

[1001178] Which two of the following statements in reference to SETS are untrue?
I
SETS orders can be anonymous
II
The highest priced sell order will be at the top of the sell side of the SETS order book
III
Orders at the same price will be matched on a time priority basis
IV
Orders at the same price will be matched on the basis of highest volume first
A
I and III
B
II and IV
C
II and III
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: B - II and IV

Explanation

Option II is incorrect as it is the LOWEST priced sell order that will be at the top of the sell side of the SETS order book. Option IV is incorrect as order book priority is PRICE then TIME (volume is irrelevant).

Question 10

[1015192] Who offers stock-lending and borrowing facilities in the Eurobond market?
A
CREST
B
Clearstream
C
CGO
D
LCH.Clearnet
The correct answer is: B - Clearstream

Explanation

Clearstream and Euroclear both provide Eurobond clearance, settlement, custody, lending and borrowing services.

Question 11

[1012472] Which of the following is/are true regarding SETS?
I
It is a quote driven market where market makers display bid and offer prices
II
It is an order driven market where members place orders into an electronic order book
III
Orders are matched in order of priority according to price, then time of input
A
I only
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

SETS is a fully automatic electronic trading system. It is referred to as an order book, as it is driven by the orders placed on it and not bid/offer quotes. The system will rank the orders by best price and then earliest time.

Question 12

[1015179] Which of the following investments is/are settled through CREST?
I
UK corporate equities
II
Money market instruments
III
UK corporate loan stock
IV
UK government bonds
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, III and IV
C
I and IV
D
II only
The correct answer is: A - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Money market instruments are now settled through Crest.

Question 13

[1016227] What is the purpose of the London Stock Exchange's central counterparty service?
A
To reduce systematic risk through diversification
B
To reduce liabilities by guaranteeing returns
C
To reduce default risk through margin
D
To reduce settlement risk through delivery vs. payment
The correct answer is: C - To reduce default risk through margin

Explanation

The Central Counterparty service (CCP) provided by the London Stock Exchange reduces default risk by novating the contract and collecting margin. CREST protects against settlement risk through delivery vs. payment (DvP).

Question 14

[1013448] Which of the following best defines initial margin?
A
Adverse movements expected over the next week
B
Initial deposit to cover the maximum likely daily loss on a futures contract
C
Adverse movements in value from the previous day
D
Adverse movements from the previous week
The correct answer is: B - Initial deposit to cover the maximum likely daily loss on a futures contract

Explanation

Initial margin is a 'goodwill deposit' payable to LCH.Clearnet when entering into futures positions.

Question 15

[1015163] Which of the following is true regarding London Stock Exchange member firms?
A
They must quote firm prices at which they will trade if they choose to act as principal
B
They are automatically considered to be market makers and therefore quote firm prices at which they will trade
C
They may choose to act as an agency broker for some deals and as a principal for others
D
They have to act either as an agency broker or principal but not both
The correct answer is: C - They may choose to act as an agency broker for some deals and as a principal for others

Explanation

London Stock Exchange member firms have dual capacity: every member may deal as a principal or agency broker. If a member firm wants to take principal trading a step further then they may, in certain stocks, register as a market maker. Market makers are obliged to quote firm two way prices.

Question 16

[1046696] A firm lends out client stock, who would make the trade report?
A
It is not a reportable trade
B
The firm
C
It will be automatic
D
The custodian
The correct answer is: A - It is not a reportable trade

Explanation

There is not enough to assume any selling has taken place so therefore it implies collateral lending and this is not a reportable trade.

Question 17

[1013423] Which organisation acts as central counterparty and clearing house?
A
LCH.Clearnet
B
RCH
C
OM London Exchange
D
CREST
The correct answer is: A - LCH.Clearnet

Explanation

LCH.Clearnet is a recognised clearing house (RCH) which acts as central counterparty for trades executed on may exchanges.

Question 18

[1001163] A market order contains which of the following information?
I
Whether the order is a buy or sell
II
Limit price
III
Volume of shares
IV
Expiry date
A
II and III
B
I and IV
C
I and III
D
I, III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I and III

Explanation

A market order will execute at the current best price on the order book whatever that may be. It will also execute immediately. Consequently, such an order will not specify a price or an expiry time.

Question 19

[1015191] Which of the following best describes CREST?
A
Computer based system
B
Paper based system
C
Electronic trading system
D
Electronic order book
The correct answer is: A - Computer based system

Explanation

CREST deals with securities in a dematerialised format.

Question 20

[1023959] What is the main purpose of stock borrowing from the lender's point of view?
A
To reduce risk in the portfolio
B
To increase liquidity in the market
C
To increase the portfolio returns
D
To reduce capital requirements
The correct answer is: C - To increase the portfolio returns

Explanation

Lending of stock by an institution will generate fees, which is its main purpose.

Question 21

[1015198] Which of the following is commonly used for the settlement of Eurobond transactions?
A
LCH.Clearnet
B
Euroclear
C
LME
D
SWX Europe
The correct answer is: B - Euroclear

Explanation

Eurobond trades generally settle through one of two clearing houses: Euroclear and Clearstream. LCH.Clearnet is a central counterparty and LME and SWX Europe (the new name for virt-x) are exchanges.

Question 22

[1046720] On SETS and SEAQ, what does NMS relate to?
A
The minimum order size
B
The total daily volume
C
The maximum order size
D
The average trade volume
The correct answer is: D - The average trade volume

Explanation

Even though a better answer is a percentage of the average daily volume made by institutions, the average trade volume is the best option given by the examiner.

Question 23

[1012316] CREST is:
I
A trading system
II
A settlement system
III
A custodian
IV
A CSD
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
II, III and IV
D
I, II and IV
The correct answer is: C - II, III and IV

Explanation

A CSD is a Central Securities Depositary, which refers to any institution that provides custodial services. CREST is also a RCH (Recognised Clearing House) and provides settlement on a delivery versus payment system.

Question 24

[1015183] Which of the following investments is/are not settled through CREST?
I
UK equities
II
Options on Euronext.liffe
III
Treasury bills
IV
UK government bonds
A
II, III and IV
B
II and III
C
I and IV
D
II only
The correct answer is: D - II only

Explanation

Options on NYSE Liffe clear through the LCH.Clearnet. Treasury bills are traded on the money markets but are now settled through Crest.

Question 25

[1015182] Ms Uvavu wishes to sell £20,000 of shares through a broker. Which of the following costs would she incur?
I
Broking commission
II
SDRT
III
Takeover Panel levy
A
I only
B
I and II
C
I and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - I and III

Explanation

The Takeover Panel levy of £1 is chargeable on all UK equity transactions with a consideration of £10,000 or more. The broker is not going to do the deal for free, so brokerage will have to be paid, but as its not a purchase she will not incur stamp duty.

Question 26

[1015204] Who acts as depositary for Eurobonds?
A
Clearstream
B
CREST
C
LCH.Clearnet
D
Euro Bourse
The correct answer is: A - Clearstream

Explanation

Settlement / depositary functions for Eurobonds are carried out by Euroclear and Clearstream.

Question 27

[1015173] What is a NYSE designated market maker?
A
A firm that trades only in certain stocks
B
An elective professional client
C
A firm that can only deal with retail clients
D
A firm responsible for matching or filling orders to ensure liquidity
The correct answer is: D - A firm responsible for matching or filling orders to ensure liquidity

Explanation

Designated market makers ensure liquidity (similar to the LSE market maker role).

Question 28

[1015162] Which of the following is TRUE about LSE market makers?
A
Quote continuous bid and offer prices, but do not have to indicate a minimum number of shares they will trade
B
Quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares at which their prices are firm
C
Do not quote continuous bid and offer prices, but indicate a minimum number of shares they will trade
D
Do not quote continuous bid and offer prices, and do not have to indicate a maximum number of shares at which their prices are firm
The correct answer is: B - Quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares at which their prices are firm

Explanation

LSE market makers must quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares they will trade.

Question 29

[1070652] How many days does a UK equity trade take to settle?
A
2 days
B
5 days
C
10 days
D
14 days
The correct answer is: A - 2 days

Explanation

Standard settlement is T+2.

Question 30

[1001181] An inter-dealer broker (IDB) can deal with which of the following?
I
Market maker acting as principal
II
Market maker acting as an agent
III
Stock borrowing and lending intermediary
IV
Broker dealer
A
I only
B
I and II
C
I, II and III
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: D - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

IDBs offer their services to other member firms. These are often market makers wishing to trade-out of large positions but retain their anonymity.

Question 31

[1015174] What is the Universal Trading Platform of the NYSE?
A
A settlement system for equities
B
A system for publishing trade information
C
A system for automatic order execution
D
A system for transferring orders to designated market makers
The correct answer is: D - A system for transferring orders to designated market makers

Explanation

Universal Trading Platform is used for passing orders to designated market makers for matching against the order book or filling. It is referred to as a 'designated order turnaround system'.

Question 32

[1017685] Frank Ortiz is very risk averse and does not want to lose any of his capital. Which of the following do you recommend?
A
Gilts priced above par
B
Hedge fund
C
Unit trust
D
Deposit account
The correct answer is: D - Deposit account

Explanation

Deposit accounts do not expose the investor's capital to risk, generally speaking. Gilts priced below par would also be considered to be a very low-risk investment.

Question 33

[1015184] How many days does a US equity trade take to settle on the New York Stock Exchange?
A
25
B
14
C
5
D
3
The correct answer is: D - 3

Explanation

Note, standard settlement in the UK is T+2.

Question 34

[1046794] Which of the following is TRUE regarding Emerging Market Securities? They:
A
are often under researched and therefore offer potential opportunities
B
offer low volatility
C
are highly correlated with government bonds
D
trade on a market that is always fair and transparent
The correct answer is: A - are often under researched and therefore offer potential opportunities

Explanation

Emerging markets are highly sensitive to political risk and hence many are highly volatile. Many markets which are still in their infancy suffer from insider trading and lack of liquidity. Like most equities, correlation with government bonds should be low.

Question 35

[1016221] Which of the following best reflects the securities that trade on SETS?
A
FTSE 100 shares only
B
FTSE 100 shares and the more liquid FTSE 250 shares
C
FTSE All Shares only
D
FTSE All Shares and the more liquid AIM shares
The correct answer is: D - FTSE All Shares and the more liquid AIM shares

Explanation

The FTSE All Share and the more liquid AIM shares are traded on the SETS platform. All others trade on SETSqx.

Question 36

[1066763] What is the role of a systematic internaliser?
A
To provide continuous liquidity in the markets by providing buy prices (BID) and sell prices (OFFER)
B
To provide intermediating services between other firms
C
Borrowing from institutional investors with large portfolios that are passively held
D
To facilitate a cross trade between clients
The correct answer is: D - To facilitate a cross trade between clients

Explanation

A broker may act on behalf of TWO clients. The broker may, therefore, buy from one client AND sell to another. This is known as a 'CROSS-TRADE'. Although in performing this trade the firm has effectively created a flat position for itself, it must report both sides of the trade into the exchange. In this situation the broker would be known as a systematic inernaliser.

Question 37

[1015194] What are GEMMs?
A
Gilt-edged money markets
B
Gilt-edged market managers
C
Gilt-edged market makers
D
Gilt-edged money makers
The correct answer is: C - Gilt-edged market makers

Explanation

GEMMs register with the DMO, and undertake to make a market in gilts. They are also LSE members.

Question 38

[1015193] Eurobond transactions are largely conducted according to rules drawn up by:
A
The Bank for International Settlements
B
The Federal Reserve
C
The European Union Commission
D
The International Capital Markets Association
The correct answer is: D - The International Capital Markets Association

Explanation

The International Capital Markets Association (ICMA) is the regulatory body for Eurobond markets.

Question 39

[1015172] An investor buys £10,500 worth of shares and sells them later the same day. Which of the following organisations would benefit from the direct charges levied on these transactions?
I
Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs
II
The Financial Conduct Authority
III
The Takeover Panel
IV
The Financial Services and Markets Tribunal
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I and III
C
II and IV
D
I only
The correct answer is: B - I and III

Explanation

The inland revenue will receive stamp duty whilst the PTM will receive a levy of £1 on deals with a consideration of £10,000 or more.

Question 40

[1046450] Euroclear UK and Ireland run a settlement system for UK securities called CREST. Other than arranging payment and delivery of securities, what extra service does CREST arrange?
A
Novation of trades performed on LSE's SETS system
B
Collects payment for SDRT and transfers them directly to HMRC
C
Creates invoices for each member for net SDRT payments at the end of each day
D
Acts as depository for bearer documents in the UK
The correct answer is: B - Collects payment for SDRT and transfers them directly to HMRC

Explanation

CREST will collect SDRT on behalf of Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC). However, these will be collected for each purchase. There is no netting of SDRT.

Question 41

[1001193] Which of the following represents the main benefit to investors of the LSE central counterparty?
A
Lower cost
B
Lower risk
C
Faster execution
D
Wider spreads
The correct answer is: B - Lower risk

Explanation

The CCP service provides greater protection for investors against the risk of settlement default.

Question 42

[1001462] Which of the following securities is most suitable if you are an investor who wishes to have an increase in returns as the performance of the company improves?
A
Debentures
B
Participating preference shares
C
Cumulative preference shares
D
Redeemable preference shares
The correct answer is: B - Participating preference shares

Explanation

Participating preference shares have a fixed dividend but also have a bonus tethered to them in years of improved performance. Cumulative preference shares, redeemable preference shares and debentures all have a fixed return.

Question 43

[1014213] The process by which a clearing house becomes the central counterparty to all transactions on NYSE.liffe is called:
A
Registration
B
Clearance
C
Novation
D
Margin
The correct answer is: C - Novation

Explanation

Novation is the process by which the clearing house becomes the central counterparty to exchange-traded transactions.

Question 44

[1070654] What is the settlement period for shares traded on the LSE?
A
2 business days
B
10 business days
C
7 calendar days
D
14 calendar days
The correct answer is: A - 2 business days

Explanation

Standard settlement is T+2.

Question 45

[1015156] Market makers on the SEAQ system of the LSE:
A
Must quote bid and offer prices up to the minimum quote size and are obliged to deal
B
Have to quote bid-offer prices but are never bound by them
C
Quote indicative bid and offer prices but do not have to deal
D
Must quote bid and offer prices up to the minimum quote price and are not obliged to deal
The correct answer is: A - Must quote bid and offer prices up to the minimum quote size and are obliged to deal

Explanation

Price quotes are required of market makers up to a minimum SIZE of trade, determined by the London Stock Exchange.

Question 46

[1044947] Which of the following is a major benefit of a quote-driven market?
A
Better prices for traders
B
No requirement for market makers
C
Time priority matching of buy and sell orders
D
Increased liquidity
The correct answer is: D - Increased liquidity

Explanation

A quote-driven market, through the use of market makers, always has buyers and sellers in the market. Market makers are often referred to as liquidity providers for that reason.

Question 47

[1012757] Which of the following best defines what variation margin payments cover?
A
Adverse movements expected over the next week
B
Initial payment to cover future movement in price
C
Adverse movements in value from the previous day
D
Adverse movements from the previous week
The correct answer is: C - Adverse movements in value from the previous day

Explanation

Variation margin can be a receipt or a payment. It represents the profit or loss on open derivative positions, which result from changes in underlying asset values from the previous day.

Question 48

[1015159] What is NMS?
A
Normal Multiplier System
B
Normal Market System
C
Normal Market Size
D
Normal Multiplier Size
The correct answer is: C - Normal Market Size

Explanation

Normal Market Size is used by the London Stock Exchange as a measure of the volume of trades executed in a particular security on SETS or SEAQ.

Question 49

[1012368] Which of the following settlement systems is used for gilt trades on the London Stock Exchange?
A
CGO
B
CREST
C
LCH.Clearnet
D
CMMO
The correct answer is: B - CREST

Explanation

The Central Gilts Office (CGO) and Central Money Markets Office (CMMO) are no longer used for gilt or money market settlements. LCH.Clearnet is the central counterparty for London Stock Exchange SETS transactions, but not Gilts.

Question 50

[1047475] SDRT:
A
Is collected by CREST
B
Is calculated by the investor
C
Is paid by the buyer directly to HMRC
D
Is paid on certificated transactions
The correct answer is: A - Is collected by CREST

Explanation

Stamp Duty and SDRT is a tax payable when certain shares are purchased. SDRT is paid on transactions that settle through CREST. CREST, calculates, collects and transfers SDRT to Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (i.e. the UK government tax authority).

Question 51

[1015555] When a market maker uses a stock borrowing and lending intermediary to cover a short position by borrowing stock from a fund manager, which of the following best describes the relationship between the SBLI and their counterparties?
A
Agent with the market maker and agent with the fund manager
B
Agent with the market maker and principal with the fund manager
C
Principal with the market maker and agent with the fund manager
D
Principal with the market maker and principal with the fund manager
The correct answer is: A - Agent with the market maker and agent with the fund manager

Explanation

The SBLI acts as intermediary with both parties.

Question 52

[1001172] On SETS, the best offer price is:
A
The lowest priced sell order
B
The lowest priced buy order
C
The highest priced sell order
D
The highest priced buy order
The correct answer is: A - The lowest priced sell order

Explanation

Note: the best bid price is the highest priced buy order.

Competency Test (Random Difficulty Questions)

Question 1

[1015327] An investor, who is a non-tax payer, receives a dividend of £400. Which of the following can he do to reclaim the tax deducted on the dividends paid if the basic rate tax band is £31,865?
A
Nothing
B
Submit a claim to his (buying) broker for £100
C
Submit a claim to the company for £100
D
Submit a claim to the Inland Revenue for £44.44
The correct answer is: A - Nothing

Explanation

The 10 per cent tax credit on UK dividends cannot be reclaimed by non-taxpayers.

Question 2

[1015333] An investor buys some shares in company A for £15,000 and company B for £8,000. Some time later the shares in company A are sold for £13,000 and the shares in company B for £27,000. Assume that the investor pays 18% tax on capital gains and that the exemption is £11,000. What is the capital gains tax paid by the investor? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 0,000
The correct answer is: 1,080 - 1,080

Explanation

The capital losses on share A can be offset against the capital gains on share B which gives a net gain of £17,000. The annual exemption can be deducted from this leaving a capital gain of £6,000. This is taxed at 18% and will give a tax bill of £6,000 x 18% = £1,080.

Question 3

[1015313] An investor owns 5,000 shares in a company, which pays a net dividend of 9p per share. The investor is a higher rate taxpayer. What is the additional tax to be paid by the investor? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without any symbols: 000.0
The correct answer is: 112.5 - 112.5

Explanation

Gross dividend = 5,000 x 0.09 x 100/90 = £500. Total Tax paid at 32.5% = £500 x 0.325 = £162.5. Therefore, additional tax to pay = £162.5 - £50 (tax credit) = £112.50.

Question 4

[1044478] Which of the following has VAT charged at the standard rate?
A
Commissions charged by stock brokers
B
Nominee services
C
Advisory services not invoiced separately
D
Portfolio management fees
The correct answer is: D - Portfolio management fees

Explanation

Portfolio management fees are subject to VAT at the standard rate. If advisory services are invoiced separately they are subject to VAT.

Question 5

[1017591] Venture capital trusts (VCT) are most similar in structure to which other collective investment vehicle?
A
OEIC
B
Investment trust
C
Unit trust
D
REIT
The correct answer is: B - Investment trust

Explanation

Venture capital trusts are constituted very much like an investment trust. However, their investment focus is specifically on smaller, higher-risk companies.

Question 6

[1015324] A higher rate taxpayer receives a net dividend of £800. How much additional tax must he pay? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 000.00
The correct answer is: 200.00 - 200.00

Explanation

Gross dividend = 100 / 90 x £800 = £889. Therefore extra tax = 22.5% x £889 = £200.

Question 7

[1015309] What is the full rate for corporation tax? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without any symbols: 00
The correct answer is: 21 - 21

Explanation

21% is payable if taxable profits are £1.5m or more.

Question 8

[1015212] Which of the following is/are true?
I
The proceeds of all life assurance policies are taxable
II
Income from pension funds is taxable
III
Contributions to pension funds are taxable
A
I only
B
II only
C
III only
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: B - II only

Explanation

Proceeds from qualifying life assurance policies are tax free (such as endowments), whilst proceeds from pensions are taxable. Contributions to pension funds are usually made from net earnings, but as tax relief is given on them it is fair to say that III is false.

Question 9

[1044628] David Cook buys a single premium life assurance bond in March 2004 for £10,000. Each March he withdraws £400 until December 2012 when he surrenders the bond for £12,500. What profit has he made? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 0,000
The correct answer is: 5,700 - 5,700

Explanation

The profit is calculated as follows: Proceeds: £12,500 Withdrawals: £400 x 8 years = £3,200 Purchase price: (£10,000) Profit: £5,700

Question 10

[1015322] What is the rate of SDRT?
A
5p per £100 consideration
B
5p per £1000 consideration
C
50p per £100 consideration
D
50p per £1000 consideration
The correct answer is: C - 50p per £100 consideration

Explanation

Stamp Duty Reserve Tax is calculated at 0.5% of the sale proceeds - remember that Stamp Duty/SDRT are payable by the BUYER of a security.

Question 11

[1044592] Terence Fisher dies in 2009/10 leaving his worldwide assets to his wife, June. His wife dies in 2020/21. The nil rate band in 2009/10 is £325,000, and if the nil rate band in 2020/21 is £400,000, what is deemed to be the nil rate band on the assets of Terence's widow?
A
£400,000
B
£650,000
C
£750,000
D
£800,000
The correct answer is: D - £800,000

Explanation

In this question Terence's nil rate band is passed on to his wife. However, it is the percentage of the nil rate band that is passed on - in this case 100%. This means that on the death of June, it is not only 100% of the current nil rate band that can be used, but 200% of the current nil rate band.

Question 12

[1015318] Company A has profits chargeable to corporation tax of £8m, and has paid cash dividends of £3m. What is its corporation tax liability?
A
£1,920,000
B
£1,680,000
C
£1,600,000
D
£780,000
The correct answer is: B - £1,680,000

Explanation

Corporation tax = £8m x 0.21 = £1.68m. NB: Dividends are paid out of post-tax profits.

Question 13

[1017658] Which of the following is true of inheritance tax?
A
IHT is paid on death only
B
IHT is paid on death and is paid in life on a potentially exempt transfer
C
IHT is paid on death and is paid in life on an exempt transfer
D
IHT is paid on death and may be paid in life on a chargeable lifetime transfer
The correct answer is: D - IHT is paid on death and may be paid in life on a chargeable lifetime transfer

Explanation

A chargeable person can be liable for IHT on lifetime transfers. For example, some transfers into a trust.

Question 14

[1017643] Marie Sanchez has taxable earned income of £30,000 (after taking into account her personal allowance). She has realised a chargeable gain of £4,000 after using her CGT allowance. How much CGT is she due on this gain? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 000.00
The correct answer is: 933.50 - 933.50

Explanation

The basic rate band ends at £31,865. Marie's gain moves beyond this band. For this reason she will be taxed on the gain partly at the basic rate (18%) and partly at the higher rate (28%). The first £1,865 of the gain is taxed at 18%: £1,865 x 0.18 = £335.70 The remaining £2,135 is taxed at 28%: £2,135 x 0.28 = £597.80 The tax due on the gain is: £335.70 + £597.80 = £933.50

Question 15

[1015317] Which of the following is false?
A
A UK resident company is liable to pay corporation tax on its profits
B
A UK resident company is liable to pay corporation tax on any capital gains it makes
C
A UK resident company is liable to capital gains tax on its capital gains
D
A UK resident company is not liable to inheritance tax
The correct answer is: C - A UK resident company is liable to capital gains tax on its capital gains

Explanation

A UK resident company is liable for corporation tax on its profits AND its capital gains.

Question 16

[1044585] Which of the following is TRUE of capital losses?
A
Capital losses need not be offset against gains in the same tax year if the annual exemption can cover it
B
Capital losses derived from a holding in an EIS can be offset against income
C
Capital losses brought forward must be used before any annual exemption
D
Net capital losses in the year of death are ignored
The correct answer is: B - Capital losses derived from a holding in an EIS can be offset against income

Explanation

To make the other statements true: Capital losses must be offset against any gains in the same year before the annual exemption is used. Any losses carried forward need only be used AFTER the annual exemption is used up. Net capital losses in the year of death can be carried back for up to three years.

Question 17

[1049978] An investor particularly wants to avoid any liability to CGT. Which of the following investment vehicles would minimise the CGT for the investor?
I
Venture capital trust
II
Open ended investment company
III
Real estate investment company
IV
Enterprise investment scheme
A
I only
B
I, III & IV
C
IV only
D
I and IV
The correct answer is: D - I and IV

Explanation

Investments in the EIS are free of CGT if held for at least three years. Investments in a VCT are exempt from CGT (and losses are not allowable). REITs and OEICs are liable to CGT on encashment but not while the funds are invested.

Question 18

[1044581] Which of the following is true of both Venture Capital Trusts (VCT) and Enterprise Investment Schemes (EIS)?
A
The maximum investment eligible for relief is £200,000
B
Capital gains tax exemption
C
Inheritance tax exemption
D
Income tax relief of 20% is available
The correct answer is: B - Capital gains tax exemption

Explanation

The following summarises the tax benefits of these investment vehicles:

Question 19

[1015306] For a small company what rate of tax will be applicable?
A
24%
B
Something between 20% and 24%
C
20%
D
0%
The correct answer is: C - 20%

Explanation

The small company's rate is 20%.

Question 20

[1044650] Brian Spencer wishes to take a lump sum from his pension savings before buying an annuity. What is the maximum amount of his funds he can take tax free?
A
5%
B
10%
C
25%
D
33%
The correct answer is: C - 25%

Explanation

Any more than this would incur a tax liability.

Question 21

[1017660] What percentage of a single premium life assurance bond can be taken from the original capital as income per annum on a tax deferred basis?
A
2%
B
5%
C
10%
D
15%
The correct answer is: B - 5%

Explanation

The 5% per annum can, however, be carried forward to future years if unused.

Question 22

[1015311] What is the tax credit on a dividend received by a 40% taxpayer?
A
10%
B
24%
C
40%
D
25%
The correct answer is: A - 10%

Explanation

The tax credit is deducted from the taxpayer's overall tax bill.

Question 23

[1051117] Clinton Dempsey has asked you, his financial adviser, to consider whether he is required to pay class 2 National Insurance contributions. You have established that this will be required if Clinton:
A
Derives all of his income from savings
B
Is over 65 and continues to derive income from employment
C
Has opted-out of the state second pension
D
Is self-employed
The correct answer is: D - Is self-employed

Explanation

Class 2 contributions are payable by self-employed individuals.

Question 24

[1049946] Marcus is a higher rate taxpayer who wishes to invest in a well-diversified fund and gain some tax efficiency, but wants to take control of the timings of his purchases and sales. He has an internet share-dealing account with his retail bank. Which of the following would be the best investment?
A
He should invest in an authorised unit trust held in an ISA account
B
He should invest in an investment trust company held in an ISA account
C
He should invest in a unit-linked investment bond
D
He should invest in an EIS-qualifying company via his share-dealing account
The correct answer is: B - He should invest in an investment trust company held in an ISA account

Explanation

Marcus wants to gain tax efficiency, and all of the investments provide a certain tax benefit. All gains and income within an ISA account are tax-free, although tax credits on dividends cannot be reclaimed. Investment bonds allow a deferral of tax until encashment, when Marcus's tax liability may be lower. Enterprise investment schemes offer income and capital gain tax relief. However, Marcus also wanted a diversified fund: this eliminates the EIS-qualifying company. He also wanted control over his purchases and sales. This definitely eliminates the unit-linked bond, which is a fixed-term investment with early encashment penalties, and, to a lesser extent the unit trust, which is likely to have dilution levies charged on purchases and sales. The unit trust will also have less clarity on the pricing of purchases and sales, because of the, typically, forward-pricing. Investment trusts, as they trade on the secondary markets, have a more immediate pricing available and can be traded through his share-dealing account.

Question 25

[1065072] Which of the following best reflects the immediate income tax relief given to an investor in an Enterprise Investment Scheme (EIS)?
A
0%
B
10%
C
20%
D
30%
The correct answer is: D - 30%

Explanation

Although the investor receives an immediate 30% income tax relief on the amount invested, there is a 3 year holding period. If the investor sells the investment within 3 years, HMRC will claw back some of the relief given.

Question 26

[1015316] How much ADDITIONAL tax does a higher rate taxpayer pay on UK dividend income?
A
10%
B
20%
C
22.5%
D
40%
The correct answer is: C - 22.5%

Explanation

TOTAL tax a higher rate taxpayer pays on dividends = 32.5%. However, taxpayers receive a 10% tax credit on dividends. Remember, a 45% taxpayer (or 37.5% with respect to dividends) is referred to as an additional rate ta payer.

Question 27

[1015305] A UK resident company is liable to which of the following taxes?
I
Corporation tax
II
Income tax
III
Capital gains tax
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
All three
The correct answer is: A - I only

Explanation

Companies pay corporation tax on their income and capital gains.

Question 28

[1012258] When a UK company pays a dividend to a foreign investor, what is the withholding tax payable?
A
10% of the gross dividend paid
B
20% of the gross dividend paid
C
32.5% of the dividend paid
D
40% of the gross dividend paid
The correct answer is: A - 10% of the gross dividend paid

Explanation

Dividends paid abroad by UK companies have only the normal 10% deducted at source. Foreign investors receiving UK dividends may claim the 10% from their own tax authority. UK resident investors may not claim back this 10%.

Question 29

[1015319] Which of the following is/are true?
I
Corporation tax is charged at a flat rate of 21% for all companies
II
Capital gains made by a company are taxable
III
Losses can be carried back for three years
A
I, II, and III
B
I and II only
C
I only
D
II and III only
The correct answer is: D - II and III only

Explanation

21% is only paid if taxable profits are £1.5m or more. A company pays corporation tax on its capital gains. Losses may be carried back for a maximum of three years.

Question 30

[1011345] What is the maximum annual VCT subscription to attract tax relief?
A
£3,000
B
£30,000
C
£200,000
D
£300,000
The correct answer is: C - £200,000

Explanation

For tax purposes, the maximum amount that can be invested on an annual basis into a VCT is £200,000.

Question 31

[1017657] Which of the following transfers are exempt for inheritance tax purposes?
A
Transfer to a child
B
Transfer to a spouse/civil partner
C
Transfer to parent
D
Transfer to a family company
The correct answer is: B - Transfer to a spouse/civil partner

Explanation

Transfers to: Spouse/civil partner Certain charities Certain political parties are examples of those exempt from inheritance tax, as are certain lifetime transfers such as small gifts and gifts on marriage.

Question 32

[1015308] A company earns taxable profit of £250,000 in the year to 31 March. How much corporation tax is payable?
A
£50,000
B
£52,500
C
£70,000
D
£77,500
The correct answer is: A - £50,000

Explanation

Corporation tax payable = £250,000 x 0.20 (20%) = £50,000.

Question 33

[1015285] Which of the following statements are true of qualifying life policies and personal pension plans?
I
Life policy premiums are paid net, but proceeds are received gross
II
Life policy premiums are paid gross, but proceeds are received net
III
Personal Pension Plans contributions are paid gross, but proceeds are received net
IV
Personal Pension Plans contributions are paid net, but proceeds are received gross
A
I and III
B
I and IV
C
II and III
D
II and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

Tax relief is obtained at the time of investment for PPPs. Tax relief is received on life policies only on their maturity.

Question 34

[1015321] If a UK fund manager wished to increase the level of franked income into the fund, he would invest more heavily in:
A
US equities
B
US bonds
C
UK equities
D
UK bonds
The correct answer is: C - UK equities

Explanation

Franked income is dividends from UK equities. It is referred to as 'franked' because it is paid out of post-tax profits.

Question 35

[1017604] Real estate investment trusts (REITs) can be held in which of the following tax wrappers?
I
Individual saving account
II
Self-invested personal pension
III
Child trust funds
A
I and II
B
II and III
C
I, II, and III
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - I, II, and III

Explanation

Investors in REITs buy shares, and these typically trade on a regulated market such as the London Stock Exchange's official list. This qualifies them for inclusion in these tax efficient wrappers.

Practice Mock Exam

Question 1

[1070280] Marie Sanchez has taxable earned income of 30,000 (after taking into account her personal allowance). She realised a capital gains of 4,000 after using her CGT allowance. How much CGT is she due on this gain?
A
880.70
B
720
C
933.50
D
1,200
The correct answer is: C - 933.50

Explanation

The basic rate band ends at 31,865. Marie's gain moves beyond this band. For this reason she will be taxed on the gain partly at the basic rate (18%) and partly at the higher rate (28%). The first 1,865 of the gain is taxed at 18%: 1,865 x 0.18 = 335.70 The remaining 2,135 is taxed at 28%: 2,135 x 0.28 = 597.80 The tax due on the gain is: 335.70 + 597.80 = 933.50

Question 2

[1001162] Which one of the following would distinguish an electronic quote-driven system from an order-driven system?
A
They are often designed for the most liquid securities
B
Electronic trading is faster and more secure
C
Orders that are received can be matched automatically or by market makers
D
Market makers have to quote bid and offer prices
The correct answer is: D - Market makers have to quote bid and offer prices

Explanation

Only in quote-driven markets do market makers have to quote bid offer prices.

Question 3

[1001211] Which two of the following forms of settlement does CREST normally provide?
A
Book entry transfer
B
Free delivery
C
Delivery versus payment
D
Arbitration settlement
The correct answer is: C - Delivery versus payment

Explanation

DVP is the simultaneous transfer of ownership of a security in exchange for its equivalent value in consideration. Free delivery means that payment is made BEFORE the security is delivered. Although CREST can handle free delivery, it usually settles via delivery versus payment (DVP).

Question 4

[1001449] Which of the following will be the most suitable investment for a non-taxpayer who expects interest rates to rise and who requires income?
A
Exchangeable bonds
B
Low coupon bonds
C
Gilt strips
D
FRNs
The correct answer is: D - FRNs

Explanation

FRNs are Floating Rate Notes. These bonds pay a variable rate of interest linked to the interest rate in the economy. Therefore, the coupon on the bond will rise if interest rates increase. Also, the prices of FRNs are less sensitive to changes in interest rates than fixed rate bonds.

Question 5

[1001462] Which of the following securities is most suitable if you are an investor who wishes to have an increase in returns as the performance of the company improves?
A
Debentures
B
Participating preference shares
C
Cumulative preference shares
D
Redeemable preference shares
The correct answer is: B - Participating preference shares

Explanation

Participating preference shares have a fixed dividend but also have a bonus tethered to them in years of improved performance. Cumulative preference shares, redeemable preference shares and debentures all have a fixed return.

Question 6

[1001470] Which of the following may be taken into account under the 'know your customer' principle when trying to understand a client's profile and needs in relation to investing?
I
Personal details
II
Income
III
Assets and liabilities
IV
Expectations
A
I, II and III
B
I, III and IV
C
I, II and IV
D
All of the above
The correct answer is: D - All of the above

Explanation

All of the choices are relevant to the KYC policy.

Question 7

[1002093] Which of the following is a benefit of marketing your shares on AIM rather than the official list of the LSE?
A
Lower profile
B
Less liquidity
C
Lower regulatory burden
D
Order book trading
The correct answer is: C - Lower regulatory burden

Explanation

The obligations imposed on AIM are lower than those imposed on fully-listed companies. Both markets have access to order-driven systems.

Question 8

[1002787] The role of counterparty to the buyer of an exchange-traded futures contract is taken over from the seller by:
A
A consortium of member firms
B
The clearing member through which the contract was sold
C
A clearing house
D
An exchange
The correct answer is: C - A clearing house

Explanation

All exchange trades are settled via a clearing house acting as central counterparty. As central counterparty, a clearing house is the buyer against every short-trade, and the seller against every long-trade.

Question 9

[1012263] What is the universal trading platform system of the NYSE?
A
A settlement system for equities
B
A system for publishing trade information
C
A system for automatic order execution
D
A system for transferring orders to specialists
The correct answer is: D - A system for transferring orders to specialists

Explanation

SuperDOT is used for passing orders to specialists for matching against the order book or filling. It is referred to as a 'designated order turnaround system'.

Question 10

[1012315] Which of the following is /are true regarding capital gains tax?
I
An allowance is given for inflation
II
Allowance for length of ownership
III
Annual exemption 11,000
IV
Losses carried forward indefinitely
A
III and IV
B
III only
C
I and II
D
II and III
The correct answer is: A - III and IV

Explanation

The indexation allowance in option one and the allowance for length of ownership (taper relief), option two, were withdrawn April '08.

Question 11

[1012320] In respect of money laundering, which of the following is/are required of a company?
I
Identification procedures
II
Training staff
III
Internal controls, policies and procedures
A
I, II and III
B
I and III
C
III only
D
I and II
The correct answer is: A - I, II and III

Explanation

Other requirements are to appoint a Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO) and to report all suspicions.

Question 12

[1012321] Which of the following are FCA Principles of Business?
I
Communications with clients
II
Financial prudence
III
Market conduct
A
I, II and III
B
I and II
C
I and III
D
II and III
The correct answer is: A - I, II and III

Explanation

The principles apply to every firm. The application of the principles is modified for incoming EEA firms, incoming treaty firms and UCITS qualifiers.

Question 13

[1012326] A trust that is governed by the Trustee Act 2000 is forbidden to do which of the following?
I
Invest 10% in UK equity
II
Invest 10% in property
III
Invest 60% in fixed income stocks
IV
Invest 75% in authorised unit trusts
A
I only
B
I and II
C
I, II and III
D
None of the above
The correct answer is: D - None of the above

Explanation

Under the Act, direct investment in real estate is now permitted.

Question 14

[1012330] Which of the following is true of dealing commission?
I
It must be disclosed to the client
II
There must be no price disadvantage to the client
III
The firm must disclose the arrangements periodically
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
I, II, and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II, and III

Explanation

Examples of acceptable dealing commission include services improving the firm's investment management decisions through research. Periodic disclosure of the arrangements need to be made.

Question 15

[1012333] Which of the following are specified investments under FSMA 2000?
I
UK corporate equities
II
Stock Market Index bets
III
Commodities
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II only
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: B - I and II

Explanation

Stock market index bets (also known as 'contracts for differences' or CFDs) are covered under the legislation. TANGIBLE ASSETS (i.e. commodities) are not.

Question 16

[1012339] Which of the following regulates pension funds?
A
Trustee Act 2000
B
Pensions Act 2004
C
Companies Act 2006
D
Financial Services and Markets Act 2000
The correct answer is: B - Pensions Act 2004

Explanation

The Pensions Act 2004 introduced the requirement of the Scheme Specific Funding Requirement.

Question 17

[1012340] In the event of an unfair takeover, which of the following courses of action is/are open to the Takeover Panel?
I
Rescind the takeover
II
Fine the predator company
III
Issue a public censure
A
I, II and III
B
II and III
C
III only
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - III only

Explanation
