Question 45

[1015318] Company A has profits chargeable to corporation tax of 8m, and has paid cash dividends of 3m. What is its corporation tax liability?
A
1,920,000
B
1,680,000
C
1,600,000
D
780,000
The correct answer is: B - 1,680,000

Explanation

Corporation tax = 8m x 0.21 = 1.68m. NB: Dividends are paid out of post-tax profits.

Question 46

[1018133] Which of the following would NOT automatically be considered as 'durable medium' under the FCA's definition?
A
Paper
B
DVD
C
Personal computer
D
Websites
The correct answer is: D - Websites

Explanation

Websites are not automatically considered a durable medium. A firm can only claim this is so if certain criteria are met. The hard drive of a personal computer, however, is contained under the definition.

Question 47

[1018140] Any firm providing execution services for a client must produce an order execution policy. Which of the follow is not TRUE with regard to a firm's order execution policy?
A
It must contain an account of the relative importance the firm assigns to execution factors
B
It must contain a list of the main execution venues used by the firm
C
It must be assessed by a third party firm before being shown to clients
D
It must be reviewed annually and regularly monitored for its effectiveness
The correct answer is: C - It must be assessed by a third party firm before being shown to clients

Explanation

There is no requirement for a third party firm to assess the policy. However, a firm must receive prior consent to this policy from its clients.

Question 48

[1024417] Eckhardt is heavily invested in UK equity and now wishes to extend his investment portfolio to include overseas equity. What new risk is he exposing himself to?
A
Liquidity
B
Capital
C
Currency
D
Income
The correct answer is: C - Currency

Explanation

Eckhardt was already exposing himself to liquidity, capital and income risks, but by investing overseas he will be using other currencies and exposing himself to the risk of movements in foreign exchange rates.

Question 49

[1024423] Which of the following is LEAST likely to be considered a UK resident?
A
Someone who was non-UK resident in all of the previous three tax years and visits the UK for 45 days during this tax year
B
Someone who was UK resident in the previous tax year and visits the UK for only 16 days during this tax year
C
Someone who is resident for no more than 184 days during this tax year
D
Someone who has their only home in the UK but only uses it for 100 days each tax year
The correct answer is: A - Someone who was non-UK resident in all of the previous three tax years and visits the UK for 45 days during this tax year

Explanation

A person is non-resident if any of the following conditions are met: They visit the UK for fewer than 16 days during the tax year; or They are non-UK resident in all of the previous three tax years and visit the UK for fewer than 46 days during the tax year; or They work full-time overseas and visit the UK for fewer than 91 days during the tax year. A person is resident if Part A does not apply and any of the following conditions are met: They are present in the UK for 183 days or more during the tax year; or They have their only home in the UK, This must be for a period of at least 91 days and they must live there for at least 30 days; or They carry out full-time work in the UK.

Question 50

[1024430] Capital gain is realised within the unit trust fund, at the same time an investor sells his units back to the fund, realising his capital gain on the unit. What is the tax situation of the investor and the fund?
A
The investor does not need to pay CGT on the unit as the fund pays CGT on the realisation of any gains
B
The investor may need to pay CGT on the unit but the fund is exempt from paying tax on capital gains
C
A unit trust and the units in that trust are exempt from tax on capital gains
D
HMRC will collect tax on the capital gain made by both the investor and the unit trust
The correct answer is: B - The investor may need to pay CGT on the unit but the fund is exempt from paying tax on capital gains

Explanation

Unit trusts (OEICs and ETFs) do not pay tax on capital gains. Investors may, however have to pay capital gains tax (CGT) on any realised gains they make. Remember, paying CGT on gains made will not be necessary if the investors' gains are below their annual exemption.

Question 51

[1025387] If a member firm registers to be a market maker on the LSE, which of the following would be true?
I
They would have access to IDBs
II
They are able to indicate prices at which they could deal
III
They can decide when they wish to quote
A
I only
B
I, II and III
C
I and II
D
None of the above
The correct answer is: A - I only

Explanation

During the Mandatory Quote Period (8.00am - 4.30pm) the standard requirement is for the quotation of "Firm" prices upon which market makers MUST deal. There are, of course, exceptions to this rule during, say, fast markets when "Indicative" prices may be shown. Inter-Dealer Brokers are used by market makers.

Question 52

[1032467] One of the discretionary accounts managed by Bill Farnsworth, CFA, is the Jones Corporation employees' profit sharing plan. Diane Jones, the company president, recently asked Farnsworth to vote the shares in the firm's profit sharing plan in favour of the company nominated slate of directors and against the directors sponsored by a dissident stockholder group. Farnsworth does not want to lose this client, because he directs all the client's trades to a brokerage firm that provides Farnsworth with useful information about tax-free investments. This information is not of value in managing the Jones Corporation account but it does help in managing several other accounts. The brokerage firm providing this information also offers the lowest prices for trades. Farnsworth investigates the proxy fight issue, concludes that management's slate of directors is better for the long run performance of the firm than those recommended by the dissident group, and votes accordingly. Farnsworth:
A
Violated the Standards in voting the shares in the manner requested by Jones, but not in directing trades to the brokerage firm.
B
Did not violate the Standards in voting the shares in the manner requested by Jones or in directing trades to the brokerage firm.
C
Violated the Standards in directing trades to the brokerage firm, but not in voting the shares as requested by Jones.
D
Violated the Standards in voting the shares in the manner requested by Jones, and in directing trades to the brokerage firm.
The correct answer is: B - Did not violate the Standards in voting the shares in the manner requested by Jones or in directing trades to the brokerage firm.

Explanation

Choice "b" is correct. Since Farnsworth's vote in favour of the company's slate of directors was based upon his own analysis of the issues and not on Jones' request, the CFA Institute Standards were not violated. Also, directing trades to the lowest priced broker does not violate the CFA Institute Standards. Choice "a" is incorrect. Farnsworth did not violate the Standards in voting the shares. Choice "c" is incorrect. Farnsworth did not violate the Standards in directing the trades to the brokerage firm.

Question 53

[1036872] What is the purpose behind a firm maintaining adequate records of collateral?
A
To enable the return of identical assets when a client fulfils their obligations
B
To enable the return of equivalent assets when a client fulfils their obligations
C
To enable the return of identical assets when a client fails to fulfil their obligations
D
To enable the return of equivalent assets when a client fails to fulfil their obligations
The correct answer is: B - To enable the return of equivalent assets when a client fulfils their obligations

Explanation

A firm only has to return equivalent, not identical assets.

Question 54

[1039353] Which of the following is TRUE of the statutory notices issued by the RDC?
A
A decision notice may suggest actions that differ from the warning notices
B
There is no right to appeal against a supervisory notice
C
There is no right to appeal a further decision notice
D
A supervisory notice will lead directly to disciplinary action
The correct answer is: A - A decision notice may suggest actions that differ from the warning notices

Explanation

A decision notice, issued after the firm has referred the warning notice to the RDC, may contain different information to that suggested in the warning notice due to the new information provided by the firm in the referral. A firm can appeal both a supervisory and further decision notice. Supervisory notices are supportive and only warning and decision notices lead to discipline.

Question 55

[1039427] Which of the following BEST highlights a problem with order-driven markets?
A
No guarantee of execution
B
Lack of price transparency
C
Need for market maker quotes
D
Only works for large orders
The correct answer is: A - No guarantee of execution

Explanation

The problem with order-driven markets is highlighted when there is not adequate liquidity in the markets. If there is an insufficient number of buyers and sellers the trades may not be matched.

Question 56

[1040171] After establishing the personal details of an investor, what is the first thing you should do before recommending any investment products?
A
Establish current income and expenditure
B
Explain the technical jargon related to the investment products
C
Explain the general state of the economy
D
Determine the financial situation of the investor
The correct answer is: D - Determine the financial situation of the investor

Explanation

This is the best answer. Establishing the investor's current financial situation gives the financial advisor a basis on which to move forward. This would look at their current investments and their current liabilities - such as mortgages, overdrafts and credit cards. After this, the advisor is likely to look at the income and expenditure of the client.

Question 57

[1044626] Which of the following are benefits of a qualifying endowment life assurance bond over investing directly in unit trusts?
I
Guaranteed minimum sum paid on death
II
Proceeds are tax free
III
Can always be sold at the current realisable price
IV
No commission costs
A
I and II
B
I and IV
C
II and III
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and II

Explanation

Endowment policies have a basic sum assured that will be paid tax-free on the earlier of death of the policyholder or maturity of the bond. Terminating a life policy early will lead to a surrender value below the prices the policy is linked to.

Question 58

[1045986] In the event that a firm breaches the general prohibition, which of the following is TRUE?
A
All of the firm's contracts are void
B
Any agreements with the firm are unenforceable against the client
C
Contracts are voidable at the discretion of the court
D
Contracts are voidable at the discretion of the FCA
The correct answer is: B - Any agreements with the firm are unenforceable against the client

Explanation

In essence contracts are voidable at the discretion of the client.

Question 59

[1046672] When considering whether an individual is fit and proper for the approval process, the FCA will consider many aspects. Honesty, integrity and reputation may cause the individual to fail. What is the scope of the test?
A
The company for which approval is being sought
B
Any financial company within the jurisdiction of the UK
C
Any company within the jurisdiction within the EEA
D
Any company, any jurisdiction
The correct answer is: D - Any company, any jurisdiction

Explanation

The FCA will take into consideration information from any company in any jurisdiction in relation to its impact on the company for which approval is being sought.

Question 60

[1046683] Firm XYZ is an authorised person in the UK and communicates a promotion from Firm JKL, an authorised overseas person. Which of the following is TRUE?
A
There would be no compensation cover
B
As the promotion is being relayed through a UK firm the compensation scheme is available
C
The extent to which the compensation will or will not be available must be stated
D
The compensation cover follows home state rules
The correct answer is: C - The extent to which the compensation will or will not be available must be stated

Explanation

Where a firm communicates or approves a financial promotion on behalf of an overseas person, the financial promotion must make clear which firm has communicated or approved it and (where relevant) must explain: - That the conduct of business rules for the protection of retail clients do not apply; - The extent to which the compensation scheme will be available (or, if not, a statement of that fact).

Question 61

[1046715] According to corporate governance requirements for a listed company, a company must:
A
Disclose price sensitive information
B
Ensure that management responsibilities are shared within a firm
C
Have a trading record of three years
D
Produce quarterly accounts
The correct answer is: B - Ensure that management responsibilities are shared within a firm

Explanation

Corporate governance - ensures that the directors are responsible and accountable for the running of the firm. It also ensures that the responsibilities are shared and that too much influence is not placed with one person. Reporting (ensuring that all shareholders are given an equal opportunity to access price-sensitive information) is a continuing obligation, but not covered by corporate governance.

Question 62

[1047427] Which of the following would require disclosure under the notifiable interest requirement?
A
An individual acquiring shares to take their stake to 2.8%
B
An individual acquiring 0.5% to add to an existing holding of 2.9%
C
A market maker acquiring 0.5% to add to an existing stake of 4.9%
D
A custodian acquiring 0.5% to add to an existing stake of 5.7%
The correct answer is: B - An individual acquiring 0.5% to add to an existing holding of 2.9%

Explanation

The requirement to disclose shareholdings starts at the 3% level under UK law. Non-beneficial holdings (e.g. market makers) start at 10% and custodians are exempt from these requirements.

Question 63

[1047430] The best description of an inter-dealer broker would be:
A
Acts as agent between dealers
B
Quotes prices to market makers
C
Facilitates stock lending
D
Provides a range of services to hedge fund clients
The correct answer is: A - Acts as agent between dealers

Explanation

Whilst effectively they act as agent they actually settle trades as if they were principals to preserve anonymity.

Question 64

[1047433] Which of the following is a benefit of the LSE CCP service?
A
Flexible settlement timing
B
Negotiation on deliverable assets
C
Counterparty disclosure
D
Settlement netting
The correct answer is: D - Settlement netting

Explanation

Multiple fills on an order book will settle as one transaction with the central counterparty (CCP). This is referred to as settlement netting.

Question 65

[1047486] An investor is looking for long-term capital growth. You recommend:
A
Debentures
B
Gilts
C
Preference shares
D
Ordinary shares
The correct answer is: D - Ordinary shares

Explanation

Ordinary shares would fulfil the objective of long-term capital growth. A debenture is a secured bond. Bonds and preference shares are more likely to be used where there is a requirement for income.

Question 66

[1047494] Who sets the rules for members of the LSE governing their trading?
A
Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
B
London Stock Exchange (LSE)
C
UK Listing Authority (UKLA)
D
Takeover Panel (TP)
The correct answer is: B - London Stock Exchange (LSE)

Explanation

The LSE sets the rules for its member firms.

Question 67

[1047510] Which of the following would not be able to take advantage of the FSCS?
A
An individual who has money held in a cash deposit account wrapped in an Individual Savings Account
B
An authorised collective investment scheme investing in designated investments
C
A retail client dealing through an authorised intermediary
D
A small company with a qualifying insurance contract
The correct answer is: B - An authorised collective investment scheme investing in designated investments

Explanation

Authorised firms cannot claim from the FSCS. An authorised intermediary would be a broker for example.

Question 68

[1047516] Which of the following is a provision of the Money Laundering Regulations?
A
Employees should report all suspicions to the National Crime Agency
B
There is no need to identify new business
C
The regulations are considered guidance and are not legally binding
D
Training must be given to employees in relation to money laundering prevention
The correct answer is: D - Training must be given to employees in relation to money laundering prevention

Explanation

Employees report to the MLRO. There is a need to identify new business or customers. The regulations are a legal obligation.

Question 69

[1047693] Thomas works at a small bank. Over the last few months he has been accepting deposits from an individual who visits the UK regularly. This is most likely to be which stage in the process of money laundering?
A
Placement
B
Layering
C
Scheme
D
Integration
The correct answer is: A - Placement

Explanation

Accepting deposits is most likely to be the introduction of money into the financial system, which is part of the placement stage. The other two stages are layering and integration. Scheme is a made-up answer.

Question 70

[1049597] Anton and Jane are divorcees. Anton is a basic rate taxpayer and Jane is a higher rate taxpayer. They have no children. They jointly own a property worth 500,000 split equally and included in their individual estates. Anton's estate is valued at 650,000 while Jane's estate is valued at 900,000. They have recently witnessed an unmarried couple's ordeal concerning inheritance tax and therefore have decided to get married in order to lower their inheritance tax (IHT) liability. Assume the marriage takes place and the nil-rate band for IHT stays constant at 325,000. If Anton were to die and gift his estate to Jane, what would be the inheritance tax liability on Anton's estate?
A
0
B
130,000
C
325,000
D
650,000
The correct answer is: A - 0

Explanation

Gifts between spouses are totally exempt from IHT.

Question 71

[1049603] Anton and Jane are divorcees. Anton is a basic rate taxpayer and Jane is a higher rate taxpayer. They have no children. They jointly own a property worth 500,000 split equally and included in their individual estates. Anton's estate is valued at 650,000 while Jane's estate is valued at 900,000. They have recently witnessed an unmarried couple's ordeal concerning inheritance tax and therefore have decided to get married in order to lower their inheritance tax (IHT) liability. Assume the marriage takes place and the nil-rate band for IHT stays constant at 325,000. If both Anton were to die, followed by Jane soon after, what would be the amount of inheritance tax due on Jane's estate?
A
0
B
230,000
C
360,000
D
490,000
The correct answer is: C - 360,000

Explanation

We can only assume that Anton's estate was passed on to Jane, giving a total value of assets at 1,550,000. However, Anton's nil-rate band would also be passed on to Jane, giving Jane a nil-rate band of 650,000. Assets liable to IHT, therefore, would total: 1,550,000 - 650,000 = 900,000 The IHT due on the estate, therefore, would be: 900,000 x 40% = 360,000

Question 72

[1049604] Anton and Jane are divorcees. Anton is a basic rate taxpayer and Jane is a higher rate taxpayer. They have no children. They jointly own a property worth 500,000 split equally and included in their individual estates. Anton's estate is valued at 650,000 while Jane's estate is valued at 900,000. They have recently witnessed an unmarried couple's ordeal concerning inheritance tax and therefore have decided to get married in order to lower their inheritance tax (IHT) liability. Assume the marriage takes place and the nil-rate band for IHT stays constant at 325,000. If Jane was to transfer during her lifetime 50,000 worth of shares into a trust for the benefit of Anton, what kind of transfer would that be?
A
Potentially exempt transfer
B
Chargeable lifetime transfer
C
Exempt
D
Gift transfer
The correct answer is: C - Exempt

Explanation

A total of 325,000 can be transferred under the nil rate band exemption. Any subsequent transfer would be subject to the relevant tax charge.

Question 73

[1049605] Anton and Jane are divorcees. Anton is a basic rate taxpayer and Jane is a higher rate taxpayer. They have no children. They jointly own a property worth 500,000 split equally and included in their individual estates. Anton's estate is valued at 650,000 while Jane's estate is valued at 900,000. They have recently witnessed an unmarried couple's ordeal concerning inheritance tax and therefore have decided to get married in order to lower their inheritance tax (IHT) liability. Assume the marriage takes place and the nil-rate band for IHT stays constant at 325,000. If Jane was to transfer her 250,000 share in their house to Anton and still live in it, what kind of event would that be?
A
Potentially exempt transfer
B
Gift with reservation of benefit
C
Exempt
D
'Bed and Spouse'
The correct answer is: C - Exempt

Explanation

Gifts and transfers between spouses are exempt from IHT. However, had the gift been made to another person under the same conditions, it would have been a gift with reservation of benefit.

Question 74

[1049606] Anton and Jane are divorcees. Anton is a basic rate taxpayer and Jane is a higher rate taxpayer. They have no children. They jointly own a property worth 500,000 split equally and included in their individual estates. Anton's estate is valued at 650,000 while Jane's estate is valued at 900,000. They have recently witnessed an unmarried couple's ordeal concerning inheritance tax and therefore have decided to get married in order to lower their inheritance tax (IHT) liability. Assume the marriage takes place and the nil-rate band for IHT stays constant at 325,000. As Jane is a higher rate taxpayer, which rate of tax would she be expected to pay on any capital gains she would realise on her share portfolio?
A
10%
B
18%
C
22.5%
D
28%
The correct answer is: D - 28%

Explanation

The capital gains tax rate for higher rate taxpayers is 28%.

Question 75

[1049643] A firm operating a share offer should do which of the following according to the UK Listing Authority's rules?
I
Have a prospectus approved by UKLA
II
Have a prospectus approved by LSE
III
Publish a prospectus
IV
Apply for passport for part 4A permission
A
I and III only
B
II and III only
C
I, III and IV only
D
I and IV only
The correct answer is: A - I and III only

Explanation

Under the listing rules, no securities may be admitted to listing unless the UK Listing Authority has approved either listing particulars or a prospectus and that these documents have been published. In general, a prospectus is required whenever an application for listing is made and the securities are to be offered to the public prior to admission to listing.

Question 76

[1051080] An investor has the following spread of assets in his portfolio: Which of the following would best benefit the investor?
A
Increase in interest rates
B
Decrease in interest rates
C
Increase in inflation
D
Decrease in inflation
The correct answer is: B - Decrease in interest rates

Explanation

A decrease in interest rates would improve the ability to borrow. This would increase the demand for property, sending prices higher, and improve conditions in which companies could expand, increasing share prices. A drop in interest rates would also increase the prices of bonds.

Question 77

[1051081] You have collected the following information from a client: Based on the information given only, how would assess this portfolio?
A
The investor is exposed to too much risk
B
The investor has the balance about right
C
The investor should place more weight in CFDs
D
The investor should place more weight in AIM shares
The correct answer is: A - The investor is exposed to too much risk

Explanation

Despite the ageing population in the UK - the client is likely to have a good many years ahead of them - They are approaching the official retirement age. For this reason, they should be seeking a greater proportion of income-related investments in order to meet the ongoing costs of young children.

Question 78

[1051086] When considering the following investments, which is true?
I
25,000 in an exchange-traded fund
II
38,000 in an investment trust company
III
18,000 in an authorised unit trust
A
Purchases in I and II only would incur stamp duty
B
Investment II only has a fixed capital structure
C
Real-time pricing can be observed in investments I and III
D
The managers of the investment vehicles offering II and III can issue more shares if demand requires
The correct answer is: B - Investment II only has a fixed capital structure

Explanation

Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and unit trusts are open-ended, so if demand requires, more shares/units can be issued. An investment trust company (ITC) is closed-ended (has a fixed capital structure). Only the ITC would incur stamp duty. The ITC and the ETF offer real-time pricing. The unit trust is typically priced on a forward-basis at a particular valuation point.

Question 79

[1054044] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific trades of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. To open their French branches Brokerbiz is most likely to:
A
Apply to the FCA to passport.
B
Apply to the French regulator to passport.
C
Set up an independent subsidiary in France and apply to the French regulator for authorisation.
D
They can already trade in the EEA because they are a MiFID firm.
The correct answer is: A - Apply to the FCA to passport.

Explanation

By applying to the FCA, Brokerbiz would be able to set up French branches and provide MiFID and ancillary services.

Question 80

[1054046] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific trades of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. The statements of principle that apply to Esra cover which of the following topics?
I
Participating in required training.
II
Ensuring the company is well organised.
III
Making sure the firm complies with regulations.
IV
Being honest when dealing with clients
A
I
B
I, II, III, IV
C
I, IV
D
II, III
The correct answer is: C - I, IV

Explanation

Whilst Esra is the manager of a small team, this would not be considered a significant management function; therefore, only four of the seven statements of principle would be applicable.

Question 81

[1054047] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific trades of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. Before sending out the promotion Esra must:
A
Have the promotion approved by an authorised firm.
B
Ensure the promotion is fair, clear and not misleading.
C
Check that the mailing list is up-to-date.
D
Ensure that those on the list are exempt from Section 21.
The correct answer is: B - Ensure the promotion is fair, clear and not misleading.

Explanation

Whilst C may be advisable from a marketing point of view, there is no legal obligation. Since Esra works at an authorised firm, neither A nor D is required.

Question 82

[1054048] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific trades of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. The complaint will most likely be:
A
Passed back to the firm, as they have not entered into voluntary jurisdiction.
B
Dismissed by the Ombudsman.
C
Paid by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
D
Investigated by the FCA.
The correct answer is: B - Dismissed by the Ombudsman.

Explanation

Due to the nature of the firm, the case would come under compulsory jurisdiction under the FOS. Whilst the client is not happy about being on the mailing, list it is difficult to say that they have faced loss or material inconvenience or distress. The FSCS deals with compensation when a firm has gone into liquidation. There does not appear to be any evidence of breaking of the principles for the FCA to investigate.

Question 83

[1054049] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific trades of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. How will Esra's organisation be classified for her team's trades?
A
Retail client
B
Professional client
C
Eligible counterparty
D
Either as a professional client or eligible counterparty, depending on the type of trade
The correct answer is: C - Eligible counterparty

Explanation

As an authorised firm, the organisation will be treated as a per se eligible counterparty for dealing and broking.

Question 84

[1054051] Esra has worked for Brokerbiz for five years and been in her current role for two years. Brokerbiz is a large multinational equities dealer/broker with a wealth of clients. Esra has a wide knowledge of a variety of financial instruments gained from the multitude of qualifications that she has completed. She has been an approved person since she started at Brokerbiz and currently manages a small equity trading team consisting of three people which specialises in OTC contracts. Brokerbiz has recently assessed the market in France and believes that there are significant profits to be made by setting up international branches. In an attempt to increase their UK market share prior to any venture into new areas, Brokerbiz has decided to send a financial promotion to potential clients and have asked Esra to aid with production of the literature. Whilst gathering information for the promotion, Esra received a memo detailing the specific orders of all the major clients of the firm. Esra felt this information was very beneficial in terms of her trading activities and used the data to inform this. After the promotion was sent out, one of the recipients objected to having their name on the mailing list. The firm apologised and removed her name from the list. This was explained to the client in the final response which was sent out 55 days after the complaint was received. However, the client has written to the Financial Ombudsman, requesting financial compensation. The FCA have looked into Esra's dealings. What is the most likely course of action?
A
No action, as the information was available to a number of people.
B
Launch a prosecution for insider dealing under the Criminal Justice Act.
C
Charge her with market abuse.
D
Investigate the company for insider dealing.
The correct answer is: C - Charge her with market abuse.

Explanation

Whilst a number of people knew about the deal, it was not publicly available information. Only trades that take place on exchange or via a professional intermediary are covered by the Criminal Justice Act, which means that the most likely action will be to charge her with insider dealing under market abuse legislation. Whilst individuals within an organisation can be prosecuted for insider dealing, the organisation cannot be prosecuted as a whole.

Question 85

[1066756] Investment brokers would be classified as:-
A
Eligible Counterparties
B
Elective Professional Clients
C
Retail Clients
D
Eligible Clients
The correct answer is: A - Eligible Counterparties

Explanation

As an authorised firm an investment broker would be classified as a per se professional client and as an eligible counterparty for eligible counterparty business.

Practice Mock Exam

Question 1

[1012256] All of the following are covered by the insider dealing legislation except:
A
Futures
B
OTC traded interest rate and currency derivatives
C
Depository receipts
D
Warrants
The correct answer is: B - OTC traded interest rate and currency derivatives

Explanation

The insider dealing legislation relates specifically to abuses of information in respect of securities markets. This therefore includes instruments based on securities, such as stock index futures, share warrants and equity options. It does not relate to OTC markets, such as foreign exchange forward contracts. Additionally, the legislation does not cover assets with no secondary market, such as unit trusts.

Question 2

[1000386] Which of the following could be a reason for the FCA to not publish a final notice?
A
If the person is an approved person and would consequently find future employment difficult to obtain
B
If publishing would be prejudicial to the interests of consumers
C
More than 60 days has elapsed since the start of the investigation
D
If publication will lead to confidence in the firm being damaged
The correct answer is: B - If publishing would be prejudicial to the interests of consumers

Explanation

The FCA may not publish information relating to a final notice, supervisory notice that has taken effect or notice of discontinuance if publication would, in the FCA's opinion, be unfair to the person with respect to whom the action was taken or prejudicial to the interests of clients.

Question 3

[1000460] A director of a company has recently informed a friend about a pending takeover of the company, telling them that since this information is not public, they can make a quick profit by buying the company's shares. The friend declines to trade on this information. Who has committed an offence under insider dealing legislation?
A
The director
B
The friend
C
Both
D
No one
The correct answer is: A - The director

Explanation

The friend did not trade on the information. Assuming that she/he did not pass on this information further, she did not commit a crime. The director committed a crime by disclosing insider information, and encouraging someone to deal on that information.

Question 4

[1001237] Which of the following roles does CREST assume with regards to stamp duty reserve tax?
A
Collecting agent
B
Receiving agent
C
Paying agent
D
Issuing agent
The correct answer is: A - Collecting agent

Explanation

CREST calculates and collects SDRT and Irish stamp duty.

Question 5

[1012269] How does an individual attain threshold competence?
I
Passing an appropriate examination
II
Passing an internal assessment
III
Working unsupervised for six months
IV
Obtain sponsorship from an approved person
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
I, II and III
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and II

Explanation

Threshold competency is attained by passing examinations followed by an internal assessment.

Question 6

[1012272] In a comparison between UK pension fund investments and those of France and Germany which of the following is true?
A
UK pension funds hold less equities than their French and German counterparts
B
UK pension funds typically hold less fixed income than French and German pension funds
C
UK pension funds have less assets under management than French or German pension funds
D
The investment characteristics of French and German pension funds are very similar to UK pension funds
The correct answer is: B - UK pension funds typically hold less fixed income than French and German pension funds

Explanation

UK pension funds have under management six times that of German pension funds and twelve times that of French pension funds. The figure for UK pension fund investment in bonds is only 4% compared to 75% in Germany.

Question 7

[1012275] Which of the following satisfy the FCA's definition of a retail investment product?
I
Units in a regulated unit trust
II
Life policies
III
Investment trust savings schemes
A
II and III
B
I and III
C
I and II
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

Life policies, regulated unit trusts, investment trust savings schemes and personal pension plans are all defined as retail investment products.

Question 8

[1012279] An investor buys 10,000 worth of shares on the London Stock Exchange and sells them later the same day. Which of the following organisations would benefit from the direct charges levied on these transactions?
I
Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs
II
The Financial Conduct Authority
III
The Takeover Panel
IV
The Tax and Chancery Chamber of the Upper Tribunal
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I and III
C
II and IV
D
I only
The correct answer is: B - I and III

Explanation

Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs will receive stamp duty whilst the Takeover Panel will receive a levy of 1 on deals with a consideration of 10,000 or more.

Question 9

[1012301] The Scheme Specific Funding Requirement, introduced by the Pensions Act 2004, relates to which of the following pension schemes?
A
Certain occupational defined benefit schemes
B
Certain occupational money purchase schemes
C
Private pension schemes
D
SERPS
The correct answer is: A - Certain occupational defined benefit schemes

Explanation

The minimum funding requirement only applies to defined benefit pension schemes to ensure they remain adequately funded.

Question 10

[1012309] Churning is a violation of which of the following principles for businesses?
A
Financial prudence
B
Market conduct
C
Customers' interest
D
Skill, care and diligence
The correct answer is: C - Customers' interest

Explanation

Acting in the customers' interests is principle for business number six.

Question 11

[1012316] CREST is:
I
A trading system
II
A settlement system
III
A custodian
IV
A CSD
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
II, III and IV
D
I, II and IV
The correct answer is: C - II, III and IV

Explanation

A CSD is a Central Securities Depositary, which refers to any institution that provides custodial services. CREST is also a RCH (Recognised Clearing House) and provides settlement on a delivery versus payment system.

Question 12

[1012404] The minimum expected market capitalisation of an applicant for listing on the London Stock Exchange is:
A
300k
B
700k
C
5m
D
10m
The correct answer is: B - 700k

Explanation

Per the UK Listing Authority (UKLA) Listing Rules, the minimum market capitalisation for equities is 700k (200k for debt securities).

Question 13

[1012407] If the shareholders reject the dividend proposed by the directors at the AGM, which of the following would apply?
A
No dividend is paid to the shareholders
B
An alternative dividend is proposed
C
The dividend is paid in shares
D
The dividend is deferred until the following year
The correct answer is: B - An alternative dividend is proposed

Explanation

Directors propose dividends which must be approved by the shareholders.

Question 14

[1012412] Who regulates the Eurobond market?
A
Treasury
B
ICMA
C
LSE
D
FCA
The correct answer is: B - ICMA

Explanation

The Eurobond market is regulated by the International Markets and Securities Association, a Designated Investment Exchange.

Question 15

[1012413] Which of the following is/are TRUE of discretionary investment management?
I
Seeking client approval before buying and selling
II
Initiating transactions
III
Monitoring transactions to settlement
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
III only
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

In discretionary investment management, approval is not required for each transaction.

Question 16

[1012415] Which of the following is TRUE about LSE market makers?
A
Quote continuous bid and offer prices, but do not have to indicate a minimum number of shares they will trade
B
Quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares they will trade
C
Do not quote continuous bid and offer prices, but indicate a minimum number of shares they will trade
D
Do not quote continuous bid and offer prices, and do not have to indicate a maximum number of shares they will trade
The correct answer is: B - Quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares they will trade

Explanation

LSE market makers must quote continuous bid and offer prices, and indicate a maximum number of shares they will trade.

Question 17

[1012419] Which of the following is/are TRUE of authorised collective investment schemes?
I
They work on the principle of spreading risk by diversification
II
Units are available to the public
III
The price of units are based on the net asset value of the fund
IV
They usually only invest in transferable securities
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
I, II and III
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: D - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Authorised collective investment schemes comprise unit trusts and OEICs - both are valued at Net Asset Value. Remember, however, that investment trusts are valued according to supply and demand in the market.

Question 18

[1012420] What is an individual's personal allowance for CGT?
A
Nil
B
Totally dependent on their tax banding
C
5,300
D
11,000
The correct answer is: D - 11,000

Explanation

In the current financial year 14/15 the allowance on CGT is 11,000.

Question 19

[1012421] CREST is:
A
Computer based
B
Auction based
C
Order based
D
A trading system
The correct answer is: A - Computer based

Explanation

CREST is a computer based settlement system.

Question 20

[1012424] Under which of the following circumstances should a company listed on the London Stock Exchange publish a prospectus before securities are offered to the public?
I
When the shares are offered free of charge to existing shareholders
II
When the offer is made in connection with a take-over or merger
III
Where the firm makes a placing to 200 or more persons per EU state
A
II only
B
II and III
C
III only
D
I and II
The correct answer is: C - III only

Explanation

Prospectuses are generally required when the company issues new shares to the public. They are not required for scrip issues or in takeover situations, or for issues up to 150 persons per EU state.

Question 21

[1012425] Apart from the Competition and Markets Authority, who else decides whether or not a merger should go ahead?
A
The FCA
B
The Takeover Panel
C
The Department of Business Innovation and Skills
D
The Treasury
The correct answer is: C - The Department of Business Innovation and Skills

Explanation

The Business Secretary can intervene if the merger raises a matter of national security or involves a newspaper.

Question 22

[1012427] What type of service is best suited for a retail client who has already decided to sell her shares?
A
Advisory
B
Discretionary
C
Execution only
D
Portfolio management
The correct answer is: C - Execution only

Explanation

A retail client who has decided to sell shares will not require advice or investment management services.

Question 23

[1012430] Which of the following is not a defence under the insider dealing legislation?
A
An individual passed on information, but did not expect the recipient to deal
B
The deal was not done to make a profit or avoid a loss
C
A market maker had inside information in the course of his/her business, but acted bona fide for that business
D
Acting on inside information when the source is not known
The correct answer is: D - Acting on inside information when the source is not known

Explanation

The offence is committed if the person dealing knows that the information is 'insider' - however the precise source need not be known.

Question 24

[1012433] What is the most suitable risk warning stated on an advert for an income and growth unit trust?
A
You might lose more than you originally invested
B
The value of your units may go down as well as up
C
You must be a professional investor
D
Your home may be at risk if you do not keep up payments
The correct answer is: B - The value of your units may go down as well as up

Explanation

The answer in A would be most suitable for adverts relating to contingent liability transactions, e.g. futures.

Question 25

[1012435] The UK Code on Corporate Governance recommends that boards of directors should evaluate their own performance every:
A
Month
B
Two years
C
Year
D
Six months
The correct answer is: C - Year

Explanation

The combined code contains a number of principles of good governance relating to directors and institutional investors.

Question 26

[1012437] Which of the following investment services is/are exempt from the client agreement rules?
I
Transactions with authorised persons
II
Acting as the trustee of a unit trust scheme
III
The supply of published recommendations
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

If an FCA authorised firm provides services, or does transactions with an authorised person, provides services to the trustee of a unit trust for whom it is the investment manager or supplies published recommendations, the client agreement rules do not apply.

Question 27

[1012439] Which of the following is true regarding London Stock Exchange member firms?
A
They must quote firm prices at which they will trade if they choose to act as principal
B
They are automatically considered to be market makers and therefore quote firm prices at which they will trade
C
They may choose to act as an agency broker for some deals and as a principal for others
D
They have to act either as an agency broker or principal but not both
The correct answer is: C - They may choose to act as an agency broker for some deals and as a principal for others

Explanation

London Stock Exchange member firms have dual capacity: every member may deal as a principal or agency broker. If a member firm wants to take principal trading a step further then they may, in certain stocks, register as a market maker. Market makers are obliged to quote firm two way prices.

Question 28

[1012442] Who was responsible for the Regulated Activities Order 2001?
A
The Treasury
B
The Consumer Credit Council
C
Joint Money Laundering Steering Group
D
The Securities and Exchange Commission (USA)
The correct answer is: A - The Treasury

Explanation

The Treasury was responsible for making the Regulated Activities Order 2001. This defines which investments and activities are regulated.

Question 29

[1012444] Which of the following are not regulated investments?
I
Contracts for difference used for risk management
II
Ancient pottery collections held in bonded warehouses
III
Shares in open-ended investment companies
IV
Rights under contracts of general insurance
A
I only
B
II only
C
I and II
D
II, III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I and II

Explanation

Contracts for difference (CFDs) are not classed as regulated investments if they are used for risk management. This also applies to options and futures used for risk management. Physical investments are also not included as regulated investments i.e. land, antiques and commodities.

Question 30

[1012446] Who needs to be aware of the complaints handling procedures?
A
An appointed director
B
The MLRO
C
The compliance officer
D
All staff
The correct answer is: D - All staff

Explanation

All staff of a firm need to be made aware of the firm's complaints handling procedures which must be in place and operated. They must be appropriate and effective, as well as being written down.

Question 31

[1012447] Which one of the following does not form part of the FCA high level standards (Block 1), within the FCA handbook:
A
Middle management
B
The Statement of Principles for businesses
C
The Code of Practice for approved persons
D
The fit and proper criteria for approved persons
The correct answer is: A - Middle management

Explanation

The FCA high level standards (Block 1) apply to senior management, not middle management.

Question 32

[1012448] The Treasury will mostly limit qualifying investments, in respect of market abuse, to those traded on:
A
All futures markets worldwide
B
All exchanges based in the European Economic Area
C
Only the London Stock Market
D
The six RIEs physically based in the UK
The correct answer is: D - The six RIEs physically based in the UK

Explanation

In practice the Treasury will limit qualifying investments to those traded on the six recognized investment exchanges (6 RIEs) physically based in the UK. However, developments such as the Internet could lead to UK markets being physically based anywhere.

Question 33

[1012449] Joan Smith has a governing function as she is a director of a small investment bank employing 40 approved persons. As she is also head of equity trading, does the FCA dictate another person be appointed and approved in order to perform the role head of equity trading?
A
No, as the bank is too small
B
Yes, as it is important to ensure the two roles are separate
C
Yes, as any investment business must fulfil these roles in order to comply with authorisation
D
Yes, as none of these roles are compulsory
The correct answer is: A - No, as the bank is too small

Explanation

No, as the bank is too small. Another level of management is not required as most people in governing functions are assumed to be carrying out a managerial role also. In larger institutions of more than 100 approved persons it would be necessary.

Question 34

[1013490] An investment strategy that is passive usually means:
A
The trustees do not usually evaluate the performance of the fund manager
B
The trustees take NO part in the management of the fund at any stage
C
The fund manager is trying to identify and acquire undervalued stocks
D
The fund manager is seeking to track a benchmark index having determined the preferred level of risk of the client
The correct answer is: D - The fund manager is seeking to track a benchmark index having determined the preferred level of risk of the client

Explanation

Passively managed funds are usually tracker or index funds. The fund manager is not trying to choose cheap stocks, but instead looking to mimic the performance of a particular index that reflects the required risk level of the customer.

Question 35

[1013879] A firm is approached by an authorised collective investment scheme (CIS) in relation to designated investment business. Which of the following best represents the conditions under which the CIS will get classified as a professional client?
A
Turnover of 40 million and own funds of 2 million
B
Turnover of 40 million and a balance sheet of 15 million
C
It is always classified as a professional client
D
It can never be classified as a professional client
The correct answer is: C - It is always classified as a professional client

Explanation

Authorised collective investment schemes are per se professional clients.

Question 36

[1013922] According to the COBS, the financial promotion rules always apply to a firm in relation to:
A
The communication of a financial promotion to a person outside the UK from outside the UK
B
The communication of a financial promotion to a person outside the UK from inside the UK
C
The communication of a financial promotion from the UK to a person inside the UK
D
The communication of a financial promotion to a person outside the UK for purposes of business which is carried on outside the UK
The correct answer is: C - The communication of a financial promotion from the UK to a person inside the UK

Explanation

Communication made from outside the UK to a person outside the UK are never covered by COBS. Communications from outside the UK to a person in the UK may be covered by home state rules - particularly with reference to ecommerce.

Question 37

[1013986] In relation to non-MiFID business, firms need only follow suitability criteria when dealing for:
A
All clients
B
Non-retail clients
C
Firms managing Occupational Pension Schemes
D
Professional clients
The correct answer is: C - Firms managing Occupational Pension Schemes

Explanation

Under the COBS suitability applies for non-MiFID business only when making personal recommendations to retail clients and firms managing occupational, stakeholder and personal pension schemes, shareholder pensions and stakeholder pensions schemes. If the question referred to MiFID business, the rule would apply to all customers.

Question 38

[1014061] All of the following are true regarding the rules on client money, except:
A
Interest earned on client money need not be paid to clients
B
Professional clients may opt out of client money protection providing they have given written consent and the firm has warned them of the risks of opting out of the rules
C
All client accounts must be reconciled on a daily basis
D
Money due to the firm to settle an account where the firm has dealt as principal with the client is not client money
The correct answer is: C - All client accounts must be reconciled on a daily basis

Explanation

The reconciliation is as often as necessary, which is not necessarily every day. NOTE: the interest earned on client money need not be paid to clients. The firm can keep any interest on the money - although they would need to notify a retail client that this is the case. Only if the firm chooses to pay the interest to client, will the interest will become client money.

Question 39

[1014239] Which of the following bodies sets out processes and documentation for the OTC derivatives markets?
A
International Capital Markets Association
B
International Accounting Standards Board
C
International Swaps and Derivatives Association
D
Financial Conduct Authority
The correct answer is: C - International Swaps and Derivatives Association

Explanation

ISDA set-out the processes and documentation required for the OTC derivatives markets.

Question 40

[1015315] A person who does not pay tax has 300 shares. The net dividend is 10p per share. What refund can be claimed?
A
75
B
6
C
7.50
D
nil
The correct answer is: D - nil

Explanation

The tax credit on dividends cannot be claimed back by non-taxpayers.

Question 41

[1015782] What is the best definition of clearing?
A
Recording and matching trades and maintaining positions
B
Ensure legal obligations resulting from a trade are met
C
Continuous trading activity throughout the trading day
D
Using derivatives that will be physically-delivered
The correct answer is: A - Recording and matching trades and maintaining positions

Explanation

This is a difficult question which is not particularly well worded. Technically speaking clearing and settlement are two separate processes. 'Ensure legal obligations resulting from a trade are met' best describes settlement and 'recording and matching trades and maintaining positions' is closer to the process of clearing, which describes what happens before settlement.

Question 42

[1016032] Tom discloses inside information to Harry, and reminds Harry not to deal based on that information, but Harry does anyway. Who should be charged with insider dealing?
A
Tom, not Harry
B
Harry, not Tom
C
Neither Tom nor Harry
D
Both Tom and Harry
The correct answer is: B - Harry, not Tom

Explanation

Harry would be guilty of insider dealing. He was fully aware of the nature of the information and dealt anyway. Tom, although disclosing the information, reminded Harry not to deal. He could therefore use either of the following defences: He could have passed on the information in the normal course of business, or he could use the defence that he did not expect the recipient to deal. Both of these defences would be consistent with reminding Harry not to deal.

Question 43

[1017640] Kelly Hilton, a 35 year-old mother of two, works part-time earning 5,000 pa. How much tax will Kelly pay?
A
832.40
B
532.40
C
225.00
D
Nil
The correct answer is: D - Nil

Explanation

Kelly will not pay any tax as her income is below the personal allowance limit of 10,000.

Question 44

[1017654] Louis Hamilton, a UK resident, has investments outside the UK that produce income. What tax may be deducted by a foreign country?
A
Income tax
B
Income tax and capital gains
C
Withholding tax
D
Inheritance tax
The correct answer is: C - Withholding tax

Explanation

Withholding tax is, literally, the tax withheld by the country in which the income is earned. Despite this, tax will be due in the country of residence for the investor too. Often there is a tax treaty between nations allowing investors to claim a relief on the lower of the two tax liabilities. Clearly, if withholding tax is greater than the tax in the country of residence, there will be no refund.

Question 45

[1017657] Which of the following transfers are exempt for inheritance tax purposes?
A
Transfer to a child
B
Transfer to a spouse/civil partner
C
Transfer to parent
D
Transfer to a family company
The correct answer is: B - Transfer to a spouse/civil partner

Explanation

Transfers to: Spouse/civil partner Certain charities Certain political parties are examples of those exempt from inheritance tax, as are certain lifetime transfers such as small gifts and gifts on marriage.

Question 46

[1018139] Where a firm becomes aware of a conflict of interest that may damage a particular client's interests, which of the following procedures must the firm follow?
A
Disclose relevant details in a durable medium to the client, allowing the client to decide
B
Disclose relevant details orally to the client, allowing the client to decide
C
Continue to deal regardless of the conflict, and the client was informed of potential conflicts in the conflicts of interest policy
D
Refuse to deal for the client, as the conflict cannot be managed
The correct answer is: A - Disclose relevant details in a durable medium to the client, allowing the client to decide

Explanation

The FCA rules state that a firm must disclose the relevant details to the client in a durable medium, and allow the client to decide how they should proceed. This disclosure must be a last resort, after all other methods used by the firm to manage conflicts have failed.

Question 47

[1024433] A middle aged investor with a maturing family now wishes to focus his investments on saving for his retirement whilst still providing protection for his family. He already invests in unit trusts and is a low risk investor. What would you think should be the focus of his investments?
A
With profits bonds
B
Income generating investments such as bonds
C
Investments offering capital growth such as property and equity
D
The ease with which he can switch between one product and another
The correct answer is: A - With profits bonds

Explanation

With profits bond offers a guaranteed capital return plus a share in any profits. It also has a life assured element, should the investor die during the term of the bond thus offering an element of protection for his family.

Question 48

[1024445] Which of the following would be a consequence of investing in a regulated scheme rather than an unregulated scheme?
A
Lower overall costs
B
Higher management fees
C
More market activity
D
Higher potential return
The correct answer is: A - Lower overall costs

Explanation

Unregulated funds tend to be more aggressive in the market causing more market activity, higher fees but a potentially higher return (or bigger loss!). Regulated funds have more restrictions placed upon them including how much they can charge. This tends to lower overall cost of investment, but also potentially give lower returns.

Question 49

[1024571] Diversification is a way to mitigate all of the following types of risk EXCEPT:
A
Management risk
B
Business risk
C
Industry risk
D
Interest rate risk
The correct answer is: D - Interest rate risk

Explanation

Diversification can help to mitigate (reduce) non-systematic or specific risks such as those shown in the other answer options by combining a number of assets that are not perfectly positively correlated. Interest rate risk, however, is a systematic risk and affect all areas of the market and cannot be mitigated through diversification.

Question 50

[1032469] David Brent, CFA, notices that a fellow employee called Gareth Keenan, CFA, has been making amendments to trade order records in an attempt to hide the unfair allocation process that he has used to allocate trades to clients. Gareth discriminates against certain clients and breaches the firm's allocation policy. David is unhappy about this practice and informs the firm's compliance officer regarding these activities. A few weeks after the notification to the compliance officer, David notices that Gareth is still altering the records. According to the Standards of Practice, David must:
A
Report the violation to the appropriate regulatory authority
B
Dissociate himself from the unethical activity
C
Confront Gareth Keenan, CFA
D
David has honoured the Standards of Practice and no further action is required
The correct answer is: B - Dissociate himself from the unethical activity

Explanation

Although confronting the individual may be a reasonable course of action it is not required under the Standards. If a member believes that the questionable behaviour is continuing, the member must dissociate from the activity. Although reporting to the appropriate regulatory authority seems a logical pathway, the Standards only encourage this rather than require it.

Question 51

[1032583] A client asks for advice and provides the following objectives to his financial advisor: to retire at 55 years of age, to provide protection to his family in the event of death and to repay his mortgage as quickly as possible. If the advisor believes meeting all of these objectives is not currently possible, which of the following is true?
A
Regulations state that the advisor needs to persuade the client to be more realistic
B
The FCA state that life insurance objectives must be met before pension requirements
C
In exercising the client's best interests rules, the advisor should recommend that the pension takes priority over other investment
D
Regulations do not dictate which objectives should take priority, it is down to investor choice
The correct answer is: D - Regulations do not dictate which objectives should take priority, it is down to investor choice

Explanation

If an investor cannot meet all of their objectives, which of them will take priority is a decision for the client to make.

Question 52

[1032584] Which of the following statements best defines the role of a Fact Find?
A
It must be completed by the client prior to meeting the advisor
B
It must be in writing and signed by both the advisor and the client
C
It must be attached to any recommendations
D
The nature and content of the Fact Find are not governed by regulations
The correct answer is: D - The nature and content of the Fact Find are not governed by regulations

Explanation

Although a useful tool, the fact find is not a regulatory requirement.

Question 53

[1039354] Which of the following BEST describes the protections offered to 'whistleblowers' as applied under the Public Interests Disclosure Act (PIDA)?
A
It outlines the obligations on relevant persons to disclose information that is of public interest
B
It protects persons from retaliation where they inform the regulatory authorities of concerns that might come to their attention at their place of work
C
It protects persons from retaliation where they inform the press of any concerns that might come to their attention at their place of work
D
It outlines the obligations on relevant persons to disclose suspicions regarding money laundering
The correct answer is: B - It protects persons from retaliation where they inform the regulatory authorities of concerns that might come to their attention at their place of work

Explanation

PIDA protects employees of the financial industry who reveal to a regulatory body that they have concerns over the way their company is organised and controlled. SYSC 18 reinforces the coverage of PIDA for financial services firms.

Question 54

[1039359] When executing a trade for a retail client, assuming no specific instructions were given, which of the following would ensure best execution?
A
Adherence to the order execution policy
B
Executing any outstanding firm order first
C
Placing the total consideration for the transaction as the most important factor
D
Executing away from a regulated market
The correct answer is: A - Adherence to the order execution policy

Explanation

The order execution policy sets out how a firm will achieve best execution. Therefore, if the firm adheres to this, they fulfil best execution. The reference to retail clients is irrelevant to the question, as this would also apply to professional clients.

Question 55

[1044215] Which of the following best describes corporate governance?
A
A mechanism to ensure the company is run in the best long term interests of the directors
B
A mechanism to ensure the company is run in the best short term interests of the shareholders
C
A mechanism to ensure the company is run in the best short term interests of the directors
D
A mechanism to ensure the company is run in the best long term interests of the shareholders
The correct answer is: D - A mechanism to ensure the company is run in the best long term interests of the shareholders

Explanation

Companies should have a long term view in the running of their business with a focus on the shareholders rather than the directors.

Question 56

[1044580] Which of the following is NOT a tax benefit of the Enterprise Investment Scheme (EIS)?
A
Income tax relief of up to 30% on shares held for over three years
B
Exempt from IHT if held for over two years
C
Exempt for CGT if held for over three years
D
Capital losses cannot be used to offset against income tax
The correct answer is: D - Capital losses cannot be used to offset against income tax

Explanation

Investors can offset losses against income for a tax year.

Question 57

[1044759] Which of the following statements most accurately describes the parties that GIPS are intended to apply to and serve? GIPS apply to:
A
Firms that issue securities and serve brokers.
B
Investment management firms and serve their existing clients only.
C
Investment management firms and serve their existing and prospective clients.
D
Governments issuing index-linked bonds to pension funds
The correct answer is: C - Investment management firms and serve their existing and prospective clients.

Explanation

Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) apply to investment management firms. They are intended to serve existing and prospective clients of investment firms.

Question 58

[1046011] A client asks for a copy of a trade confirmation for a trade that was carried out six years ago. Which would be a valid response to the client?
A
The firm is never required to provide copies of documentation
B
Records are only kept for five years from the date of dispatch
C
Records of trade confirmations are not kept by the firm
D
The client should contact the FCA for a copy
The correct answer is: B - Records are only kept for five years from the date of dispatch

Explanation

Records are only required to be kept for five years.

Question 59

[1046675] Once a warning notice has been issued, what would be issued next to inform the firm that the investigation is no longer proceeding?
A
Supervisory notice
B
Decision notice
C
Discontinuance notice
D
Further decision notice
The correct answer is: C - Discontinuance notice

Explanation

A notice of discontinuance is issued where proceedings set out in a warning notice or decision notice are being discontinued.

Question 60

[1047429] A disadvantage of an order-driven system over a quote-driven system would be:
A
Lack of transparency
B
No guarantee of execution
C
Anonymity
D
Wider spreads
The correct answer is: B - No guarantee of execution

Explanation

An order driven system relies on sufficient liquidity for orders between buyers and sellers to be matched. If there is insufficient liquidity an order may not trade. A quote-driven system is where a market maker provides a price to buy or sell the security. Therefore clients can always trade with a market maker - it might just be at an unfavourable price.

Question 61

[1047444] Diversification would reduce:
A
Market risk
B
Specific risk
C
Systematic risk
D
Systemic
The correct answer is: B - Specific risk

Explanation

All of the other refer to the same risk. Systematic risk or market risk refers to the risk of investing in shares rather than less risky products such as cash or bonds. Specific risk relates to the risk of investing in a specific company's. By holding a variety of shares we can remove the risk relating to an individual company. Systematic risk can only be reduced by not investing in shares.

Question 62

[1047475] SDRT:
A
Is collected by CREST
B
Is calculated by the investor
C
Is paid by the buyer directly to HMRC
D
Is paid on certificated transactions
The correct answer is: A - Is collected by CREST

Explanation

Stamp Duty and SDRT is a tax payable when certain shares are purchased. SDRT is paid on transactions that settle through CREST. CREST, calculates, collects and transfers SDRT to Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (i.e. the UK government tax authority).

Question 63

[1047697] In respect of financial promotions issued by appointed representatives, which of the following is responsible?
A
It is always the responsibility of the appointed representative
B
It is always the responsibility of the firm
C
It is the responsibility of both the appointed representative and the firm
D
It is the responsibility of the generator, not the firm
The correct answer is: B - It is always the responsibility of the firm

Explanation

This is a tricky question. The financial promotion is the responsibility of the firm. The generator refers to the person who creates the financial promotion, i.e. printer or advertising company.

Question 64

[1049940] The following transactions occur: Martin buys 5000 shares in a FTSE100 index company and the transaction settles through CREST. Hilary buys 1000 dematerialised shares in a small UK company. Fiona buys 10,000 nominal value gilts that settle through CREST Harold buys 1000 units in an FCA authorised unit trust With regard to stamp duty and stamp duty reserve tax (SDRT), which of the following are true?
A
Martin and Hilary pay SDRT
B
Harold and Martin pay SDRT and Hilary pays stamp duty
C
Martin and Fiona pay SDRT and Harold pays stamp duty
D
Martin, Fiona and Harold pay SDRT and Hilary pays stamp duty
The correct answer is: A - Martin and Hilary pay SDRT

Explanation

SDRT is payable on the purchase of dematerialised shares that settle through CREST, so Martin and Hilary would have to pay this. There is no stamp duty liability on the purchase of gilts or unit in a unit trust (although the unit trust itself will be paying SDRT on all of the purchases within the fund).

Question 65

[1049947] Despite being a higher rate taxpayer and enjoying many adrenaline-inducing sports, Trevor is a very cautious investor. He is attracted to the idea of equity investment, but has been told of the capital-at-risk element and worries about this. He is happy to lock his money into an investment for some time. What would you advise?
A
Investing in equity, particularly companies in the FTSE 100, are unlikely to expose his capital to risk. In fact, equity over the long-term will always rise.
B
Investing in a share in a FTSE 100 index-linked exchange-traded fund (ETF) will diversify away any capital risk and give exposure to equity.
C
Investing in guaranteed equity bond will allow benefits from an increase in FTSE 100 index share prices, and guarantees that at least the capital invested will be returned.
D
Investing in a FTSE 100 index future will give exposure to the FTSE 100 index share prices and, having no initial outlay, exposes the investor's capital to no risk.
The correct answer is: C - Investing in guaranteed equity bond will allow benefits from an increase in FTSE 100 index share prices, and guarantees that at least the capital invested will be returned.

Explanation

Our investor is very cautious, so equity is low on the list of appropriate investments. Although true that equity does generally increase over time, capital cannot be guaranteed even in a diversified investment such as an ETF. The guaranteed equity bond offered by national savings and investments, not only allows for exposure to gain on equity, but also protects the capital invested. Although, in its purest sense, there is no initial outlay on a future, there is significant capital at risk, and cash calls can be made on the investor above any initial outlay.

Question 66

[1049999] Emily invested 80,000 in an investment bond seven years ago and withdrew 2,000 in year one, 3000, in year two and 4,000 in year three. What sum could Emily withdraw in year four without triggering a chargeable event for income tax?
A
2,000
B
3,000
C
4,000
D
7,000
The correct answer is: D - 7,000

Explanation

Cumulative withdrawals of 5% of the original capital do not trigger chargeable events. 80,000 x 5% = 4,000 per year. After four years the cumulative total of potential withdrawals is 4,000 x four years = 16,000. Actual withdrawals have been 2k + 3k + 4k = 9k. This means Emily has the potential to withdraw 16,000 - 9,000 = 7k without triggering a chargeable event.

Question 67

[1051023] Which of the following transactions in sterling-denominated securities would be MOST LIKELY to attract stamp duty reserve tax?
A
The Red Cross buys convertible bonds
B
A hedge fund buys Eurobonds
