C
A trader at the market making department of an investment bank buys shares
D
A unit trust manager buys shares in dematerialised form
The correct answer is: D - A unit trust manager buys shares in dematerialised form

Explanation

Registered charities (such as the Red Cross) are exempt, as well as firms acting as intermediaries and providing liquidity, such as market makers. Eurobonds are exempt, as they are bearer securities. However, shares in dematerialised form are subject to SDRT.

Question 68

[1051076] If a firm is unable to disclose the exact costs payable by a client on providing a client agreement, what must the firm do?
A
Refuse to trade for the client
B
Disclose the basis on which the fee will be calculated
C
State that according to FCA regulations charges do not need to be disclosed
D
Disclose charges made to a similar client investing in a substantially similar investment
The correct answer is: B - Disclose the basis on which the fee will be calculated

Explanation

Where it is not possible to disclose exact fees and commission, the firm must disclose the basis on which these will be calculated.

Question 69

[1051121] Rosie and Jim are down-sizing their business. They have sold their office for 1m and are purchasing a lease on a retail premise for 140,000. The rate of stamp duty land tax payable would be:
A
Nil
B
1%
C
2%
D
3%
The correct answer is: A - Nil

Explanation

Purchases of non-residential leases of less than 150,000 attract 0% SDLT.

Question 70

[1051131] John, a higher rate taxpayer, has investments in two mutual funds. The related income from these funds is given below: Americas' balanced equity fund, dividend = 780. Ajax OEIC, debt focus, dividend = 140. What is the additional tax that John has to pay on these?
A
184
B
230
C
299
D
309.50
The correct answer is: B - 230

Explanation

A mutual fund that invests in debt would have its dividends treated as interest for purposes of tax. This would be the case with the Ajax OEIC. For the Americas' fund, we will calculate tax on its income as equity. Americas' fund dividend tax: 780 / 0.9 x 22.5% = 195. Ajax OEIC dividend tax = 140 / 0.8 x 20% = 35. Total tax = 230.

Question 71

[1052229] You work as a financial advisor for a firm that only offers fee-based advice. Horace, a new client, has recently sought your advice after becoming dissatisfied with his previous advisor, who offered commission based advice. He is concerned that he is now paying for what he once got for free. What do you say to assure him that fee-based advice is fairer?
I
Like all quality products, good advice costs money
II
The advice Horace received with the previous advisor was not free, but all the cost will be taken in exit charges
III
With fee-based advice, it is clear what is being paid for the advice and how much is being invested
IV
As the client is paying a fee, it will avoid product and provider bias in the advisor
A
I and III
B
II and III
C
I and IV
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: D - III and IV

Explanation

Fee-based advice provides more clarity to the investor on the cost of advice. With commission-based advice, this cost can be hidden to the client. There is no guarantee that the advice given will be better when using a fee-based advisor, but it does eliminate the advisor recommending the products or provider that offer the best commissions (product/provider bias).

Question 72

[1052289] Consider the following individuals: Rita, a research analyst, knowingly passes inside information to her brother and encourages him to deal Iris, the owner of a fast food restaurant, looks after criminal property until it appears to be legitimate William, an asset manager, deals on investment research that was specifically produced for the firm's clients Which of the following is true?
A
Only Rita could be served with an unlimited fine
B
Only Iris could serve a 14-year prison sentence
C
Only William is guilty of Insider Dealing as defined under the Criminal Justice Act
D
Only Rita and William can be charged with financial crime
The correct answer is: B - Only Iris could serve a 14-year prison sentence

Explanation

Rita is committing Insider Dealing. This is a criminal offence and can be punished with seven years in prison and an unlimited fine. Iris is committing a money laundering offence. This is a criminal offence and can be punished with 14 years in prison and an unlimited fine. William is front running. This is not necessarily a breach of law, but is a breach of FCA regulation. Disciplinary measures will be taken by the FCA, which could involve an unlimited fine. Anyone, whether a market participant or not, can be accused and prosecuted for financial crime.

Question 73

[1054052] Last year Mr Michaels was 65 years old. He has recently retired and received a company pension which paid a 100,000 lump sum and 500 per month. Due to this and other income, he is a basic rate taxpayer. His long-term advisor, Mr Jordan, has been asked to look into possible investments. Mr Jordan is aware of 10,000 outstanding on Mr Michaels mortgage with a current interest rate of 5%. The monthly payment on the mortgage is 100. This year, Mr Michaels has put 3,000 into a Cash NISA and 7,600 of his shares in a stocks and shares NISA; he has 7,400 worth of shares in Vodong Inc which are not ISA wrapped. Mr Michaels also holds 2,000 in a current account which is earning 0.5% interest. Mr Michaels has a current limit on his credit card of 3,336 and has a balance of 500. The credit card has an interest rate of 19.8% pa; although, there is 0% on purchases that are less than two months old. Mr Michaels pays off the balance in full each month. The current rates of interest on non-ISA savings accounts are 3% up to 5,000, 4% on 5,000 - 9,999 and 5% on 10,000 and over. A 20-year investment bond can also be bought for a cash sum of 90,000. This provides no income during the term, but will provide a 6% pa guaranteed return on expiry. An alternative would be to spread the investment around a number of sources, including a unit trust that has been performing well recently. Mr Michaels had many investments in stocks in the past; although he had lost a great deal and is wary about further investment. Mr Michaels has always aimed to generate an income from his investments to pay for future costs, such as the possible eventuality of care home charges. He also wants to provide an inheritance for his grandchildren in the future. Mr Jordan's fact find was:
A
Sufficient
B
Adequate
C
Excellent
D
Inadequate
The correct answer is: D - Inadequate

Explanation

Whilst Mr Jordan has a long term relationship with the client, and is aware of his previous objectives, there is no indication that he has completed a fact find in relation to the change of circumstances to see if Mr Michael's recent retirement and receipt of a large lump sum have altered his aims.

Question 74

[1054053] Last year Mr Michaels was 65 years old. He has recently retired and received a company pension which paid a 100,000 lump sum and 500 per month. Due to this and other income, he is a basic rate taxpayer. His long-term advisor, Mr Jordan, has been asked to look into possible investments. Mr Jordan is aware of 10,000 outstanding on Mr Michaels mortgage with a current interest rate of 5%. The monthly payment on the mortgage is 100. This year, Mr Michaels has put 3,000 into a Cash NISA and 7,600 of his shares in a stocks and shares NISA; he has 7,400 worth of shares in Vodong Inc which are not ISA wrapped. Mr Michaels also holds 2,000 in a current account which is earning 0.5% interest. Mr Michaels has a current limit on his credit card of 3,336 and has a balance of 500. The credit card has an interest rate of 19.8% pa; although, there is 0% on purchases that are less than two months old. Mr Michaels pays off the balance in full each month. The current rates of interest on non-ISA savings accounts are 3% up to 5,000, 4% on 5,000 - 9,999 and 5% on 10,000 and over. A 20-year investment bond can also be bought for a cash sum of 90,000. This provides no income during the term, but will provide a 6% pa guaranteed return on expiry. An alternative would be to spread the investment around a number of sources, including a unit trust that has been performing well recently. Mr Michaels had many investments in stocks in the past; although he had lost a great deal and is wary about further investment. Mr Michaels has always aimed to generate an income from his investments to pay for future costs, such as the possible eventuality of care home charges. He also wants to provide an inheritance for his grandchildren in the future. If Mr Jordan suggests the unit trust, should he provide a suitability report?
A
Yes
B
No
C
If the unit trust is unregulated
D
If the unit trust invests in derivatives
The correct answer is: A - Yes

Explanation

As this is a personal recommendation to, a client a suitability test should be completed. As it is a unit trust and the recommendation is for a retail client, Mr Jordan should be provided with a suitability report.

Question 75

[1054054] Last year Mr Michaels was 65 years old. He has recently retired and received a company pension which paid a 100,000 lump sum and 500 per month. Due to this and other income, he is a basic rate taxpayer. His long-term advisor, Mr Jordan, has been asked to look into possible investments. Mr Jordan is aware of 10,000 outstanding on Mr Michaels mortgage with a current interest rate of 5%. The monthly payment on the mortgage is 100. This year, Mr Michaels has put 3,000 into a Cash NISA and 7,600 of his shares in a stocks and shares NISA; he has 7,400 worth of shares in Vodong Inc which are not ISA wrapped. Mr Michaels also holds 2,000 in a current account which is earning 0.5% interest. Mr Michaels has a current limit on his credit card of 3,336 and has a balance of 500. The credit card has an interest rate of 19.8% pa; although, there is 0% on purchases that are less than two months old. Mr Michaels pays off the balance in full each month. The current rates of interest on non-ISA savings accounts are 3% up to 5,000, 4% on 5,000 - 9,999 and 5% on 10,000 and over. A 20-year investment bond can also be bought for a cash sum of 90,000. This provides no income during the term, but will provide a 6% pa guaranteed return on expiry. An alternative would be to spread the investment around a number of sources, including a unit trust that has been performing well recently. Mr Michaels had many investments in stocks in the past; although he had lost a great deal and is wary about further investment. Mr Michaels has always aimed to generate an income from his investments to pay for future costs, such as the possible eventuality of care home charges. He also wants to provide an inheritance for his grandchildren in the future. In relation to monthly income, would it be more beneficial to pay the mortgage or place the 10,000 in a non-ISA savings account?
A
Pay mortgage
B
Place sum in non-ISA savings account
C
It depends on the access to the savings.
D
The rates are equivalent, so it will make no difference.
The correct answer is: A - Pay mortgage

Explanation

Despite the rates being the same, the effect on the Mr Michael's net income would be very different. Mr Michaels would pay 5% interest on the outstanding balance; whereas he would receive a net income from the savings of 4%, due to the tax on the interest.

Question 76

[1054055] Last year Mr Michaels was 65 years old. He has recently retired and received a company pension which paid a 100,000 lump sum and 500 per month. Due to this and other income, he is a basic rate taxpayer. His long-term advisor, Mr Jordan, has been asked to look into possible investments. Mr Jordan is aware of 10,000 outstanding on Mr Michaels mortgage with a current interest rate of 5%. The monthly payment on the mortgage is 100. This year, Mr Michaels has put 3,000 into a Cash NISA and 7,600 of his shares in a stocks and shares NISA; he has 7,400 worth of shares in Vodong Inc which are not ISA wrapped. Mr Michaels also holds 2,000 in a current account which is earning 0.5% interest. Mr Michaels has a current limit on his credit card of 3,336 and has a balance of 500. The credit card has an interest rate of 19.8% pa; although, there is 0% on purchases that are less than two months old. Mr Michaels pays off the balance in full each month. The current rates of interest on non-ISA savings accounts are 3% up to 5,000, 4% on 5,000 - 9,999 and 5% on 10,000 and over. A 20-year investment bond can also be bought for a cash sum of 90,000. This provides no income during the term, but will provide a 6% pa guaranteed return on expiry. An alternative would be to spread the investment around a number of sources, including a unit trust that has been performing well recently. Mr Michaels had many investments in stocks in the past; although he had lost a great deal and is wary about further investment. Mr Michaels has always aimed to generate an income from his investments to pay for future costs, such as the possible eventuality of care home charges. He also wants to provide an inheritance for his grandchildren in the future. If the investment bond meets its guaranteed return, how much will it be worth on maturity (assuming annual compunding)?
A
198,000
B
288,642
C
268,739
D
95,400
The correct answer is: B - 288,642

Explanation

The investment bond costs 900,000 and offers a guaranteed return of 6% p.a. over 20 years. 90,000 x 1.06^20 = 288,642.19 NOTE: this question has recently been changed.

Question 77

[1054057] Last year Mr Michaels was 65 years old. He has recently retired and received a company pension which paid a 100,000 lump sum and 500 per month. Due to this and other income, he is a basic rate taxpayer. His long-term advisor, Mr Jordan, has been asked to look into possible investments. Mr Jordan is aware of 10,000 outstanding on Mr Michaels mortgage with a current interest rate of 5%. The monthly payment on the mortgage is 100. This year, Mr Michaels has put 3,000 into a Cash NISA and 7,600 of his shares in a stocks and shares NISA; he has 7,400 worth of shares in Vodong Inc which are not ISA wrapped. Mr Michaels also holds 2,000 in a current account which is earning 0.5% interest. Mr Michaels has a current limit on his credit card of 3,336 and has a balance of 500. The credit card has an interest rate of 19.8% pa; although, there is 0% on purchases that are less than two months old. Mr Michaels pays off the balance in full each month. The current rates of interest on non-ISA savings accounts are 3% up to 5,000, 4% on 5,000 - 9,999 and 5% on 10,000 and over. A 20-year investment bond can also be bought for a cash sum of 90,000. This provides no income during the term, but will provide a 6% pa guaranteed return on expiry. An alternative would be to spread the investment around a number of sources, including a unit trust that has been performing well recently. Mr Michaels had many investments in stocks in the past; although he had lost a great deal and is wary about further investment. Mr Michaels has always aimed to generate an income from his investments to pay for future costs, such as the possible eventuality of care home charges. He also wants to provide an inheritance for his grandchildren in the future. Mr Jordan has advised Mr Michaels to use his full NISA entitlement each year. Mr Michaels is entitled to place how much additional in each this year?
A
2,680 in the cash NISA and 3,680 in the stocks and shares NISA
B
2,000 in the cash NISA and 2,400 in the stocks and shares NISA
C
2,760 in the cash NISA or 3,920 in the stocks and shares NISA
D
4,400 in the cash NISA or 4,400 in the stocks and shares NISA
The correct answer is: D - 4,400 in the cash NISA or 4,400 in the stocks and shares NISA

Explanation

The current NISA allowance is 15,000. Mr Michaels has already put 3,000 in the cash ISA and 7,600 in the stocks and shares, totalling 10,600, so he could put an additional 4,400 in one or the other.

Question 78

[1054059] Mr Faversham has recently passed away. He leaves a wife (Felicity Faversham) and three sons (Jon, James and Jeffro). Ten years ago, Mr Faverhsam placed 25% of his estate into trust for his three grandchildren (Anna, Anne and Anjolina) and they will have access to this on thei twenty-first birthdays. The country house (Faversham Hall) passed directly to Felicity Faversham. Mr Faversham's remaining assets passed to his sons, as stipulated through Mr Faversham's will that is being handled by the law firm Pembers and Ross. Pembers and Ross have been established since 1846 and have handled the Faverhsam business since Mr Faversham's grandfather made a fortune in coal. As part of the will, the firm is holding a number of assets, including shares which they will distribute to the brothers on completion. However, James Faversham is concerned about tax issues in relation to the transfer. Jon Faversham owns a tyre retread business, which is struggling in the current economic climate. He and his wife Sarah have recently approached Pembers and Ross, as they are keen to encourage a swift resolution of the will, as he is concerned about cash flow in his business and feels that he may need to file for bankruptcy if he does not receive his inheritance soon. A friend of Jeffro Faversham has recently inherited 500,000 and needs investment advice. Jeffro has been happy with the helpfulness of the partners at the firm and recommends them to his friend. In regards to treatment of Mr Faversham's estate, Pembers and Ross will:
A
Act as executors and obtain grant probate
B
Act as administrators and seeks a letter of administration
C
Act according to the national intestacy rules
D
Distribute according to the rules on interest in possession
The correct answer is: A - Act as executors and obtain grant probate

Explanation

Since Mr Faversham died testate (with a valid will), the executors will obtain a grant probate.

Question 79

[1054060] Mr Faversham has recently passed away. He leaves a wife (Felicity Faversham) and three sons (Jon, James and Jeffro). Ten years ago, Mr Faverhsam placed 25% of his estate into trust for his three grandchildren (Anna, Anne and Anjolina) and they will have access to this on thei twenty-first birthdays. The country house (Faversham Hall) passed directly to Felicity Faversham. Mr Faversham's remaining assets passed to his sons, as stipulated through Mr Faversham's will that is being handled by the law firm Pembers and Ross. Pembers and Ross have been established since 1846 and have handled the Faverhsam business since Mr Faversham's grandfather made a fortune in coal. As part of the will, the firm is holding a number of assets, including shares which they will distribute to the brothers on completion. However, James Faversham is concerned about tax issues in relation to the transfer. Jon Faversham owns a tyre retread business, which is struggling in the current economic climate. He and his wife Sarah have recently approached Pembers and Ross, as they are keen to encourage a swift resolution of the will, as he is concerned about cash flow in his business and feels that he may need to file for bankruptcy if he does not receive his inheritance soon. A friend of Jeffro Faversham has recently inherited 500,000 and needs investment advice. Jeffro has been happy with the helpfulness of the partners at the firm and recommends them to his friend. The CGT issues with the will:
A
Should be passed to the HMRC for consideration
B
Could be dealt with using a deed of variation
C
Are inherent to the will and cannot be changed
D
Were paid when the will was created
The correct answer is: B - Could be dealt with using a deed of variation

Explanation

Deeds of Variation can be used to make a will more tax efficient. It must be agreed by all parties over 18 and completed within two years of death.

Question 80

[1054061] Mr Faversham has recently passed away. He leaves a wife (Felicity Faversham) and three sons (Jon, James and Jeffro). Ten years ago, Mr Faverhsam placed 25% of his estate into trust for his three grandchildren (Anna, Anne and Anjolina) and they will have access to this on thei twenty-first birthdays. The country house (Faversham Hall) passed directly to Felicity Faversham. Mr Faversham's remaining assets passed to his sons, as stipulated through Mr Faversham's will that is being handled by the law firm Pembers and Ross. Pembers and Ross have been established since 1846 and have handled the Faverhsam business since Mr Faversham's grandfather made a fortune in coal. As part of the will, the firm is holding a number of assets, including shares which they will distribute to the brothers on completion. However, James Faversham is concerned about tax issues in relation to the transfer. Jon Faversham owns a tyre retread business, which is struggling in the current economic climate. He and his wife Sarah have recently approached Pembers and Ross, as they are keen to encourage a swift resolution of the will, as he is concerned about cash flow in his business and feels that he may need to file for bankruptcy if he does not receive his inheritance soon. A friend of Jeffro Faversham has recently inherited 500,000 and needs investment advice. Jeffro has been happy with the helpfulness of the partners at the firm and recommends them to his friend. Pembers and Ross, in administering the will, are providing safe custody of the assets for the Faversham family. They are also, potentially, about to give investment advice to the friend of Jeffro. From a regulatory perspective, how will this be treated?
A
Pembers and Ross need to be authorised
B
Pembers and Ross need to be authorised for the custody, but not for the advice
C
Pembers and Ross does not need authorisation as they are exempt
D
Pembers and Ross need to be authorised for the advice, but not for the custody
The correct answer is: D - Pembers and Ross need to be authorised for the advice, but not for the custody

Explanation

As the custodian services are provided as incidental business to execution of the will, they can provide these under their exemption as a DPB. However, they would need to be authorised to provide investment advice as a core activity.

Question 81

[1054062] Mr Faversham has recently passed away. He leaves a wife (Felicity Faversham) and three sons (Jon, James and Jeffro). Ten years ago, Mr Faverhsam placed 25% of his estate into trust for his three grandchildren (Anna, Anne and Anjolina) and they will have access to this on thei twenty-first birthdays. The country house (Faversham Hall) passed directly to Felicity Faversham. Mr Faversham's remaining assets passed to his sons, as stipulated through Mr Faversham's will that is being handled by the law firm Pembers and Ross. Pembers and Ross have been established since 1846 and have handled the Faverhsam business since Mr Faversham's grandfather made a fortune in coal. As part of the will, the firm is holding a number of assets, including shares which they will distribute to the brothers on completion. However, James Faversham is concerned about tax issues in relation to the transfer. Jon Faversham owns a tyre retread business, which is struggling in the current economic climate. He and his wife Sarah have recently approached Pembers and Ross, as they are keen to encourage a swift resolution of the will, as he is concerned about cash flow in his business and feels that he may need to file for bankruptcy if he does not receive his inheritance soon. A friend of Jeffro Faversham has recently inherited 500,000 and needs investment advice. Jeffro has been happy with the helpfulness of the partners at the firm and recommends them to his friend. In relation to Faversham Hall, Mr and Mrs Faversham were:
A
Tenants in common
B
Tenant owners
C
Feudal tenants
D
Joint tenants
The correct answer is: D - Joint tenants

Explanation

Ownership of Faversham Hall passed directly to Mrs Faversham, rather than to the estate.

Question 82

[1054063] Mr Faversham has recently passed away. He leaves a wife (Felicity Faversham) and three sons (Jon, James and Jeffro). Ten years ago, Mr Faverhsam placed 25% of his estate into trust for his three grandchildren (Anna, Anne and Anjolina) and they will have access to this on thei twenty-first birthdays. The country house (Faversham Hall) passed directly to Felicity Faversham. Mr Faversham's remaining assets passed to his sons, as stipulated through Mr Faversham's will that is being handled by the law firm Pembers and Ross. Pembers and Ross have been established since 1846 and have handled the Faverhsam business since Mr Faversham's grandfather made a fortune in coal. As part of the will, the firm is holding a number of assets, including shares which they will distribute to the brothers on completion. However, James Faversham is concerned about tax issues in relation to the transfer. Jon Faversham owns a tyre retread business, which is struggling in the current economic climate. He and his wife Sarah have recently approached Pembers and Ross, as they are keen to encourage a swift resolution of the will, as he is concerned about cash flow in his business and feels that he may need to file for bankruptcy if he does not receive his inheritance soon. A friend of Jeffro Faversham has recently inherited 500,000 and needs investment advice. Jeffro has been happy with the helpfulness of the partners at the firm and recommends them to his friend. In relation to the trust, Mr Faversham senior was:
A
The investor
B
The remainderman
C
The settlor
D
The beneficiary
The correct answer is: C - The settlor

Explanation

The settlor creates the trust and puts property in at the start.

Question 83

[1066745] Which organisation is used to settle US equities?
A
The Federal Reserve
B
The Depositary Trust Company
C
The Securities and Exchange Commission
D
The Equity Settlement Company
The correct answer is: B - The Depositary Trust Company

Explanation

The Depositary Trust Company (DTC) is the central clearing house for US equities, and the settlement cycle is T+3. Settlement of T-bonds is T+1, and the settlement agency is the Federal Reserve.

Question 84

[1066764] How are the values of exchange traded futures calculated for accounting purposes?
A
According to the market value of the underlying asset
B
According to the price that was agreed on the creation of the contract
C
According to the market value of the future
D
According to the value of previous contracts held to delivery
The correct answer is: C - According to the market value of the future

Explanation

Derivatives should be valued on fair value through profit or loss (FVTPL). In this way they are marked to market at the time of producing the financial statements and any profit or loss, realised or unrealised, is reflected in the profit and loss account. Derivative positions used as a hedge are not be covered under IAS39, because, in general, a derivative used as a hedge will be held to delivery and therefore its realisable value. For this reason, the price that was agreed on the creation of the contract will be value used on the financial statements.

Question 85

[1067039] What is an individual's personal allowance for CGT?
A
Nil
B
Totally dependent on their tax banding
C
5,300
D
11,000
The correct answer is: D - 11,000

Explanation

In the current financial year the allowance on CGT is 11,000

Practice Mock Exam

Question 1

[1012257] Which of the following settlement systems is used for gilt trades on the London Stock Exchange?
A
CGO
B
CREST
C
LCH.Clearnet
D
CMMO
The correct answer is: B - CREST

Explanation

The Central Gilts Office (CGO) and Central Money Markets Office (CMMO) are no longer used for gilt or money market settlements. LCH.Clearnet is the central counterparty for London Stock Exchange SETS transactions, but not Gilts.

Question 2

[1012281] Ajax Fund Management wishes to promote its Euro Growth Fund which was created in 1995. If Ajax wishes to use past performance data in the promotion which of the following must it include in order to comply with the FCA's financial promotion rules?
I
A warning stating that past performance is not necessarily an indication of future performance
II
At least five year's worth past data is used
III
The past performance of a similar investment
A
I only
B
II only
C
I and II
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - I and II

Explanation

The FCA financial promotion rules allow past performance data to be used in financial promotions provided that the promotion: a) states that past performance may not necessarily be repeated b) contains at least five year's worth of data, or the entire life of the fund, whichever is shorter

Question 3

[1000369] What notice need be given to a firm prior to a visit by an enforcement officer from the FCA?
A
One week
B
48 hours
C
None
D
One day
The correct answer is: C - None

Explanation

No notice is needed although a mutually convenient time will often be arranged.

Question 4

[1000372] Representatives of the FCA and PRA can do all of the following except:
A
Enter a firm's premises without notice
B
Interview any director, partner or employee of the firm, whether they are an approved person or not
C
Remove any documents from the firm's business premises
D
Monitor any firm on a periodic basis
The correct answer is: C - Remove any documents from the firm's business premises

Explanation

This requirement applies only to information and documents reasonably required in connection with the exercise by the regulator of functions conferred on it by or under this Act. These will typically be copies rather than originals.

Question 5

[1000438] Which of the following would not be considered market abuse under S118 of FSMA 2000?
A
An employee of a firm trades on price-sensitive information that has been disclosed through an RIS
B
A firm sells a large holding of bonds, a transaction that significantly reduces the market price, and then repurchases their holding at the lower price
C
A firm unintentionally submits incorrect trade details, which leads to a significant move in the market
D
A firm controls a large percentage of a company's shares and takes out a large up-bet with a spread-betting firm
The correct answer is: A - An employee of a firm trades on price-sensitive information that has been disclosed through an RIS

Explanation

Information disclosed through an RIS (regulatory information service), such as the LSE's Regulatory News Service, is considered to be public information. For B, the firm has engaged in a wash trade and D is an example of an abusive squeeze, both of which is a breach of the legislation. Market abuse does not need to prove intent, so C may also be a breach under misleading statements.

Question 6

[1001462] Which of the following securities is most suitable if you are an investor who wishes to have an increase in returns as the performance of the company improves?
A
Debentures
B
Participating preference shares
C
Cumulative preference shares
D
Redeemable preference shares
The correct answer is: B - Participating preference shares

Explanation

Participating preference shares have a fixed dividend but also have a bonus tethered to them in years of improved performance. Cumulative preference shares, redeemable preference shares and debentures all have a fixed return.

Question 7

[1006612] Which of the following is TRUE with regards to OEIC shares and inheritance tax?
A
OEIC shares are exempt from IHT
B
OEIC shares are included as part of a deceased's estate
C
OEIC shares purchased more than seven years before death are exempt
D
OEIC shares held in an ISA are exempt from IHT
The correct answer is: B - OEIC shares are included as part of a deceased's estate

Explanation

OEIC shares are chargeable assets for IHT purposes.

Question 8

[1012275] Which of the following satisfy the FCA's definition of a retail investment product?
I
Units in a regulated unit trust
II
Life policies
III
Investment trust savings schemes
A
II and III
B
I and III
C
I and II
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

Life policies, regulated unit trusts, investment trust savings schemes and personal pension plans are all defined as retail investment products.

Question 9

[1012287] Apart from the Competition and Markets Authority, who else decides whether or not a merger should go ahead?
A
The FCA
B
The Panel on Takeovers and Mergers
C
Department of Business Innovation and Skills
D
The Treasury
The correct answer is: C - Department of Business Innovation and Skills

Explanation

The Security of State for Trade and Industry can intervene if the merger raises a matter of national security or involves a newspaper.

Question 10

[1012288] Which of the following is true of a NYSE designated market maker?
A
Continually quotes buying and selling prices throughout the day
B
Accepts orders from members of the general public
C
Not allowed to execute own account orders
D
Mostly manage one stock
The correct answer is: A - Continually quotes buying and selling prices throughout the day

Explanation

Most designated market makers manage between five and ten stocks and they act as an agent for all Universal Trading Platform (electronically routed) orders.

Question 11

[1012290] How often must a company have a general meeting?
A
Every calendar year
B
Twice a year
C
Every two years
D
Every time one is requested by the shareholders
The correct answer is: A - Every calendar year

Explanation

According to the Companies Act an AGM has to be held every calendar year no more than 15 months from the previous one.

Question 12

[1012296] A UK listed company would normally be categorised as what type of client for non-MiFID business?
A
Retail client
B
Eligible counterparty
C
Professional client
D
Authorised person
The correct answer is: C - Professional client

Explanation

Providing the company has net assets of at least 10m, it would usually be treated as an professional client.

Question 13

[1012302] During an FCA inspection visit it is discovered that an investment management firm has breached a Principle for Business. Which of the following will result?
A
Automatic termination of the firm's authorisation
B
Automatic fine by the FCA
C
Automatic disciplinary action by the FCA
D
The FCA may take the breach into account for disciplinary purposes
The correct answer is: D - The FCA may take the breach into account for disciplinary purposes

Explanation

There are no automatic enforcement actions by the FCA.

Question 14

[1012452] If a UK fund manager wished to increase the level of franked income into the fund, he would invest more heavily in:
A
US equities
B
US bonds
C
UK equities
D
UK bonds
The correct answer is: C - UK equities

Explanation

Franked income is dividends from UK equities. It is referred to as 'franked' because it is paid out of post-tax profits.

Question 15

[1012453] What can the Takeover Panel do in the event of an unfair takeover?
A
Order the takeover to be reversed
B
Impose a fine
C
Prosecute the directors
D
Change the City Code to attempt to address the problem
The correct answer is: D - Change the City Code to attempt to address the problem

Explanation

The Takeover Panel does not have legal powers, it could change the Code and hope that it is not breached.

Question 16

[1012457] An investor, who is a non-tax payer, receives a dividend of 400. Which of the following can he do to reclaim the tax deducted on the dividends paid?
A
Nothing
B
Submit a claim to his (buying) broker for 100
C
Submit a claim to the company for 100
D
Submit a claim to the Inland Revenue for 44.44
The correct answer is: A - Nothing

Explanation

The 10% tax credit on UK dividends cannot be reclaimed by non-taxpayers.

Question 17

[1012458] Certain individuals must be approved by the FCA and demonstrate fitness and propriety at an individual level. Which of the following might the FCA take into account when considering the application of an individual?
I
Suitable qualifications
II
Past employment record with other firms in the financial services industry
III
Any criminal record
IV
Their position in the firm
A
I, II and III
B
I, II and IV
C
II, III and IV
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: D - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

The FCA will need to consider various factors that may determine an applicant's fitness and properness.

Question 18

[1012463] Markets in the European Union (EU) are automatically eligible markets and securities listed in the EU are deemed approved securities. Which of the following characteristics would a trustee take into account when considering whether another market is eligible?
I
That it is regulated by a statutory body or directly by the government
II
It operates regularly
III
It has a transparent pricing mechanism
IV
It is open to the public
A
I, II and III
B
I, III and IV
C
II, III and IV
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: D - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Trustees in unit trusts are bound by the Financial Services (Regulated Schemes) Regulations published by the Financial Conduct Authority. Amongst other things these lay down the criteria defining an eligible market.

Question 19

[1012464] A small trust fund governed by the investment powers of the Trustees Act 2000 would normally be able to invest in which of the following investments?
I
Ordinary shares
II
Corporate bonds
III
Land in the United Kingdom
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

The Trustees Act 2000 gives trustees, not governed by a trust deed, two types of investment powers: General Investment Powers, which state that the trustee may invest in any ordinary security (such as equities and bonds) and Specific Investment Powers allowing them to invest in freehold or leasehold land in the UK.

Question 20

[1012470] A company seeking to apply for a listing on the Official List of the LSE applies to:
A
LSE
B
FCA
C
Treasury
D
SEC
The correct answer is: B - FCA

Explanation

The FCA is the UK's Listing Authority.

Question 21

[1012482] Which of the following is NOT a power conferred on the Financial Conduct Authority?
A
To authorise directly the Bank of England
B
To delegate tasks of regulation to DPBs
C
To wind up an authorised firm in the interests of investors
D
To issue a set of Conduct of Business rules to be used as a basis for working practice throughout the financial services industry
The correct answer is: A - To authorise directly the Bank of England

Explanation

The FCA does not directly authorise the Bank of England.

Question 22

[1012484] A company wishes to float on the London Stock Exchange's official list via an offer for sale. Which of the following must the company do to comply with the UK Listing Authority's rules regarding floatation?
I
Have a prospectus approved by the UK Listing Authority
II
Publish its prospectus
III
Advertise the prospectus in at least one national newspaper
A
I only
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II and III

Explanation

The UK Listing Authority (a role of the FCA) requires that prospectuses, or listing particulars as they are sometimes called, must be published and circulated.

Question 23

[1012485] An FCA firm has to report twice a year to the FCA on completions of complaints. What periods, for completion of complaints after receipt of complaints, must the firm report on?
I
2 weeks
II
4 weeks
III
6 weeks
IV
8 weeks
A
I and II
B
II and IV
C
IV only
D
None of the above
The correct answer is: B - II and IV

Explanation

An FCA firm must provide the FCA with a twice-yearly report that includes: The total number of complaints Complaints closed within four weeks of receipt Complaints closed within eight weeks of receipt Complaints closed more than eight weeks after receipt Complaints outstanding at the end of the reporting period The reports must be sent even if no complaints were received (i.e. a NIL RETURN).

Question 24

[1012490] There is a General Prohibition against a person communicating a financial promotion unless the person is authorised, or the content of the promotion is approved by an authorised person. It is a defence for a person to show that he:
I
Reasonably believed that the communication was prepared by an authorised person
II
Reasonably believed that the communication was approved by an authorised person
III
Exercised due diligence
IV
Exercised his free will
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
I, II and III
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I, II and III

Explanation

The General Prohibition requires that any person who communicates a financial promotion must be authorised or exempt. Alternatively, the promotion can be approved by an authorised person. If a person contravenes the General Prohibition, it is a defence for that person to show that he exercised due diligence. It is also a defence if that person reasonably believed that the communication was prepared or approved by an authorised person.

Question 25

[1012491] Under the FCA client money rules, the FCA can require all of the following treatments of client money EXCEPT:
A
Held on trust
B
Treat multiple accounts as one
C
Lodge client money in a pension trust fund
D
Order when interest must or must not be distributed
The correct answer is: C - Lodge client money in a pension trust fund

Explanation

Lodging client money in a pension trust fund is not an action that the FCA can require under their client money rules.

Question 26

[1012493] When a firm is found in breach of the regulations, place the following in the order that procedures would occur:
I
Regulatory Decision Committee sends a decision notice
II
Disciplinary action
III
FCA sends a preliminary findings letter
IV
FCA launches an investigation
A
III, IV, I, II
B
II, IV, I, III
C
IV, III, I, II
D
IV, I, III, II
The correct answer is: C - IV, III, I, II

Explanation

The first stage is to launch an investigation, followed by sending a preliminary findings letter. Having considered representations from the firm and any decision by the Financial Services and Markets Tribunal, the Regulatory Decision Committee sends a decision notice to the firm.

Question 27

[1013891] Before conducting any designated investment business, a firm need not provide a retail client with:
A
A durable copy of the relevant transactions
B
Terms of the agreement
C
Information about fees and commissions
D
Information about the firm
The correct answer is: A - A durable copy of the relevant transactions

Explanation

Clearly no transactions can have taken place before the other three are given to the client. All pre-trade information must be in a durable medium.

Question 28

[1013903] All key features documents must include information:
A
That the firm is passported under MiFID
B
Explaining the cancellation procedure
C
Commenting on the applicability of stakeholder pensions rather than the product covered
D
Containing sufficient material such that a professional client is able to make an informed decision
The correct answer is: B - Explaining the cancellation procedure

Explanation

'That the firm is passported under MiFID' is irrelevant for the KFD. The stakeholder pension clauses are necessary only for personal pension schemes and the information must be sufficient for a retail client to understand and make an informed decision.

Question 29

[1014062] If a retail client wishes to ensure that they do not lose any money in a deposit, which of the following is the most suitable deposit or investment?
A
Up to 85,000 in a UK bank account
B
Any amount in a UK account
C
Up to 35,000 in a UK account
D
Up to 50,000 in a UK bank account
The correct answer is: A - Up to 85,000 in a UK bank account

Explanation

85,000 is the amount is guaranteed by the FSCS.

Question 30

[1014706] The FCA decides to pursue an investigation of an authorised firm. How is this communicated?
A
Verbally on a taped telephone line
B
In writing
C
Verbally by asking the firm to visit the FCA
D
Verbally by the FCA visiting the firm
The correct answer is: B - In writing

Explanation

Investigations are communicated in writing.

Question 31

[1014753] In respect of the responsibilities of an authorised firm which of the following is TRUE?
A
A firm does not have to adopt and communicate to workers' appropriate internal procedures for handling workers' concerns
B
The firm is not required to perform identity checks for money laundering purposes where the firm does not see fit to apply them
C
A firm does not have to provide appropriate training in respect of money laundering
D
A firm must take reasonable care to establish and maintain systems and controls that are appropriate to the business
The correct answer is: D - A firm must take reasonable care to establish and maintain systems and controls that are appropriate to the business

Explanation

A firm is required to do all of the above according the Senior Management Arrangements, Systems and Controls (SYSC) Handbook.

Question 32

[1014757] According to the Conduct of Business Rules, when an appointed representative communicates a financial promotion, who ultimately bears responsibility for that communication?
A
The appointed representative communicating the promotion
B
The authorised firm that approves the promotion
C
The product provider if different from the approving authorised firm
D
The person who confirms compliance of the financial promotion
The correct answer is: B - The authorised firm that approves the promotion

Explanation

Responsibility for the communication remains with the authorised firm, even if communicated by an appointed representative.

Question 33

[1014787] An employee of an authorised firm suspects that deposits being made by a client are suspicious. Which of the following would allow the employee to distinguish funds being deposited for terrorist activities from those deposited for money laundering?
A
The deposit comes from a legitimate source such as a standing order from a UK credit institution
B
The deposit is a large one-off payment made in cash
C
The transaction is communicated indirectly, e.g. through a third party account
D
The deposit is a result of unusual patterns of trading for the client
The correct answer is: A - The deposit comes from a legitimate source such as a standing order from a UK credit institution

Explanation

Terrorism can be funded from legitimate sources, whereas the funds involved in money laundering always come from the proceeds of crime. All of the other deposits could be either terrorism or money laundering.

Question 34

[1015017] A new client seeks your opinion before entering into a client agreement. What should you do?
A
Refuse to give him any advice
B
Advise him on an execution only basis
C
Notify the compliance officer having given advice
D
Provide the client with advice since it appears to be required solely for the purposes of preparing the client agreement
The correct answer is: D - Provide the client with advice since it appears to be required solely for the purposes of preparing the client agreement

Explanation

As soon as advice is given, however, a client agreement should be produced.

Question 35

[1015809] Which of the following is the best description of the principal-to-principal guarantee structure?
A
The guarantee extends from the customer to the clearing house
B
The guarantee operates between the customer and broker
C
The guarantee operates between the broker and the clearing member
D
The guarantee operates between the clearing member and the clearing house
The correct answer is: D - The guarantee operates between the clearing member and the clearing house

Explanation

The clearing house guarantees trades between itself and the clearing member only.

Question 36

[1018135] An existing client approaches their firm and requests that they give him a lower level of protection. Which of the following would be appropriate action for the firm to take?
A
The firm must offer this level of protection based on specific client instructions
B
The firm may only offer this level of protection if the client in question is already deemed a professional client
C
The firm must not offer this level of protection as if it were appropriate to do so it would have categorised the client as such already
D
The firm must first assess the client and then, if necessary, warn them of the additional risks
The correct answer is: D - The firm must first assess the client and then, if necessary, warn them of the additional risks

Explanation

A lower level of protection would involve a client asking for 'elective' status - or to opt up to the next category of client. This requires assessment by the firm involved before a decision is made.

Question 37

[1024420] A new investor has approached you with the intention of taking out a life policy on her partner. What should be your main priority when recommending a policy?
A
Affordability for the investor
B
Attitude towards risk of the partner
C
Lifestyle and health of the partner
D
Commission that you would receive
The correct answer is: A - Affordability for the investor

Explanation

The insurance company would need to know the health and lifestyle issues to assess risk. Your duty as an advisor, however, is to your client, so attitude to risk and affordability are a priority. As this is a life policy, attitude to risk is not really an issue, so affordability is the main area to focus on.

Question 38

[1032585] Which of the following is LEAST likely to affect a client's attitude to risk?
A
Whether their investment objective is income or capital
B
The timescale of the investment
C
The existing investments owned by the client
D
The level of the client's current tax bracket
The correct answer is: D - The level of the client's current tax bracket

Explanation

Objectives, timescale and the existing assets owned by the investor are major factors affecting an investor's attitude to risk. Tax implications are less about risk and more about whether income or capital should be a major concern.

Question 39

[1032684] Sally's company imposes trading restrictions on employees forbidding them from entering into any equity purchases of US listed securities. Sally believes that this is an unfair restriction on her right to trade and decides to buy a single share in Microsoft, not for personal profit , but to make an ethical stand. Has Sally violated her duty towards her employer?
A
Yes, because she has no right to unilaterally disapply a trading restriction just because she feels it unjust
B
No, because the purchase was justified on ethical grounds
C
Yes, because she could still make a profit
D
No, because the company may not restrict an employee's right to trade
The correct answer is: A - Yes, because she has no right to unilaterally disapply a trading restriction just because she feels it unjust

Explanation

It is definitely a breach. Whether the trade would be profitable or not is irrelevant.

Question 40

[1039359] When executing a trade for a retail client, assuming no specific instructions were given, which of the following would ensure best execution?
A
Adherence to the order execution policy
B
Executing any outstanding firm order first
C
Placing the total consideration for the transaction as the most important factor
D
Executing away from a regulated market
The correct answer is: A - Adherence to the order execution policy

Explanation

The order execution policy sets out how a firm will achieve best execution. Therefore, if the firm adheres to this, they fulfil best execution. The reference to retail clients is irrelevant to the question, as this would also apply to professional clients.

Question 41

[1039422] A father gives his son a gift of equities with a market price of 1,250. What ad valorem stamp duty reserve tax would be payable?
A
5
B
6.25
C
10
D
There is no stamp duty reserve tax liability
The correct answer is: D - There is no stamp duty reserve tax liability

Explanation

Stamp duty (and stamp duty reserve tax (SDRT)) is not payable on gifts.

Question 42

[1044207] The UK Code on Corporate Governance contains provisions on the following, except:
A
Human Resources
B
Effectiveness
C
Shareholder relations
D
Accountability
The correct answer is: A - Human Resources

Explanation

The UK Code on Corporate Governance looks at: Leadership Effectiveness Accountability Remuneration Shareholder relations

Question 43

[1044626] Which of the following are benefits of a qualifying endowment life assurance bond over investing directly in unit trusts?
I
Guaranteed minimum sum paid on death
II
Proceeds are tax free
III
Can always be sold at the current realisable price
IV
No commission costs
A
I and II
B
I and IV
C
II and III
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and II

Explanation

Endowment policies have a basic sum assured that will be paid tax-free on the earlier of death of the policyholder or maturity of the bond. Terminating a life policy early will lead to a surrender value below the prices the policy is linked to.

Question 44

[1044751] Which of the following statements is most likely correct? A CFA member or candidate:
A
Must report evidence of illegal violations to the appropriate regulatory organisation.
B
Can participate or assist in a violation simply by having knowledge of the violation and not taking action to stop it.
C
Is not held responsible for participating in illegal acts where violation of the law is evident to those who should know it.
The correct answer is: B - Can participate or assist in a violation simply by having knowledge of the violation and not taking action to stop it.

Explanation

According to standard I (A), in some cases reporting an illegal violation to regulatory officials may be appropriate but is not always necessary, and is not required.

Question 45

[1045992] As part of the requirements set out in SYSC, which of the following is TRUE?
A
Responsibilities must be split equally among all directors
B
All firms must maintain clear apportionment of significant responsibilities among directors
C
Records must be held for a five-year period of time
D
Directors cannot be held liable for rule breaches by employees
The correct answer is: B - All firms must maintain clear apportionment of significant responsibilities among directors

Explanation

The split does not necessarily need to be equal, records must be held for six years, and directors are liable for all rule breaches in their area.

Question 46

[1045993] When a firm provides designated investment business to a retail client, the training and competency requirements do not apply for which of the following?
A
Advising and dealing
B
Managing
C
Daily oversight
D
Arranging
The correct answer is: D - Arranging

Explanation

The rules apply for advising, dealing, managing and overseeing on a daily basis.

Question 47

[1046450] Euroclear UK and Ireland run a settlement system for UK securities called CREST. Other than arranging payment and delivery of securities, what extra service does CREST arrange?
A
Novation of trades performed on LSE's SETS system
B
Collects payment for SDRT and transfers them directly to HMRC
C
Creates invoices for each member for net SDRT payments at the end of each day
D
Acts as depository for bearer documents in the UK
The correct answer is: B - Collects payment for SDRT and transfers them directly to HMRC

Explanation

CREST will collect SDRT on behalf of Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC). However, these will be collected for each purchase. There is no netting of SDRT.

Question 48

[1046694] Which of the following is a principle of the Takeover Code?
A
The predator must announce a bid only after ensuring that it can partially fill any cash consideration
B
The target company directors must advise shareholders on its view about the impact of the bid
C
A predator already having influence over 20% or more of the voting rights of a company must, if it acquires any further influence, make an offer for all the remaining shares
D
Under the terms of a mandatory bid offers must be in cash or accompanied by a cash alternative at not less than the highest price paid by the predator during the offer period and within the three months prior to its commencement
The correct answer is: B - The target company directors must advise shareholders on its view about the impact of the bid

Explanation

The predator must announce a bid only after ensuring that it can fulfil in FULL any cash consideration, if offered or required, and after taking reasonable steps to secure implementation of other types of consideration. A predator already having influence over 30% or more of the voting rights of a company must, if it acquires any further influence, make an offer for all the remaining shares. Offers must be in cash or accompanied by a cash alternative at not less than the highest price paid by the predator during the offer period and within the 12 months prior to its commencement.

Question 49

[1047433] Which of the following is a benefit of the LSE CCP service?
A
Flexible settlement timing
B
Negotiation on deliverable assets
C
Counterparty disclosure
D
Settlement netting
The correct answer is: D - Settlement netting

Explanation

Multiple fills on an order book will settle as one transaction with the central counterparty (CCP). This is referred to as settlement netting.

Question 50

[1047443] An investor looking for capital appreciation and/or income at very high risk would invest in:
A
A diversified portfolio of FTSE shares
B
A new start-up company quoted on AIM
C
Fixed interest security
D
Index-tracking fund
The correct answer is: B - A new start-up company quoted on AIM

Explanation

The key here is the high risk element of the strategy. AIM shares are riskier than a diversified portfolio of FTSE shares. The income would come from the receipt of dividends from the company.

Question 51

[1047479] A listed company divests and the spin off company starts trading on AIM. The spin off company would need to follow all of the following rules EXCEPT:
A
Companies Act 2006
B
UKLA Listing Rules
C
FCA Transparency and Disclosure Rules
D
LSE rules
The correct answer is: B - UKLA Listing Rules

Explanation

The UKLA Listing Rules do not apply to AIM-quoted companies. The UKLA listing rules apply to listed companies, which are companies quoted on the Official List of the LSE. This is different to the Alternative Investment Market.

Question 52

[1049736] Lee, a financial adviser for firm A, discloses to Martin, a financial adviser for firm B, that he has a client that continually complains about the service provided by firm A. The client is also a client of firm B and Martin uses this information to win the total business of this client by restructuring the client agreement. After a little while, Martin's manager discovers that this is the case. Which of the following is the most ETHICAL response by the manager?
A
Congratulate Martin on winning the new business
B
Express your concerns to Martin about his behaviour, but take no further action
C
Contact the client and inform her of the circumstances of her agreement with the firm
D
Contact firm A and apologise for the behaviour of Martin
The correct answer is: C - Contact the client and inform her of the circumstances of her agreement with the firm

Explanation

One of the key concepts in ethics is to put the client first, as well as being open, honest, transparent and fair. The best approach is to inform the client of the way her business was won and allow her to decide on whether this affects the relationship of trust with Martin.

Question 53

[1049919] A firm has an outdated client agreement with a retail client, which allows them to lend out the assets of the client. Although the client agreed to this at the time, the clause has never been actioned. However, now the firm would now like to use it. Which of the following would be the best course of action?
A
Lend out the assets as the client has agreed to it
B
Lend out the assets, but replace them with equivalent stock
C
Check with the client that they are still happy to lend out the assets based on the old agreement
D
Sent out a new agreement restating the details clearly and making sure that it is legally binding
The correct answer is: D - Sent out a new agreement restating the details clearly and making sure that it is legally binding

Explanation

It is an obligation on the firm to ensure a client is kept up to date of any changes to any terms and conditions. This has obviously not happened. Before the firm can consider lending out the client's assets, the client must be informed 'in good time' of any changes to the agreement.

Question 54

[1049936] Angela is 28 years old. She is looking to allocate money within her pension fund and is planning to retire at 60 years old. Mary is 40 years old. She requires investments that will provide sufficient funds to pay for her son's university fees. Her son is currently 13 years old. Which of the following best reflects the attitudes of the two investors?
A
Mary is likely to have a more positive attitude to risk than Angela
B
Both Mary and Angela are saving to meet real liabilities
C
Neither Mary nor Angela are interested in growth
D
Tax efficiency of the investments is a greater concern for Angela than for Mary
The correct answer is: B - Both Mary and Angela are saving to meet real liabilities

Explanation

Most of this is thinking about the time horizons of the investors. Angela obviously has the longer horizon. This would suggest a greater willingness to take on risk, and a greater emphasis on real investments and growth. Mary has a shorter investment horizon. This suggests less willingness to take on risk. Nevertheless, her potential liability is still some way in the future, so the impact of inflation needs to be considered. Angela is less concerned about the tax implications of the investments, as she is allocating them within her pension, where they would be tax exempt. Tax will be a concern to Mary; income tax during the life of the investment and capital gains tax on maturity of the investment.

Question 55

[1049943] Henry dies leaving most of his assets, totalling 550,000 to his spouse, Margaret, and a smaller amount, 65,000, to his only daughter Annabelle. The nil-band rate is 325,000. How would this be considered for inheritance tax (IHT) purposes?
A
No IHT is due, and Margaret receives 100% of Henry's nil-rate band
B
No IHT is due, and Margaret receives 80% of Henry's nil-rate band
C
116,000 IHT is due, so that Margaret can receive 100% of Henry's nil-rate band
D
26,000 IHT is due on the gift to Annabelle, and Margaret receives 80% of Henry's nil-rate band
The correct answer is: B - No IHT is due, and Margaret receives 80% of Henry's nil-rate band

Explanation

The transfer between spouses is totally exempt from IHT and would not be included in the estate. This means the estate is valued at 65,000 only, which is well below the nil-rate band, so clearly no IHT is due. However, the 65,000 gift on death is part of the estate and uses up some of the nil-rate band: 65,000 / 325,000 x 100 = 20% This leaves 80% of the nil-rate band remaining, which can be passed on to Margaret.

Question 56

[1049945] Dwayne, 55, wishes to leave a substantial amount of income generating assets on trust for the maintenance of his wife, 56, after his death. However, he wants to ensure that a third party receives the assets on the death of his wife. Which of the following trusts would be most suitable?
A
Discretionary trust
B
Interest in possession trust
C
Accumulation and maintenance trust
D
Absolute trust
The correct answer is: B - Interest in possession trust

Explanation

An interest in possession trust would allow Dwayne to place his assets in trust. The income generated can be handed over to his wife, the life interest, in order to support her after his death. However, the life interest cannot touch the assets themselves. On the death of the life interest, the assets pass in their entirety to another beneficiary, referred to as the remainderman.

Question 57

[1050808] Which of the following does NOT fall under the compulsory jurisdiction of the Financial Ombudsman Service?
A
A UK firm managing investment on behalf of UK and US clients
B
A UK firm managing foreign exchange accounts for a UK client
C
A firm from outside the EEA marketing to and accepting deposits from the UK investors
D
An UK firm providing custody services to clients in Scotland
The correct answer is: B - A UK firm managing foreign exchange accounts for a UK client

Explanation

All FCA authorised firms come under the compulsory jurisdiction of the FOS. Firms providing services in foreign exchange do not require authorisation by the FCA. Although firms WITHIN the EEA accepting deposits from UK investors would fall under voluntary jurisdiction, a firm outside the EEA would need authorisation from the FCA before they could provide those services.

Question 58

[1051013] Which of the following types of trade is most likely to be settled on a PvP basis?
A
FX
B
UK shares
C
US shares
D
UK corporate loan stock
The correct answer is: A - FX

Explanation

PvP stands for payment versus payment, where both parties are receiving (and paying) cash. This type of settlement is associated with FX trades.

Question 59

[1051028] Which of the following investors would be committing an offence under the insider dealing legislation in the Criminal Justice Act 1993?
A
Martin deals on inside information regarding barley options that he received from his brother, an investment manager, making a profit from the transaction
B
Angela buys CFDs on a particular company's shares based on inside information provided by her friend, a research analyst, making a loss from the transaction
C
Holpar Ltd deals in a rival's shares based on inside information received from an inside source, gaining a profit
D
Torpenhow Plc sells a large holding of an oil company's shares based on inside information they received from an inside source, preventing a large loss
The correct answer is: B - Angela buys CFDs on a particular company's shares based on inside information provided by her friend, a research analyst, making a loss from the transaction

Explanation

Martin's trade is in wheat options. Commodity options are not covered by the CJA. It is also not possible for a company to commit an offence under the legislation. This leaves only Angela, who despite making a loss does commit an offence under the CJA.

Question 60

[1051076] If a firm is unable to disclose the exact costs payable by a client on providing a client agreement, what must the firm do?
A
Refuse to trade for the client
B
Disclose the basis on which the fee will be calculated
C
State that according to FCA regulations charges do not need to be disclosed
D
Disclose charges made to a similar client investing in a substantially similar investment
The correct answer is: B - Disclose the basis on which the fee will be calculated

Explanation

Where it is not possible to disclose exact fees and commission, the firm must disclose the basis on which these will be calculated.

Question 61

[1051080] An investor has the following spread of assets in his portfolio: Which of the following would best benefit the investor?
A
Increase in interest rates
B
Decrease in interest rates
C
Increase in inflation
D
Decrease in inflation
The correct answer is: B - Decrease in interest rates

Explanation

A decrease in interest rates would improve the ability to borrow. This would increase the demand for property, sending prices higher, and improve conditions in which companies could expand, increasing share prices. A drop in interest rates would also increase the prices of bonds.

Question 62

[1052073] A buy limit order of 2000 shares at a price of 248 has an expiry of next Friday. Which is the BEST answer to when will it execute?
A
When it matches an incoming sell order of 248 before the end of Friday
B
It will execute against another buy order of 248 or less before the end of Friday
C
It will execute against another sell order of 248 or less before the end of Friday
D
It will execute against another sell order of 248 or more before the end of Friday
The correct answer is: C - It will execute against another sell order of 248 or less before the end of Friday

Explanation

A limit order is to buy or sell a volume at a price or better. This order will buy at 248 or cheaper before the end of Friday.

Question 63

[1052171] Under the Joint Money Laundering Steering Group Guidance Notes, which of the following would identify why enhanced due diligence is required for a politically exposed person?
A
Due to their position, they are more vulnerable to corruption
B
They have the ability to withhold information
C
They live overseas
D
They work for an authorised firm
The correct answer is: A - Due to their position, they are more vulnerable to corruption

Explanation

The main factor used in identifying a politically exposed person (PEP) is their vulnerability to corruption. According to JMLSG Guidance this includes persons who are: heads of state, heads of government and ministers; members of parliaments; members of supreme courts, or of other high-level judicial bodies whose decisions are not generally subject to further appeal; members of courts of auditors or of the boards of central banks; ambassadors, and high-ranking officers in the armed forces; and members of the administrative, management or supervisory boards of State-owned enterprises. These categories also include direct family members of the above, such as spouse, children and parents. They do not, however, include middle-ranking or more junior officials.

Question 64

[1052675] Marie Sanchez has taxable earned income of 30,000 (after taking into account her personal allowance). She realised a capital gains of 4,000 after using her CGT allowance. How much CGT is she due on this gain?
A
880.90
B
720
C
933.50
D
1,200
The correct answer is: C - 933.50

Explanation

The basic rate band ends at 31,865. Marie's gain moves beyond this band. For this reason she will be taxed on the gain partly at the basic rate (18%) and partly at the higher rate (28%). The first 1,865 of the gain is taxed at 18%: 1,865 x 0.18 = 335.70 The remaining 2,135 is taxed at 28%: 2,135 x 0.28 = 597.80 The tax due on the gain is: 335.70 + 597.80 = 933.50

Question 65

[1054064] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year. They own a variety of investments and usually meet with their financial advisor semi-annually. Saliy owns 50,000 of shares, which she bought six years ago for 5,000. In the previous fiscal year, she sold these shares to Dahir for 20,000 and has repurchased them this year for 25,000. In this fiscal year Saliy, transferred 30,000NV of gilts with a 5% coupon to Dahir. He has decided to sell them six months into the fiscal year. They are currently trading at PAR. The couple are planning to move house and have had an offer accepted on a house they like at 250,000 and are moving towards completion. They have agreed to sell their cottage to a Mr and Mrs Wilson at its current value. This will be the first home that the Wilson's have owned. Their financial advisor has suggested that they invest in a Venture Capital Trust. He inform them that they could invest up to 200,000 per year and this would result in an income tax relief of of 30,000. He explains that the vehicle is low risk due to the wide variety of companies it invests in. Saliy will need to make tax payments:
A
In April and October each year.
B
Monthly
C
By January and July each year.
D
Through PAYE
The correct answer is: C - By January and July each year.

Explanation

As Saliy earns over 80% of her income through self-employent she will pay 50% of her taxes in advance by the end of January and 50% in arrears to be paid by the end of July.

Question 66

[1054065] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year. They own a variety of investments and usually meet with their financial advisor semi-annually. Saliy owns 50,000 of shares, which she bought six years ago for 5,000. In the previous fiscal year, she sold these shares to Dahir for 20,000 and has repurchased them this year for 25,000. In this fiscal year Saliy, transferred 30,000NV of gilts with a 5% coupon to Dahir. He has decided to sell them six months into the fiscal year. They are currently trading at PAR. The couple are planning to move house and have had an offer accepted on a house they like at 250,000 and are moving towards completion. They have agreed to sell their cottage to a Mr and Mrs Wilson at its current value. This will be the first home that the Wilson's have owned. Their financial advisor has suggested that they invest in a Venture Capital Trust. He inform them that they could invest up to 200,000 per year and this would result in an income tax relief of of 30,000. He explains that the vehicle is low risk due to the wide variety of companies it invests in. What type of National Insurance contributions will Dahir and Saliy pay?
A
Dahir, Class 2; Saliy, Class 2
B
Dahir, Class 2; Saliy, Class 3
C
Dahir, Class 1; Saliy, Class 2 and 4
D
Dahir, Class 4; Saliy, Class 3
The correct answer is: C - Dahir, Class 1; Saliy, Class 2 and 4

Explanation

Dahir is employed, so his employer pays class 1. Saliy is self-employed, so will pay class 2 and 4 as long as she makes the necessary level of profit.

Question 67

[1054066] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year. They own a variety of investments and usually meet with their financial advisor semi-annually. Saliy owns 50,000 of shares, which she bought six years ago for 5,000. In the previous fiscal year, she sold these shares to Dahir for 20,000 and has repurchased them this year for 25,000. In this fiscal year Saliy, transferred 30,000NV of gilts with a 5% coupon to Dahir. He has decided to sell them six months into the fiscal year. They are currently trading at PAR. The couple are planning to move house and have had an offer accepted on a house they like at 250,000 and are moving towards completion. They have agreed to sell their cottage to a Mr and Mrs Wilson at its current value. This will be the first home that the Wilson's have owned. Their financial advisor has suggested that they invest in a Venture Capital Trust. He inform them that they could invest up to 200,000 per year and this would result in an income tax relief of of 30,000. He explains that the vehicle is low risk due to the wide variety of companies it invests in. What is the total amount received by the HMRC for both home sales/purchases?
A
2,500
B
4,500
C
7,500
D
9,500
The correct answer is: B - 4,500

Explanation

Mr and Mrs Wilson would pay 200,000 x 1% = 2,000. Dahir and Saliy would pay 250,000 x 1% = 2,500.

Question 68

[1054067] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year. They own a variety of investments and usually meet with their financial advisor semi-annually. Saliy owns 50,000 of shares, which she bought six years ago for 5,000. In the previous fiscal year, she sold these shares to Dahir for 20,000 and has repurchased them this year for 25,000. In this fiscal year Saliy, transferred 30,000NV of gilts with a 5% coupon to Dahir. He has decided to sell them six months into the fiscal year. They are currently trading at PAR. The couple are planning to move house and have had an offer accepted on a house they like at 250,000 and are moving towards completion. They have agreed to sell their cottage to a Mr and Mrs Wilson at its current value. This will be the first home that the Wilson's have owned. Their financial advisor has suggested that they invest in a Venture Capital Trust. He inform them that they could invest up to 200,000 per year and this would result in an income tax relief of of 30,000. He explains that the vehicle is low risk due to the wide variety of companies it invests in. Saliy is considering selling her shares. How much CGT would she pay? (Assume that she has made no other capital gains this year)
A
14,000
B
3,920
C
896
D
12,600
The correct answer is: B - 3,920

Explanation

As she had sold the shares to her husband in the previous fiscal year and repurchased them in this fiscal year, she can benefit from the practice of bed and spouse, which allows her to use her CGT allowances on each of these sales. This means that any prior gains or losses would have been settled at the previous sale, so she is only liable for CGT since the repurchase. (Disposal - cost of purchase - allowance) X CGT rate (50,000 - 25,000 - 11,000) X 0.28 = 3,920

Question 69

[1054068] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year. They own a variety of investments and usually meet with their financial advisor semi-annually. Saliy owns 50,000 of shares, which she bought six years ago for 5,000. In the previous fiscal year, she sold these shares to Dahir for 20,000 and has repurchased them this year for 25,000. In this fiscal year Saliy, transferred 30,000NV of gilts with a 5% coupon to Dahir. He has decided to sell them six months into the fiscal year. They are currently trading at PAR. The couple are planning to move house and have had an offer accepted on a house they like at 250,000 and are moving towards completion. They have agreed to sell their cottage to a Mr and Mrs Wilson at its current value. This will be the first home that the Wilson's have owned. Their financial advisor has suggested that they invest in a Venture Capital Trust. He inform them that they could invest up to 200,000 per year and this would result in an income tax relief of of 30,000. He explains that the vehicle is low risk due to the wide variety of companies it invests in. If Dahir sells the bonds, what would be his total tax liability in relation to the bonds (this year)? Assume he has made not used his capital gains tax allowance.
A
150
B
3,642
C
300
D
3,792
The correct answer is: A - 150

Explanation

He would receive one set of semi-annual coupons at 5% 30,000 X 0.05 / 2 = 750. His income tax liability would be 750 X 0.20 = 150. There is no CGT payable on disposal of bonds.

Question 70

[1054069] Dahir and Saliy have been happily married for 30 years and live in a small rural cottage in Derbyshire. It has a current value of 200,000 and they purchased it for 130,000. Saliy is a self-employed contractor earning approximately 60,000 a year, and Dahir works at a university as a lab technician earning 20,000 per year.
